I table the documents. Will the honourable senator please come to the table to make and subscribe the oath or affirmation of allegiance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform honourable senators that His Excellency the Governor-General appointed the Hon. Neal Blewett as Minister for Trade and Overseas Development on Friday, 1 February 1991. Dr Blewett is now responsible for development assistance issues as well as trade negotiations. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to yesterday's Melbourne Age, which reports further dissent of the parliamentary Left towards the Government's Gulf policy, and I ask: does the Minister agree with Senator Childs when he, as convener of the Left, says that the allies should now hold back from further military operations against Iraq? If Senator Ray does not agree, can he indicate what steps will be taken to further discipline the parliamentary Left following the obviously unsuccessful attempt to censure them last week? When will the Government demand from its own Party the same sense of national unity on the Gulf war which it is seeking from the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my role and never will be to be the arbiter of what my Party says or thinks on particular issues. Senator Childs is quite entitled to express his views within the proper forums of the Party. He does so--
—You cannot lead your Party; you cannot lead your country.

—What we have opposite is the nearest thing to a set of daleks I have ever seen. All they can pipe out is, `I shall obey'. The 30-odd opposite are political daleks. What is crucial in any of these events-and one of the things that the Labor Party has reasserted in recent days; it is the principle we have had since 1891-is collective decision making and support of those collective decisions. It has never been the tradition of the Labor Party not to have internal debate on these issues; we do, we have done so for 100 years now, and we will continue to do so for another 100 years. That is the nature of the Labor Party-to debate these issues, to consider them and to come to a collective decision.

ANSWER.PARA: How many times have we sat in this chamber and heard the other side criticise our collective decision making by saying what a terrible thing it is that we make collective decisions and stick by them and that we do not have a conscience or anything else? Here they are getting up today saying that we all have to think along exactly the same lines. In politics dissent and debate is a healthy thing; something that the other side should learn. Those opposite focus their differences exclusively on personality and ambition. At least we, on this side of the chamber, from time to time debate principled issues-and we will continue to do so during the next 100 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Defence provide the Senate with details of additional costs to the Defence portfolio associated with Australia's commitment to the Gulf?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of times over recent weeks I have been asked to quantify the additional cost of our deployment to the Gulf. In responding to those questions I indicated that there were appropriate processes of government to be followed. I can now report to the Senate that those processes are now complete. Yesterday I took to Cabinet a submission outlining the additional costs of our Gulf deployment, which covers areas such as additional service allowances, additional equipment items, equipment repair, replenishment stores such as fuel, rations and weapons, and administrative support expenses. Cabinet approved additional funds of $68.882m in 1990-91 to cover immediately one-time costs, and a further $27.475m spread over the following two years to cover replacement stores and equipment repair. This comes to a total of $96.357m. The funds sought will be covered in part-that is, $52.659m worth-by a special Appropriation Bill to be introduced into the House later this week and the remainder through the normal Additional Estimates process. I have to make it clear that much of the speculation in the press that put the figure at $150m was mere speculation and tended to be very poor journalism.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, I point out that these are currently known costs. There may be additional costs, but if they exist a similar process will be gone through in which the Defence Department will seek to be fully supplemented for its commitment to the Gulf.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the Minister's statement about the refusal to permit the export of defence equipment worth $450m. I ask: when was an application made for the export of this equipment? Was the application considered by the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports and, if so, when? When and why was the application refused?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have in my head the immediate dates. That should not surprise Senator Durack, given the amount of applications we have. The application was made last year though, and I will get the exact date.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Durack also asked whether the matter was considered by the Committee. Yes, it was, but there is some misunderstanding by Senator Durack and others as to how the Committee works. It does not meet formally necessarily to make decisions. Quite often that is done by a telephone ring around, which I regard as a much more sensible approach than to have continual formal meetings.

On the third point as to whether I could identify the project, Senator Durack would realise that in the latest set of guidelines issued in 1989 it is made quite clear that all applications will be treated as commercial-in-confidence. I have no intention in this case or in any other case of revealing those applications that were rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I did not ask the Minister to identify the projects. I asked him why the application was refused.
—I regret knocking that straw man down. It was rejected because it was sending a particularly lethal product into an area of instability.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to an article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald by Greg Austin which alleges that Australia has increased its commitment in the Gulf by sending up to 10 military intelligence specialists to Saudi Arabia. I ask: can the Minister confirm the details in that article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much of that article happens to be incorrect. For instance, it quotes me as saying to Caucus yesterday that our commitment in the Gulf is $53m. First, I did not address Caucus yesterday on the subject and, secondly, as honourable senators can see from the figures alluded to in an earlier answer, it was quite a different cost for our Gulf commitment. Apparently there are currently 28 Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel on exchange with the coalition forces in the Gulf. As one would expect, some of these are involved in planning and intelligence. I would like to quote what I said very clearly at a press conference on 25 January because the author of the article had not realised that I was on public record when I said:

ANSWER.PARA: We have people involved in the planning process both in Riyadh and in the naval command. Now I am not going into any more detail on that but they do get access to all information, are actively involved and they will bring back some very valuable lessons.

The figure I have mentioned today of 28 will fluctuate from time to time-anywhere between 20 and 35-as people who are on exchange and finish their rotations come back to Australia and more go onto rotation depending on which particular unit they are assigned to.

I am not going to make an announcement every time there is a minor change to numbers in the Gulf. For example, I saw no point particularly in announcing that we sent several radio technicians to make repairs to the radios of HMAS Westralia. The fluctuation in these figures obviously does not represent any major change in our commitment of forces to the Gulf. What I regard as major changes would be extra combat elements such as F111s, Hornets, infantry units or further ships. I think I should make it very clear that that is what we talk about in terms of escalation, not minor variations to numbers in the Gulf, which go up and down. In conclusion, let me say that the latest figure for ADF personnel serving in the Gulf today is 760.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Defence. I remind the Minister of his answer to a question from my colleague Senator Paul McLean on 12 November 1990 regarding the National Service Act 1951. After accusing Senator McLean of `misleading this place', the Minister went on to say:

QUESTION.PARA: The national service scheme was abolished by administrative measures immediately after the election of the Whitlam Government in December 1972 . . . The National Service Act was not repealed at the time because some national servicemen continued to serve in the Army and it was necessary to keep the Act in force. However, the National Service Termination Bill 1973 was passed. This made it clear that no-one is liable to register or render service under the National Service Act. It is clear beyond all doubt that the National Service Act could not be revived by an Executive or administrative action.
It is perfectly plain that the National Service Act is completely defunct.

If the Minister's answer to Senator McLean was correct in November of last year, I ask: why is the Government now planning to repeal the National Service Act as reported in Melbourne's Sunday Age and admitted by the Prime Minister on Channel 9's Sunday program? Has the Government now looked more closely at that Act and discovered that the Minister was incorrect and therefore did the Minister mislead the Senate on 12 November last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be the case that one or two people have been knocking down a straw man that Senator Powell has managed to set up. I do not change any of my answer that I gave to Senator McLean. I believe I am correct. I have yet to have an opportunity to have a discussion with Mr Dawkins about this matter, but at the moment, on my reading of it, I happen to be correct. It may be that Mr Dawkins did not fully understand what the 1973 Act is about. I do not know yet; I will have to have that discussion with him. I maintain my position and I would be happy if Senator Powell, or someone else, can produce some evidence that, in fact, my position is wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have seen is a continuation of the old conscription campaign being shoved out into the community by a range of people. False letters are still going out in a desperate attempt to link conscription with the Gulf commitment, because that is the only way some people think that they can create an emotive enough climate to establish opposition to the Government's position, which has been-and we are grateful for it-endorsed by the Opposition.

I think it is about time the Australian Democrats and others accepted that this is an absolutely buried, dead issue. I repeat: this Government will not introduce conscription unless the territory of Australia is under attack and then we would need legislation carried by both chambers. That is in the Australian Labor Party platform of the 1988 conference, fully endorsed by this Government and it will be abided by this Government.

The issue of conscription is an irrelevant red herring introduced by gullible people trying to distort our Gulf commitment. I do not want anyone coming to me and saying, `This is just accidental'. We are still getting people ringing radio stations saying that the Government Printing Office is printing off the forms. Not one form has been produced out of all these allegations. False letters are still going out to people of eligible age saying that they are liable to be conscripted. I do not know who is masterminding this campaign. I know the people opposite are not-of course they are not; nevertheless, I think they are encouraging it. I stand by my answer of November until somebody can point out exactly where I am wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support comment upon recent media criticism about the revised stevedoring employment arrangements approved by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) for the port of Cairns, particularly adverse comments about the likelihood of achieving the required reduction in the stevedoring work force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been considerable adverse criticism of a provisional agreement between the Stevedoring Employers of Australia Ltd (SEAL) and the stevedoring union in Cairns, endorsed recently by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority. A great deal of that criticism has centred around claims that have been made that the 13 workers who would be made redundant in the port of Cairns as part of this provisional agreement would not accept those voluntary redundancies.

ANSWER.PARA: Interestingly enough, at a major seminar on shipping and waterfront issues that I addressed in Sydney this morning, during the question time session-which is when most of the criticism was laid-the senior executive of one of the major users of the port of Cairns asserted that we would not get the union to deliver its commitment to persuade 13 of its members to leave Cairns under voluntary redundancy because, as he put it, the redundant workers have got little to do, live in a very congenial climate and are on good wages.

I am able to advise the Senate now that a short time ago I was very pleased to be advised by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority that in response to the offers of redundancy that were issued by SEAL, 13 workers in the port of Cairns have now formally accepted those offers of redundancy and will leave the port. The target date that has been set for their actual exit from the port is 28 February.

An annual saving of around $360,000 will be made by reducing by 60 per cent the current port work force. The only reason I mention that is that, had this offer, which was made by the Government through WIRA last year, been accepted at the time, this level of savings could already have been achieved in the Port of Cairns. I regret that that was not the case, but I can assure honourable senators, despite assertions to the contrary, that the negotiation process in Cairns has not been quite as simple and clear cut as people would have it. Most of the parties involved in the negotiations, not just the unions, have changed their positions substantially during those negotiations. I stress that this is a provisional agreement. It will simply open the way for an immediate and significant reduction in the cost of operating the Port of Cairns and it will open the way for the negotiation of a final agreement for that port.

I conclude by saying that, despite all the criticism, I am grateful for the assistance that was given by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority and the role it played in negotiating this settlement. I am also grateful, particularly as a result of a number of personal visits I made to Cairns and meetings that were held there, for the personal assistance of and contribution that was made to achieving this partial resolution of the problem in Cairns by the honourable member for Leichhardt, Mr John Gayler.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Given the statement of Tim Marcus Clark of the State Bank of South Australia that the bank reports to the Reserve Bank of Australia monthly, quarterly and annually and that it cooperates fully with the bank's officers and meets all prudential guidelines, including capital adequacy, credit exposures and liquidity, and that the Reserve Bank of Australia had posted an officer full time in the head office of the State Bank, which was current as at 19 March 1990, when did the Treasurer first become aware of the problems with the State Bank of South Australia and when did the Reserve Bank draw this matter to the Treasurer's attention?
—What the Reserve Bank did or did not do in relation to the State Bank of South Australia is something which I am not able at this time to provide details about.
—You should be able to.

—Really? I was not aware of Mr Marcus Clark's statement. Mr Marcus Clark has left his position as chief executive of the bank and, I suspect, has made a number of statements. I am not aware of the credibility or veracity of any of those statements, so I cannot make a comment about them. However, as far as the State Bank is concerned, in a strict sense State banks, wherever they may be, are not federally supervised. It may well be that the State Bank of South Australia, sensing some apprehension about its future, approached the Reserve Bank and made some arrangements. I do not know. The fact of the matter is that State banks are not federally supervised banks. In South Australia even the State Government is at arm's length from the State Bank by virtue of the State Banking Act of South Australia.
—What are you talking about?

—I would not get excited about all that. As I understand it, the State Banking Act in South Australia does not give the Premier any authority to direct the bank on any matter. In relation to the precise details of the arrangements which Mr Marcus Clark has presumably made public and to which Senator Olsen's question is directed, I will obtain an answer about those details as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given that Australia is now looking, along with the rest of the world community, to a post-war settlement in the Middle East, will the Minister confirm that the Australian Government will give a high priority to seeking a resolution to the internal strife in Lebanon? Is the Minister aware of widespread sentiment within the Australian community that resolving the conflict in Lebanon is of real significance in establishing the preconditions for a just and enduring settlement in the Middle East region generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has constantly made clear our view that, once the Gulf crisis is resolved, the international community will have not just the opportunity but the very heavy responsibility to address the other causes of continuing instability in the Middle East. Among those is the continuing unhappy situation in Lebanon, in particular the presence of foreign forces there.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no question of any linkage, of course, in this respect. These are separate and distinct issues. The Gulf crisis must be solved first but, when it is solved, that, along with the question of the security of Israel and the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people for recognition and respect, will be very high on the agenda. Certainly, I think everyone in this country feels very deeply the tragedy and the destruction which has plagued Lebanon for so many years and which has touched the lives of so many Lebanese Australians. Efforts, however, that have already now been begun by the Lebanese people themselves give grounds for some optimism that major progress can be made now on Lebanon's underlying constitutional and political problems.

The Taif accord, which was agreed by an overwhelming majority of Lebanese parliamentarians in October 1989, sets out a new Lebanese national charter aiming at political reforms and other steps to resolve the fundamental causes of the civil war. The most important of those reforms is the political power sharing between Christians and Muslims in an enlarged Parliament, and also the agreement on a framework for the withdrawal of Syrian forces from Lebanon and the extension of the Lebanese Government's authority throughout Lebanon. Some progress has been achieved in implementing the Taif accord since October 1989 but serious problems remain, obviously, in the way of ensuring enduring peace and security, not least the question, as Senator Hill pointed out, of the Syrian forces remaining on Lebanese land, tarnishing conspicuously in that respect claims of Lebanese sovereignty. There is also, of course, Israel's continued occupation of its self-styled security zone in Lebanon.

These destabilising factors underline that while the Taif agreement has been a major step in the right direction, foreign intervention is still a constraint on the Lebanese authorities' capacity to exercise full control over their territory. We can simply all hope that discussions once the Gulf crisis is over will provide an opportunity for the international community to assist in the implementation of that agreement, and the achievement of lasting peace and security in that part of the Middle East.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether it is correct that, despite all the misleading bluster about 29 banks offering the new deeming rate, none of the four major banks pay interest if the account balance is below $2,000. If that is correct why should not pensioners, like all other depositors, be entitled to receive interest on any amount? In view of the fact that the 10 per cent with no strings attached is clearly not available, will the Minister urgently review this ill-considered decision and set a more realistic rate that will do away with the current plethora of complexities and exceptions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to keep the matter under constant review and the 10 per cent will not stay in place set in concrete forever. It can and will be varied if it needs to be.
—It needs to be, take my word for it.
—I do not think I will take Senator Archer's word for it on this occasion or any other.
—You are missing a bit of good advice.

—I have managed to last 41 years without it and I will keep going. When I look at the accounts that are available around Australia, I think the point which Senator Alston has not made is that pensioners are being offered 10 per cent when in some cases other customers of banks are not. In fact, they are able to get in some of those banks and financial institutions an advantage, given of course the decades that have gone by when billions of dollars of pensioners' money was left in these institutions to earn 4, 5 and 6 per cent to be lent out at 15 to 20 per cent. The banks had that enormous margin of profit going on for ever and ever. One should not bleed too much for them.

ANSWER.PARA: The banks have tracked the Government's decision and because for single pensioners the first $2,000 is going to be deemed at the actual rate received, and if that is nothing then we will deem it at nothing, the banks have made in many cases the first $2,000 interest free. This has not happened in all cases. The Commonwealth Bank gives 10 per cent from the first dollar in its special account for pensioners. That being the case, because that 10 per cent is available from the first dollar--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong.
—I am not wrong. The Commonwealth Bank has the 10 per cent available from the first dollar.
—No, it does not.
—It is very early in the session for Senator Walters to be so agitated; remain calm, please.
—You are wrong. Go and ask your staff.

—I do not think I will need to do that. Then, in looking at what the banks would do if indeed the rate was dropped, the intention of the banks, of course, would be to continue to track the Government's decision. So, as long as the first $2,000 was free-that is, free of interest as far as our legislation is concerned-the banks, if I reduced it to 9 per cent tomorrow, would still have the same conditions applying and so the problems to which some people referred in the last few days would not go away.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have got to look at are the enormous pluses for pensioners involved in this. In the absence of other income it is still the case that any single pensioner with less than $20,000 in the bank is not going to be affected by this measure. Even if they were going to put money in an account that required more than $2,000 to get the relevant rate of interest, the reality is that they have got to have a lot more than that to even be affected by this and to have to worry.

Given the misleading statements which some have made on this and which have tended to frighten pensioners into believing that every one of them is affected when, in fact, very few are-and even though the Department has already written to those it can readily identify as being affected by deeming-I will be writing to all aged pensioners over the course of the next few weeks to make sure that all of them have, yet again, the real message about deeming; that is, that every person affected finishes up with more disposable income. Mr President, that is, of course, the right kind of reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister seriously telling the Senate that he is not aware that the Commonwealth Bank will pay interest from the first dollar only if one has an account balance in excess of $2,000 and that, if the balance is below $2,000-and it can be either a set figure or fluctuating below-it pays no interest at all? If Senator Richardson is not aware of that, why did he not take up his solemn promise to consult with the Senate Committee on Community Affairs, when he said he would?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I readily conceded the point to which Senator Alston referred.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The ignorance coming from the back was about whether or not there was an account where 10 per cent applied from the first dollar. I dismissed the ignorance, as I always will. What Senator Alston then said is that one has got to have $2,000. I pointed out that to be affected by this one is going to have more than $2,000-in almost every case a lot more. So I just do not regard that as a problem. In terms of consulting with the Committee, as Senator Alston would be aware, I did in fact send a fax to all members of the Committee about this--
—The fact is that some of the commercial banks give 12 per cent.
—Order! Senator Alston, you do not have any more rights than any other senator in here and I will ask you to refrain from interjecting consistently.

—Thank you, Mr President. I did send a fax to all members of Senator Zakharov's committee. I am sure that Senator West would have got one. I did so, as I recall, four or five days before I made the decision. One Opposition senator-and it was not Senator Alston-actually decided to contact me, and that was Senator Walters. I want to praise Senator Walters for taking that interest. I want to say, Mr President, that Senator Walters showed a real interest, unlike other Opposition senators, in this question. I want to go further in praising her-do not stop me, please: not only did she show an interest, but when I tried to contact her-and I rang her home at 7.25 on the morning before I was making the announcement-a gentleman, who I presumed to be her husband, answered the phone and told me that she had already gone to Devonport either on party business or on business of the Senate. I congratulate Senator Walters on at least trying. As I am sure she will concede, I did try to get back to her.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to a reported decision by the Government of Taiwan to reduce imports of quality beef from Australia to the extent of $60m a year. Can the Minister advise what the implications of the Taiwanese action are for the Australian beef industry and also for trade between the two countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that we have received confirmation through the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei that the Taiwanese authorities have imposed discriminatory measures against imports of Australian shin, shank and brisket beef worth some $62m in 1990 but not, as was reported, against imports of high quality beef. The measures that have been imposed against the lower quality beef are these: first, a reduction in the length of validity of import licences from six months to three months; secondly, the imposition of a handling levy on total transaction values to be paid on application for an import licence rather than, as is usually the case, on raising a letter of credit; thirdly, restricting the coverage of licences to one item only; and fourthly, no extensions of licence validity.

ANSWER.PARA: In December last year, the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation held discussions in Sydney with representatives of Taiwan's trade and agricultural agencies on access for these categories of beef during the current 1990-91 year. The Australian industry rejected Taiwan's proposal that the industry agree to limit exports in 1991 to levels substantially below those shipped in recent years. Although a common position acceptable to both sides was not reached at the December round of discussions, the door was left open for further consultations. There was no advice from Taiwan that further action was being contemplated.

I should say more generally that, over the past 18 months, Taiwan has adopted a number of discriminatory measures against imports of Australian beef for which there has been no shred of justification. This discrimination can only be seen as inconsistent with the spirit of our overall bilateral trading relationship, not to mention Australia's reputation as a reliable and competitive supplier to the Taiwan market. Taiwan's move to discriminate further against imports of Australian beef is absolutely at odds with its stated commitment to trade liberalisation and, for that matter, its aspirations to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

The Australian Government's very strong objection to these latest discriminatory actions has been conveyed to the Taiwan authorities at appropriately senior level through the Australian Commerce and Industry Office. In response, Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade has noted that the measures outlined above apply to all sensitive agricultural imports. The Australian Government will not let this matter rest with that kind of reply and will continue to pursue, through appropriate channels, improved access arrangements for Australian beef to the Taiwan market.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing both the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance. I refer the Minister to the refusal by the Treasurer on 5 February to endorse the statement Minister for Finance five days earlier that the Federal Government's Budget surplus for 1991 is now expected to be about $4 billion, or less than half the surplus predicted at Budget time. I also refer the Minister to the report by Shroders Australia Ltd released yesterday which claimed that there may be no surplus at all this financial year and indeed that a small deficit is possible.

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister now advise the Senate what is the Government's latest considered estimate of the likely Budget outcome, and whether the damaging difference of view between the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance still exists? Can he also advise the Senate of the Government's latest assessment of the extent by which the public sector borrowing requirement will now exceed the Budget estimate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In so far as the Budget surplus is concerned, let me state quite clearly that there will be a significant shortfall in the projected 1990-91 surplus. The extent of that shortfall is very difficult to calculate precisely at present; however, it is implicit in what I said that it is believed that there will be a surplus, which answers one part of the question, and that will be a major force for national savings. In so far as the reduction in the surplus is concerned, it can be readily understood that tax receipts have fallen, unemployment benefits have risen and there has been no fiscal relaxation by the Government other than in respect of the tax cuts which commenced on 1 January this year which, amongst other things, are designed to have a stimulatory effect and to help reduce inflation. As I have said, those reasons in relation to the decline in surplus are quite clear.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Short quoted some document-I did not hear the source of it-which suggested that there would be no surplus at all but, in fact, a minor deficit. That is certainly not in the Government's forecast purview at present. In terms of fiscal policy, every piece of legislation which comes into this place, such as the Moomba gas pipeline legislation, which was rejected by the Opposition and cost the Budget surplus a projected $700m, has to be considered very carefully by people like the honourable senator who are concerned about these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. In thanking the Minister for that answer, I note that he can see that it is difficult to calculate the extent of the shortfall at this time. Does that mean that he does not agree with the statement by the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, on 31 January that the deficit will come in at `around $4 billion'?
—I am not in a position to agree or disagree about that. It is not a matter that I have discussed with the Minister.
—Get some briefs.

—Senator Kemp should take some advice from me and haul his briefs up; they are down around his legs. Let me deal with Senator Kemp's silly interjection. I have just said in answer to Senator Short's question-the honourable senator was probably chatting to Senator Bishop at the time; I do not know-that there would be a significant shortfall in terms of the Budget forecast. That ought to be as clear as a bell. If the honourable senator does not understand that, it is his problem, not mine. I will not take the answer beyond that. In between Budgets, the honourable senator comes in here and asks: is the Budget forecast on this going to be met, is it going to be met on that, and so on? I understand what he is asking and he ought to understand my answer.

—Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen reports on the Sunday program on 10 February and in today's Australian of civilian casualties from the Middle East war estimating the number of civilians killed to range from hundreds to hundreds of thousands? Does the Minister accept that even if only one civilian had been killed in each bombing raid on Iraq the death toll would now be over 40,000? What are the most current estimates of civilian casualties in Israel, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq arising from the war? Will the Minister undertake never to use the appalling euphemism `collateral damage' when referring to civilian deaths as a result of war action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Sunday program with its very diverse array of estimates of civilian casualties. Do I accept that even if only one civilian had been killed in each bombing raid on Iraq the death toll would now be over 40,000? The arithmetic is impeccable, but the premises on which it is based are really highly challengeable. The truth of the matter is that less than half of the 40,000 or more sorties that have been flown since this war began were in the nature of bombing raids involving either carpet bombing or the use of precision and guided bombs.

ANSWER.PARA: The rest of them have been in the nature of air defence suppression, combat air patrols, airborne early warning, airborne refuelling or transport missions of one kind or another. Indeed, of those less than half the number of sorties that have been in the nature of bombing raids, a very high proportion have been directed at purely military targets in the sense that there is no likelihood whatsoever of a civilian being present-for example, Scud sites or forward military positions in Kuwait. There is simply no foundation, as I say, for that kind of emotive arithmetic.

As to the actual estimates of civilian casualties, it is simply not possible for the coalition side to make any credible estimates of the civilian casualties that have occurred in Iraq or Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, and no attempt at an estimate has been made, except that it is appropriate for me to make the point that no civilian targets have been attacked as such by the coalition forces during the entire course of this war, nor is it intended that they be. The intention has been, and the effect has been, to target very narrowly, precisely and, for the most part, extremely effectively. Many eye witness accounts have referred to the very great precision of the coalition bombing raids and, indeed, of coalition aircraft risking returning to base fully laden with ordnance simply because targets could not be properly verified and because of the danger and difficulty of misplacing them in civilian directions.

I should further make the point that the coalition's task is complicated by what appears to be a conscious Iraqi tactic of moving military equipment into civilian areas, concealing arms production and research facilities in what have been previously regular industrial complexes and, furthermore, by the massive scale of the Iraqi military establishment, which means that strategic facilities are scattered throughout the length and breadth of the country.

Having made all those qualifications, all one can do in terms of assessing civilian casualties is refer to the Iraqi Government's own published figures, and we are simply unable to judge what degree of accuracy they may represent. However, the published figures for civilian casualties are 467 dead and 400 injured. The only other country for which I have any casualty figures available is Israel, and the Government's own figures there are four dead and 299 now injured.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you call that collateral bombing?

—I want to say something more about that. I will take advantage of that interjection from Senator Crichton-Browne to make the very obvious point that not only from the coalition's side has there been an extraordinarily intense and dedicated effort to avoid civilian casualties, but also the contrast between that and the attitude and behaviour of the Iraqi side could not be more apparent, not least in the quite explicit targeting of civilian populations in Saudi Arabia and Israel. Beyond that there is Saddam Hussein's spectacularly obvious disregard for casualties among his own ground forces, which he has now committed to militarily disastrous action, his overt public threats to use weapons of mass destruction and, indeed, his record of appalling behaviour towards the civilian population of Kuwait.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the final question, whether I would undertake never to use the appalling euphemism `collateral damage', the honourable senator and the Senate will know that I have some difficulty in making an undertaking not to use appalling language generally, but I will do my best in future as far as that specific request is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. In view of the fact that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, has failed to honour the undertaking he gave the wool trade and the wool industry that the floor price of 700c would be maintained for the whole of this wool selling season and including the 1991-92 season, to what extent can the industry and the trade have confidence in Mr Kerin's and the Government's most recent undertaking, that the Government will make supplementary payments to make up the difference between market prices for wool and what would have been received under the 700c per kilo reserve price? Should the market fall below 375c per kilo, will the Minister give an assurance that the Government will continue to make up the difference between wherever the market might fall and the 700c per kilogram reserve price for the rest of this wool selling season?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In so far as the statements made previously by Mr Kerin in relation to the wool industry are concerned, let me say that a lot of water has flown under the bridge since then-noted by everybody, except perhaps the National Party of Australia. For example, it was not Mr Kerin who had to change his mind drastically; it was the leaders of the wool industry who had to change their minds drastically about this sort of thing. They had a position which was quite firm last year and which they have changed on several occasions, as the realities of the world market became increasingly apparent to them. They misread a few signals and, as the realities became apparent, they changed their view.

ANSWER.PARA: The undertaking given by Mr Kerin, in terms of equity in the remains of this wool season between those who have already sold their wool at a price above 700c and those who will now be selling their wool, will be honoured.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. On 7 February the Opposition spokesperson on retirement incomes, Senator Alston, was quoted in the Melbourne Age as saying that a coalition government would legislate to curb increases in across the board award-based superannuation. What is the Minister's response to this proposal? Does the Government also plan to legislate to curb award-based superannuation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see a very interesting report in the Age on the suggestion that Senator Alston has brought forward. It was not, as far as I can recall, his debut performance on the front page, but I think he would have liked better than a headline which said, `Libs would end award super: Alston'.
—You didn't read the second edition, did you?

—I am getting to that. Senator Alston should not worry; I read it. The story was based on a speech that Senator Alston had delivered, as I understand it, the same day. In fact, he had not delivered it at that point. I think it came later. I do not know whether he had spoken to his Leader about this, but I do know that by the time the second edition came out the headline was not that Libs would `end award super' but that Libs would `curb award super'. In any event, what he did commit the Liberal Party to-and this is what I am asked about-was amending the Industrial Relations Act so that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission `could not facilitate, let alone insist on, arbitrary across the board superannuation increases'. I thought that was interesting.

ANSWER.PARA: I might say that we have not finished yet, even after two goes, because Senator Alston bobbed up again in the `Letters to the Editor' column yesterday-just to keep everyone on their toes-and this time the headline was, `Coalition wants to expand super'. I have to say that it was a bit difficult to justify the third one. We might not have had a lot of trouble with the first two, but we could have some real trouble with the third. Senator Alston tried to argue that the present system was unfair because it gave trade unionists-those horrible, nasty trade unionists-award super increases while some others missed out.

One wonders what we are objecting to. Even since 1985 award superannuation coverage has extended from 40 per cent of the work force to about 55 per cent now. What is wrong with a 15 per cent increase in the number of those who have gained access to superannuation? As far as I am concerned, the Government remains committed to that extension of superannuation across the board, which will, of course, ensure that future governments-no matter what political persuasion they might be-are able to assist in providing retirement incomes and that people themselves will have already assisted in it and increased the standard of living to which they are entitled and which they might expect in their later years.

But, of course, Senator Alston has gone backwards. He has gone back to the system of some years ago. Before we came in there were the Fraser-Howard years, advised by John Hewson. The system for superannuation was, `The boss has got it and the workers miss out'. The well-off got big tax concessions and superannuation was voluntary only for the bosses. This Government remains absolutely committed. We will bat on with extending superannuation across the board; we will bat on with providing better retirement incomes for Australians.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to a report in the Australian of 11 February headlined `Wallabies Plan Quick Detour to South Africa'. The article claims that the Australian rugby union team aims to make a lightning visit to South Africa in October next year, before its tour of Ireland and Wales, and that the tour will occur after the Springboks make an eight-match tour of Australia, including two tests. I ask the Minister: what is the Australian Government's attitude towards these proposed tours? Is it conceivable that such tours could occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report to which Senator Childs referred and indeed another one in the same vein in the Canberra Times this morning. The Government's position on the resumption of sporting links with South Africa has been perfectly clear for a very long time and has also been made clear, in the new context that has existed since the recent changes in South Africa and, in particular, the speech of President de Klerk on 1 February, by recent statements of the Prime Minister. Whether lifting of the sports boycott is considered as part of a phased relaxation of sanctions generally or whether it is looked at on its own terms, the Australian Government's position is that it can be contemplated only in respect of those sports which achieve a unified, non-racial structure.

ANSWER.PARA: In some sports, such as soccer and cricket, very significant progress towards such integration has already been achieved. However, similar progress simply has not been achieved in rugby. There are some encouraging signs, for example, in the statement on 7 February following a meeting between South African Rugby Board President Craven and the African National Congress. It was emphasised that the unity of rugby was a matter of extreme urgency. The difficulty is that any such perception there may have been in the past has not yet been mirrored by actions so far as the effective consolidation of the two rugby bodies is concerned.

Under these circumstances it would be quite premature for there to be any planning for any tour of South Africa by any Australian rugby team, let alone any visit to Australia by a Springbok team. Certainly the Australian Government would be wholly opposed to any such tours taking place before the integration of the sport in South Africa was complete.

All that said, I should immediately acknowledge that I do not believe there is any difference between the Australian Government and the Australian Rugby Football Union (ARFU) in this respect, notwithstanding the impression one would glean from reading that newspaper report and particularly its headline and opening paragraphs. In the article in question the President of the ARFU, Joe French, said that any such tours were subject to the abolition of the sports boycott. He also referred to the important talks which have taken place and which, we hope, will now accelerate between the South African Rugby Board and the predominantly non-white South African Rugby Union.

I should add that it is also my understanding-and I have been helped in this respect by reports I have received from Senator Schacht since his very productive visit there a few days ago-that the South African Government would itself regard such tours, prior to the implementation of the necessary reforms within the sporting organisations themselves, as being wholly counterproductive.

I take this opportunity to record my appreciation and that of the Government for the attitude of Mr French and the ARFU on this issue. In the face of very considerable pressure from within their own organisation, they have consistently both understood and supported the Government's position. I am confident that the Rugby Football Union and other sporting bodies in Australia will continue to respect a government position which I believe captures the sentiment of the Australian people on this important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I ask: Was the Government aware prior to 31 January 1991 that the Australian Wool Corporation did not have sufficient finance to continue sales into February and, if not, why not? If the Government was aware, why did it wait until after the suspension of sales to take action and hence further destabilise the industry and market?

—I do not know whether the Government was aware; I was not aware. In order to answer on behalf of the Minister whom I represent in this place, I will pass Senator Crane's question on to him and reply in due course.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Defence. I emphasise that I prepared this question long before Senator Vallentine's urgency motion was circulated. I ask: does the Minister agree that, because of the revelations about the arming of Iraq, the Australian people are now more starkly aware than ever of the immorality of, and the dangers inherent in, the international arms trade? As a practical and symbolic step towards eliminating Australia from the arms trade, will the Minister consider abandoning all Government involvement in, and association with, the AIDEX arms fair later this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not bore the Senate with two speeches in a row on this, so I shall be quite brief. I think the premise in Senator Coates's question is right. One has to learn lessons from history and current events. One of the lessons the world can learn is as to its attitude to the international arms trade.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite clear, when one looks at the armaments in Iraq, that the majority came from the Soviet Union-one of the major powers. That is evident in the tanks, the planes, the anti-aircraft batteries, et cetera. It is equally obvious that some of the missiles and planes came from western Europe, and some of the other technologies required-not as direct defence export-also came from western Europe. I think that we have a reasonable record with regard to arms exports to regions of instability-it is certainly better than most over a long period.

On the question of the exhibition, that is a privately sponsored exhibition and has been for a number of years when it occurs. Without judging it either way, I am going to look into what involvement the Australian Government and the Department of Defence will have in it. I believe there are two areas identified at the moment for involvement. I am going to have a look at that. I am not prejudging it and saying yes, I will cancel our involvement or, no, I will not. I will look at it on its merits, also taking into account changed circumstances. If we do not learn from history I do not think we achieve much.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to a question on 22 January from Senator Faulkner about Australia's response to a United Nations appeal for assistance to victims of the Gulf war, I indicated that the appeal in question had been directed to only 15 countries. I was advised subsequently that the appeal had, in fact, been a general one; the misunderstanding was based on a list I had been given of the responses of the 15 most regular donors to similar appeals. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

`` . . . ICA has not circulated, either internally or publicly, any document which makes any reference to governments (Australian or otherwise) being called on to cover the cost of personal injury and property damage in the event of a terrorist attack in Australia.

ICA's national operations manager distributed an internal memorandum to our regional offices on 17 January, drawing their attention to some of the insurance-related matters which usually arise when a war or war-like situation arises anywhere in the world''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented in remarks made by Senator Richardson in answer to a question from Senator Crowley. Senator Richardson has chosen to leave already. Nonetheless, the clear implication of what was said by him was that the headlines in the Age newspaper on 7 February were, somehow, ones that I had sought to influence in the sense that the first headline clearly grotesquely distorted the text of the article by suggesting that the Opposition would propose to end award superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that the correction to that second headline came about entirely as a result of action taken by the Age itself, and communicated to me in the course of an apology for getting it wrong in the first instance. My letter was clearly intended to clarify that matter in order to put to rest the sorts of headlines that Senator Richardson referred to as `ending' rather than restricting.

I take further exception to the clear suggestion that he made that we were proposing to abolish the award superannuation scheme whereas, in fact, if he had bothered to read the speech, he would have noted that we were concerned about the across the board add-on 3 per cent. The further misrepresentation was in suggesting that somehow it was intended to revert to the `bad old days' when workers missed out. Again, the speech makes it very clear that, in fact, under the current award system workers in general are still missing out very badly indeed. In fact, only 40 per cent of the private sector work force-which is little more than the number of persons who belong to trade unions in the private sector-are benefiting from award superannuation; something approaching $1 billion is outstanding in award orders; and there is a massive non-compliance about which the Government has done nothing. Therefore, I take exception to the suggestion that somehow we were condoning--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I gave leave for a personal explanation to be made on the grounds that the honourable senator had been misrepresented. I think he is now debating the issue. I understand the point he is making about the alleged misrepresentation, but I do not think he can turn it into an attack on Government policy.
—I remind Senator Alston that this is a personal explanation, not a debate.

—I acknowledge that, Mr President. I was not seeking to go beyond making it clear that there were several points where I consider that I have been misrepresented. SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may recall that I raised with him the concerns that the savings of such people could fall into the hands of unscrupulous financial entrepreneurs outside the banking system. Does the Minister further recall that he intended to take steps to reduce the rate below 10 per cent?

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR EDWARD ALBERT ROBERTSON

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 January I informed the Senate of the deaths of former Senator Edward Albert Robertson and a former member of the House of Representatives, the Hon. Gordon Munro Bryant, ED. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate to move a motion of condolence for former Senator Robertson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Saturday, 5 January 1991, of Edward Albert Robertson, Senator for the Northern Territory from 1975 to 1987, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Ted Robertson was born on 18 March 1929 in Albany in Western Australia and was educated at Claremont Teachers College and the University of Western Australia. In the early 1960s he moved to the Northern Territory where he was appointed to a succession of senior administrative posts, eventually becoming Assistant Director of Education for the Territory. He also served as a Reserve officer in the Royal Australian Air Force as an instructor with the air training corps.

His election to the Federal Parliament in 1975 as senator for the Northern Territory was distinguished by the fact that he was one of the Territory's first elected representatives to Federal politics. He served admirably for 12 years until his retirement in 1987. In the course of his parliamentary career he served on many committees and led some overseas delegations to Thailand and Indo-China. Of course, as all honourable senators who were here at the time will know, he served as an Australian Labor Party Whip in the Senate for seven years, first as Opposition Whip from 1980 and then as Government Whip from 1983, following the election of the Hawke Government.

Ted Robertson made a distinguished contribution not only to the Senate but also to the Australian Labor Party and to the general well-being of politics in the Northern Territory. This commitment was recognised as far as the Labor Party was concerned in 1986 when he was made a life member of the Party. As far as I personally am concerned, Ted Robertson and I spanned a common period in politics. He was elected less than a year after I was. I always regarded him as a person who was prepared to do a lot of hard work behind the scenes in politics to keep the political system going. He was a very solid backbencher-some people might say in more ways than one-and was very diligent in discharging his role as an Opposition backbencher. That was even more apparent when he became Whip for the Opposition and for the Government.

As Leader of the Opposition and then Leader of the Government I worked very closely with him as a Whip and he did that job very well. In some ways he was a traditional, conservative Labor Party man. I use the word `conservative' in the best possible sense of the word. He was conservative in his values which were very decent ones. He described himself as a Depression child. He used to say that his family ate regularly during the Depression but nonetheless it was in those years that the foundations of his beliefs and commitments to social justice came about. Ted used to say that he was born an Anglican and a Labor person. Although he recognised, as he used to put it, that there were deficiencies in both systems-Anglican and Labor-none of those deficiencies was sufficient to make him ever change.

When I visited the Territory over a number of years I always had a tremendous impression, which I think Opposition senators will share and Senator Collins will understand, about his involvement in various aspects of Territory life. He was a member of a wide range of community organisations-the Northern Territory Council of Social Service, the Young Men's Christian Association, of which he was recently National President, Austcare and Apex. He was greatly interested in young people and I believe he was always interested in helping the underdog.

He will be remembered as a modest man of dignity and integrity with a deep sense of duty and honour both to his constituency and the institutions to which he belonged. I think he was well respected by his peers. On behalf of the Government, I extend to his family-to his wife, Audrey, and to the other members of his family-our sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I join with the Leader of the Government in expressing our deep regret at the death of Ted Robertson in January at the age of 62. As Senator Button said, Ted Robertson was an Australian Labor Party senator for the Northern Territory from 1975 until his retirement in 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: On a personal level I will remember Ted Robertson as a sincere, dedicated and courteous senator. He was first and foremost a Territorian. His background was in education and on moving to the Territory in the early 1960s he was appointed to a succession of senior administrative posts, eventually becoming Assistant Director of Education. He was, as has just been said, with Senator Kilgariff, one of the first elected federal representatives of the Northern Territory. He saw the Senate as having its original function, that being a forum for the States and, in his case, for the Territory. His role, as he saw it, was to serve the best interests of the Territory even if that involved criticising decisions of his Party.

Senator Robertson was very active in committee work with his interests primarily in the areas of education, social issues and Aboriginal affairs. He was the parliamentary representative on the Council of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies for a total of more than seven years. He was, as has been said, the Australian Labor Party Whip in the Senate from November 1980 until his retirement.

I agree with and note a comment about his wide involvement with many community organisations-Apex, the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA), the Council of Social Service, Rostrum and Junior Farmers. That indicates the style of the person. After his retirement Senator Robertson continued his active involvement in community affairs and became President of the YMCA.
On behalf of Opposition senators I extend our sincere condolences to his wife Audrey and his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats to support the motion of condolence on the death of former Northern Territory senator, Edward Robertson. His parliamentary service has been put on record in some detail by the Government speaker and also by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. However, I wish to add a personal note.

SPEECH.PARA: I was privileged to meet Ted Robertson in 1979-some years ago now-when I worked in the Northern Territory on a youth needs survey for the Northern Territory Government. On many occasions, I had the need to call on Ted and to ask for his assistance and his interest, which were always readily available. Not only did he assist materially in the work that had to be done, but I found him to be an extremely humane person; extremely concerned about the welfare of citizens in the Northern Territory-at the best of times a fairly rough and ready society. Mr President, I will never forget his obvious deep concern for Aboriginal people, for people that were destitute and for the ordinary citizens of the Territory. I know that everyone in this place would wish to join with me in passing on our deepest condolences to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Northern Territory senator and on behalf of my colleagues in the National Party of Australia and in the Northern Territory Country-Liberal Party, I am very pleased to be associated with this condolence motion for the late Ted Robertson. I was pleased to enjoy his friendship and I know the special regard that he was afforded by my colleagues in both the Northern Territory Country- Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Ted Robertson served this Senate with five terms; that is, 12 years as a senator and as a public representative for the Northern Territory electorate. He was a good and gentle man. He had a warm and personable character. He was a very committed Christian. I would like to quote from the address given by Bishop Clyde Wood at the memorial service to Ted Robertson in Darwin at the Anglican cathedral on 8 April. He said of Ted Robertson:
He was a Christian gentleman . . . but not a saint of no earthly use.
That, indeed, was a very high accolade to Ted Robertson. He was certainly a man of very sound principles and important family standards. He had a deep respect for all human life.

Ted Robertson will be remembered with a special mark in the Northern Territory for his significant contribution in the fields of Aboriginal affairs and education. He had a sense of community service and dedication which was particularly borne out in his membership of many organisations. It has already been mentioned that he played an important role in the Young Men's Christian Association and, in fact, went on to become national president, but he also served as a representative of this Senate in the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies.

I was pleased to serve personally with him as a trustee of the Cyclone Tracy Relief Trust Fund, which was set up in Darwin following Cyclone Tracy. He was also a Reserve officer in the Royal Australian Air Force, and many young people in Darwin will remember him in that role.

Of course, his background as an educator demonstrated considerable acumen and, in particular, he played a sensitive role in developing many Aboriginal education policies which have now come to fruition. Ted Robertson also leaves a mark in Canberra both in politics and in the Australian Labor Party. He had a flair for organisation, public speaking and chairmanship; and whilst he often demonstrated, as I said earlier, warm and personable characteristics, he had a determination that survived various and very determined odds.

As a senator, I know that the constituents of the electorate that Senator Collins and I have inherited from him hold him in deep regard for the helpful and welcoming manner that he gave to our particular constituency. He never gave up trying to stop human rights violations and helping refugees and their families. In particular, he will be remembered in the Northern Territory for his contribution to many of the refugees who migrated to Australia from Timor.

As the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has mentioned, in his role here as the Labor Party Whip, he gave attention to detail that I am sure many colleagues who shared time with him in the Senate came to appreciate. In many ways, Ted Robertson was probably one of the casualties of politics because he refused to align factionally, and he held to important points of principle and not pragmatism. In fact, he showed this very positive style even at the end of his political life when his demise in politics was, to a large extent, engineered by the left and right factions of his own Labor Party in the Northern Territory to accommodate the ambitions of others coming through. Ted Robertson accepted that position even when he was downgraded on the Senate ticket.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HON. GORDON MUNRO BRYANT, E.D.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Monday, 14 January 1991, of the Honourable Gordon Bryant, member of the House of Representatives for the division of Wills from 1955 to 1980, Minister for Aboriginal Affairs from 1972 to 1973 and Minister for the Capital Territory from 1973 to 1975, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Gordon Bryant was born on 3 August 1914 at Lismore, Victoria, and educated at Frankston High School, Melbourne Teachers College and Melbourne University. Prior to entering Federal politics he was a secondary school teacher with the Victorian Education Department. He served with the Australian Army 46th Infantry Battalion and the Melbourne University Regiment, Citizen Military Forces (CMF) from 1934 to 1942. He retired from the CMF in 1961 with the rank of captain.

He was member for the seat of Wills from 1955 to 1980, and will long be remembered as a great carer of his constituency in that electorate. That was a time when the inner suburbs of Melbourne were struggling for a fair share of resources and he was very active in seeing that that happened. I noticed that at one stage the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that as a local member Gordon Bryant was a hard act to follow.

Gordon Bryant was also a member of the Council of the National Library of Australia for a total of 12 years and President of the Aborigines Advancement League in Victoria from 1957 to 1974. Honourable senators will recall that he was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs from 1972 to 1973, when he became Minister for the Capital Territory. His particular concern covering Aboriginal rights was pursued throughout his life with energy and conviction. He was very concerned as to the rights and obligations of parliamentarians and even following his retirement from Parliament in 1980 he maintained his contact with the Parliament through his work as Secretary of the Association of Former Members of the Parliament of Australia. It is fair to say that Gordon Bryant was a very energetic and active person concerned for his electorate, concerned for Aboriginals, concerned for the Australian Labor Party, and concerned for the people of his State and of this country. He was very independently minded and active in all he stood for.

As a member of the Labor Party I had a quite long association with Gordon Bryant. If there is one characteristic that I recall most about him it was his genial nature. He was a very genial, friendly man and a very outgoing person. I suppose it is unkind to say that he was also something of an irritant in terms of his diligence. After he left this Parliament he became associated with Latrobe University where he participated in seminars of academic staff. On a few occasions I was summoned as a Minister of the Government to account for the Government's failings to these groups of academics and Gordon Bryant always insisted that I attended. It was pretty tough going. He seemed to me to illustrate the gulf that exists between governments and academics.

He was extraordinarily enthusiastic. We all get youthful enthusiasms about things, but it is not left to many to retain them after they have retired. However, Gordon Bryant was one of them. I had a great personal regard for him as a warm and genial man who possessed the qualities of youthful enthusiasm. On behalf of the Government in the Senate, I tender our sympathy to his wife and two sons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Opposition senators I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in expressing our deep regret at the recent death of the Honourable Gordon Munro Bryant, E.D., at the age of 76. He was a Minister during the Whitlam Government, and probably the pinnacle of his ministerial service was his period of service as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs from 1972 to 1973. He was also Minister for the Capital Territory from 1973 to 1975.

Mr Bryant was truly what could be described as an old-style Labor man. In his maiden speech he stated that he would like to commence his parliamentary career by affirming his belief in Labor's socialist philosophy. He showed himself to be a strong advocate for the centralisation of powers and a strong advocate against the privatisation of national assets. He might be somewhat lonely if he were here today.
