SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate the Australian Democrats with this motion of condolence. In doing so I note that Gordon Bryant was one of those parliamentarians who put in extremely long service in this Parliament. He was one of few members who put in as long a period as a quarter of a century. It was a period of long and distinguished service, particularly in his capacity as a Minister during the Whitlam Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Gordon Bryant is warmly remembered for his interest in Aboriginal affairs and for his vision of a political environment in which Aboriginal people could determine the direction of their own development. That interest was not just expressed in the parliamentary sphere, as has already been noted, given that he was President of the Aborigines Advancement League in Victoria from 1957 to 1964. He was loved and admired by many in the Aboriginal community. It is in respect of that work that he is probably best known to those of us who did not have the privilege of meeting him personally.

I was interested to discover that, amongst a good deal of committee service which has already been noted, he was a member of the Joint Select Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House, a committee which was dissolved in 1970. I would have been interested to have asked someone such as Gordon Bryant, who had been on that very early committee-and there will be those in this place who would know the answer-what he thought of what finally eventuated by way of a new and permanent Parliament House. I note that that Committee had an overseas delegation in 1968 on which the Hon. Gordon Bryant travelled. It is interesting to reflect on what aspects of this building might actually be here because of the work and the interest of Gordon Bryant all that long time ago.

In looking at the maiden speech made by Gordon Bryant in this place I was quite struck by the words of a fellow former schoolteacher on the matter of state schools. He expressed enormous dissatisfaction with the standard of state schools. In that speech, he stated:
We have all seen school grounds which are dusty, gravelly wastes, and class rooms that are drab.
Although there has been a great deal of advancement and development since that speech was made in 1956, I suspect that Gordon Bryant would not have died a satisfied man yet in that area.

I think it behoves all of us to continue the work that Gordon Bryant thought so important, even from here in the Commonwealth Parliament, in the interests of our state school system. I believe that his advocacy for the state school system has not been particularly widely recognised, and I want to put on record my appreciation of that as a fellow advocate in that area.

As, indeed, the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) has noted, he was one of those old style Labor politicians. Again, as Senator Hill has mentioned, he may have had some comments about the current situation there. I feel that it would have been good to have served in a parliament with someone like Gordon Bryant. His contribution was considerable. He survived 25 years in the other place, and for that, and that alone, he deserves enormous commendation. Of course, in substance he was a contributor, as we all want to be when we come to this place. On behalf of the Democrats, I am honoured to join in supporting this condolence motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Boswell and my other colleagues in the National Party of Australia, I would like to join in this condolence motion in paying a tribute to Gordon Bryant. I was fortunate to know Gordon Bryant during the period that I was a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and, subsequently, in a number of personal capacities.

SPEECH.PARA: Gordon Bryant was obviously a man who made a great contribution to this Parliament. Anybody who serves 25 years representing one electorate must bring to the Parliament a great wealth of not only personal experience, but also experience of that particular electorate. As we know, the seat was subsequently inherited by the present Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, and I am sure that Mr Hawke would also appreciate the great work that was done by Gordon Bryant.

Other senators have already mentioned the work of Gordon Bryant as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I can remember when he was initially appointed to that portfolio. On his visits to the Northern Territory he was occasionally dubbed, both in the press and generally, as the Minister with the cheque book, because he sought to achieve significant change in the area of Aboriginal affairs from 1972 to 1973, and the only way in which change could be effected was by very prompt action.

I know that, as a Minister, Gordon Bryant was often the bane of the lives of many paternalistic public servants in the Northern Territory at that time. They could not quite come to grips with this Minister who would walk into the Northern Territory, make instant decisions and insist on the cheques being written almost on the spot to achieve significant change. I know that those changes were significant.

I know that Gordon Bryant was regarded with a great deal of affection by many Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. Like the Prime Minister of the day, Gough Whitlam, Gordon Bryant had the distinction of being very silver haired. Of course, in many Aboriginal communities it is known that as one's hair goes grey there is often a degree of flourbagging-the phrase that is put to it. I do not know whether it brings wisdom, but it certainly brings a great deal of affection in many of the Aboriginal communities. I only hope that at the end of my term in this Parliament, I can achieve some of the affection that certainly Gordon Bryant brought to many parts of my electorate.

I recall meeting Gordon Bryant in 1988 at the famous Barunga festival near the town of Katherine in the Northern Territory. He was back-as, indeed, he had come back many times-to visit Aboriginal people. He took me aside on that occasion and gave me some sound, solid advice that I will not share with the Parliament at this stage, but I can certainly say that I have heeded it, and I know that it is in the interests of Aboriginal people. He was always known, of course, as a man who was very forthright in his views and his opinions. Certainly, on behalf of the National Party, I share in the condolences to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Gordon Bryant was a great hearted character in every respect. His instincts and sentiments were in the finest traditions of the Labor movement. His great commitment, not least to the electors of Wills, his boundless energy, and his enormous good humour will be very sadly missed by his friends and former colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: His greatest achievement was, unquestionably, in retrospect, the role he played in the 1967 referendum in this country. I think it is fair to say that without his passion, his energy and his unrivalled rhetorical stamina, that referendum cause may well never have come to fruition.

I owe a particular personal debt to Gordon Bryant. It was he, when Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who plucked me from the relative obscurity then of the Melbourne University law school to work for him as a consultant on a number of aspects of Aboriginal affairs-not turtle farms, but other things.

One such matter was the beginning of formulating a response to the aspirations of the Aboriginal people for recognition of land rights. I remember tackling that issue in the particular urban Darwin context of the Kulaluk people that Senator Tambling will undoubtedly remember. They were early days. They were big and difficult issues of principle, as well as practically difficult issues, that we were grappling with, but I very much appreciated the opportunity to work with Gordon and his boundless exuberance in trying to move that along.

The other main area I was involved with him-he gave me the opportunity to work for him-was the establishment and consolidation of the network of Aboriginal legal services around Australia. I think anyone who has been following the course of Aboriginal affairs over the last generation of 20 years acknowledges the significance that the legal services have had in that particular cause. Gordon, unquestionably, made a great contribution to that, and that remains one of his numerous legacies.

From those early days with Gordon Bryant I moved on to the even headier environment of working for Lionel Murphy in Parliament on human rights issues, a path which led me steadily downhill into the Senate with the results that senators see today. I have a very personal affection for, and recollection of, Gordon for the way in which he helped me and gave me a start in public life, in many ways, in those early years.

I have to say that in later years Gordon, who lived nearby me in Melbourne-in fact, in the same electorate-favoured me with quite a number of communications drawing attention to the monumental follies of the Labor Government, in general, and me as a Minister, in particular. But the ebullience and general good humour with which these various instances of wrong headedness were delivered saved him from earning my lasting indignation, although there were occasions, I have to concede, on which it was a rather close run thing.

I am very sorry that my absence overseas prevented me from being able to attend his funeral and pay my respects to his family and, in particular, to his splendid wife Pat who really was a marvellous asset for Gordon in every respect over the years. I am glad, at least, to have the opportunity to do so now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, may I add my voice to the many good words that have been said about Gordon Bryant today. Like you, he had a background in teaching and turned it to most splendid use. Listening to Senator Gareth Evans, I am reminded of the sort of person Gordon Bryant was. He was a person who was strong in his pursuit of justice as he saw it. He strove mightily for what he thought was right and would tell people very directly what he did think, but always with a great kindness and generosity of spirit, which again has been reflected by the people who have spoken here today.

SPEECH.PARA: If we were to apply to Gordon the golden rule that we should always do unto others as we would have them do unto us, he would pass with flying colours. That came out at his funeral service, which I attended and which was attended by people from the various parts of the life that he had so fruitfully lived. There were soldiers from the Second World War, looking a little unsteady on their feet but paying their tributes to him with dignity; people who were associated with him in his career as a teacher; and, of course, people from politics-politics in Canberra and the politics that he pursued at home, for example, at the State conferences which he attended and pressed forward his views in the most wonderful fashion. The people who have spoken here today have brought out his warmth of personality. All I want to do is to endorse everything that has already been said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to add briefly my words of condolence at the passing of Gordon Bryant. I do so for two particular reasons. The first is that I did know Gordon. We shared five years in the House of Representatives from 1975 to 1980. We both left the House of Representatives at the same time in 1980 for quite different reasons: he went voluntarily, whilst I did not.
—Involuntary retirement.

—Involuntary retirement. During that period I got to know Gordon well as a fellow Victorian representative in the Parliament. The second reason is that Gordon represented the seat of Wills for 25 years. That seat basically comprised the suburbs of Brunswick and Coburg in the inner city areas of Melbourne, and for the past five years my senatorial office has been in Brunswick. During that period I have got to know many of the people who knew Gordon Bryant when he was the member for that area. It is very encouraging, and perhaps remarkable, that so long after his retirement from politics he is still so widely and warmly remembered there.

SPEECH.PARA: Gordon was a very distinguished man in many ways. His military career, which has been commented on, was a distinguished one. He served overseas during the Second World War in Borneo and Morotai. He rose to the rank of captain. He lost a lung as a result of his involvement in the Pacific campaigns, yet that never held him back from doing the things that he wanted to do in life.

Senator Button referred to Gordon as being a very genial person. That is a very good term. I would have added to that the word `amiable'. I think Gordon was a very amiable man. He was very courteous and he had a deep sense of integrity. At the same time, he was very outspoken and was very independent minded. He had a lifelong involvement with and passion for the cause of the betterment of the Aboriginal people of Australia. He was the Whitlam Government's first Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. One would have to say, looking back at that period as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, that whilst he brought a great deal of effort to that office it was probably a period which he would look back on with hindsight as one of the less satisfactory periods of his life because it was so marked with controversy and dispute.

To his everlasting credit, despite the controversy that surrounded him, for reasons that many people would say resulted from his inability to take decisions as decisively as one needs to in ministerial life, he fought for his cause in Aboriginal affairs, particularly after he lost the Ministry of Aboriginal Affairs and his role was subjected to very careful scrutiny by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I remember that because I was a member of the Public Accounts Committee at the time. The dealings that the Committee had with Gordon Bryant in sorting through just what had happened in that very turbulent period were marked by a great deal of honesty and frankness on his part. At the end of it I think he came through as an enhanced person.

His parliamentary career as a whole was chequered. It is not generally known that in 1967 he was almost a contender for the leadership of the parliamentary Labor Party on the retirement of Arthur Calwell. That was at the time when Gough Whitlam was seeking to succeed Arthur Calwell. As I understand it, Gordon Bryant was a contender for the leadership but to avoid fragmentation in the Party he withdrew from the ballot before it occurred. That was when Gough Whitlam became leader of the Party.

In 1974 it was strongly rumoured that Gordon Bryant would lose his position in the Ministry. By that stage he had become the Minister for the Capital Territory. He survived that, but the greatest survival he ever achieved was when he survived the enormous pressure that was put on him in 1976 to give up the seat of Wills and to retire before he wished to do so. He resisted that pressure, and that was a very good indication of the strength of his character. He resisted that pressure, as he said at the time, for a variety of reasons. He said:
In December 1975 Wills was the only seat where Labor voters, in significant numbers, did not desert the Labor Party. I have no intention of deserting them.

Gordon left the Parliament of his own accord in 1980. He left many friends. He left people who have remembered him with great affection since then. He was very active in his retirement. As Senator Evans said in his remarks, Gordon caused Ministers, not just of the present Government but of the Fraser years until 1983, a fair amount of curry by stirring them on issues that were of interest to him.

We have lost a very good friend, a person who was an admirable parliamentarian in every sense of the word. I join with other members of the Senate in expressing to his widow and his sons and their families, including his grandchildren, my deepest sympathy at his passing.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme: Erythropoietin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Chronic renal failure patients must already endure exhaustive dialysis to just survive. Anaemia, or lack of oxygen-carrying red blood cells that leaves one weak and lethargic, is another symptom some renal patients must also endure. The inability of the kidneys to produce a hormone known as erythropoietin makes transfusions the only viable option for these patients and the transfusion destroys all chances of a transplant due to the increased levels of antibodies.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Government to make available through an Authority Listing with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme the recombinant human erythropoietin to those chronic renal failure patients suffering from anaemia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

In particular, we are concerned about the impact on the affordability of telephone services for low income earners and rural consumers.
The Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) protect ordinary consumers from increasing prices and decreasing service and to ensure that the telephone remains an affordable utility
(b) clearly define community service obligations of all telecommunications providers

(c) ensure that, regardless of the structural arrangements, a strong and viable government telecommunications carrier is maintained and continues to provide a universal, affordable service to all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Non-Custodial Access to Children
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will consider the plight of the father in the Family Court.

Fathers, according to the Laws of Australia, should have equal rights to their children, in both custody and access applications before the Family Court. Immediate amendments to the Family Law Act should be implemented for inclusion of parental rights as distinct from children's rights. It should be made possible for fathers to obtain a fair deal in the Family Court and be able to continue involvement in their siblings upbringing at all times throughout every stage of their children's development, thus being in the best interest of the children themselves, without incurring exorbitant legal costs and manipulated by many of the legal profession. Access Orders from the Family Court should be implemented without delay and at no cost to the non-custodial parent, thus eliminating denial of access. We humbly urge Parliament to direct the Family Court by way of immediate legislation to jealously guard visitation rights and become more liberal with them.

We further do humbly seek that a private members bill be introduced on an urgent basis to consider the plight of Mr. John Zabaneh, a fellow citizen and father of four young children whom he had no access to for nearly five years despite that he had obtained unenforceable orders from the courts. John Zabaneh has been denied any input in his children's development and upbringing and has little or no knowledge of his children's progress and wellbeing.
As this matter is of human-rights nature, of paramount importance, it is specially requested that this petition be read to Parliament assembled in full.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Their Opposition to the despatch of three Australian warships to the Middle East, which is part of an unnecessary militarisation of the region, and which contributed to the likelihood of all-out war. Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The Australian warships in the Middle East be withdrawn immediately.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 February, the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) gave a speech to the National Press Club on Australia and the Gulf war. In the course of his speech he observed:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be international and domestic lessons to be learnt from this conflict.
He then went on to state:
A major lesson for the future relates to the need to control and reduce the international arms trade.

I commend the Minister for his statement and would heartily endorse such a suggestion. Indeed, I have made such a call for several years since I took my place in the Senate in 1985. However, there is a clear contradiction between the Minister's observation and Australia's own record. In particular, I refer to the intention to host Australia's international defence equipment exhibition, AIDEX 91, in November this year, and the attempt to double our military exports following the recommendations of the 1986 Cooksey report and the new guidelines introduced in 1988.

I do not intend to dwell at any length on the role of the global arms trade in leading to the carnage in the Middle East at the moment, because the media have at last discovered how the world armed Saddam Hussein. There have been first-class feature articles in the Australian, the Sydney Morning Herald, the West Australian and other papers indicating the enormous international effort that went into making Saddam Hussein's regime in Iraq the military threat that it is at the moment. Some 26 countries armed Iran and Iraq during the last decade and another four countries armed Iraq only.

Australia was not one of the countries which sold arms during the war, but we were happy to resume arms sales there after the ceasefire. The proposed sale of spare parts for Iraqi Air Force trainer aircraft by Hawker de Havilland was justified by the Minister, despite the record of Saddam Hussein's regime on human rights which we have heard so much about since 2 August last year-but, of course, we did not hear too much about it in the preceding decade. Ironically, the main culprits who sold arms to Iraq are now all supporting military intervention in the Gulf and, indeed, are facing weapons they in effect provided themselves. That includes, unfortunately, the two Australian ships which are, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) said on television last night, literally in the front line and within range of the Exocet missiles supplied to Iraq by France by the company Aerospatiale, which was one of the exhibitors at the 1989 AIDEX here in Canberra.

The bulk of military hardware was provided by the Soviet Union, France and China, but the United States provided $1.5 billion worth of dual use technology as well as trade credits, and much of the money for arms sales was put up by Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. The justification was, of course, that the world tacitly supported Iraq's invasion of Iran in 1980 because we feared the Islamic fundamentalist regime in Tehran even more than the regime in Baghdad. At the economic level, there was the lure of recycled petrodollars from one of the world's largest arms producers.

Third World arms dealers simply following the quest for dollars included Argentina, Chile, Brazil, Egypt, the Philippines, Ethiopia, North and South Korea, as well as South Africa. Their arguments to justify arms sales sound remarkably like the arguments used by our own Minister for Defence to justify Australia's arms sales, although I will accept his assertion that we do have some controls while most of these other countries have virtually none at all. Ironically, Brazil's arms industry is almost bankrupt as a result of the current arms embargo on Iraq.

Another irony is that the greatest threat to Australian ships in the Gulf comes, as I said, from the Exocet missiles sold by the French company Aerospatiale. This company occupied stand 105 in hall B at the AIDEX 89 arms bazaar in Canberra and actually advertised the various brands of Exocet missiles in the exhibition catalogue. The organisers of AIDEX 89 asserted that their exhibition was probably the most sophisticated display of defence high-tech equipment and services ever seen in the Southern Hemisphere.

In July 1989, a publicity brochure claimed that the overall success of AIDEX 89 would be judged by the number of exhibitors and the meaningful business they did. The Federal Government obviously shared this enthusiasm because it provided the Department of Defence with $59,000 to participate in AIDEX 89. I wonder how much the Department of Defence will be providing for AIDEX 91. Indirectly, other funds probably assisted organisations like Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd and the Defence Science and Technology Organisation in that 1989 exhibition. The organiser of AIDEX 91, the Sydney based trade fair company Desiko Pty Ltd, has asserted in its latest exhibition update:

The international success of the inaugural AIDEX in 1989 will mean not only a bigger show in 1991, but also a new and greater range of defence high technology industry exhibitors and their products and services.

It is putting out its glossy brochures with lots of nice pictures of the last one here in 1989 and there is a beautiful big picture of the Minister for Defence in the brochure. So obviously it is well supported by the Australian Government. The organiser and manager of AIDEX, Bob Day, went on to say:
What is of most significance is that these bigger national delegations will include many companies and organisations which have not previously exhibited in Australia.

So we are constantly expanding the range of our weapons exports in this method. I, for one, do not doubt this because the end of the Cold War in Europe has meant that many companies producing military equipment have been looking to other parts of the world to promote their sales.

The Minister for Defence warned early on in his portfolio in May last year that detente in Europe could lead to more trade in sophisticated weapons at bargain basement prices in Asia and the Pacific, and he is right. One of the companies which has already booked space at AIDEX 91 is Rockwell International, one of the United States (US) Department of Defense top 100 military contractors. This company was largely responsible for the B1 bomber and running the contaminated United States nuclear weapons plutonium production facility at Rocky Flats in Colorado-now totally discredited but, of course, leaving the taxpayers with a huge clean-up bill.

According to the strategic management and international vice-president for Rockwell's electronic operations, Mr E.S. Washington, Australia is the springboard for Rockwell International's maritime penetration of the Asia-Pacific region. There are many Australians who are not too excited about that. He went on to say that he views the region as the predominant marketing area in the next five to 10 years. Another Rockwell vice-president, George T. Jones, said:

We are transferring technology from the USA into Australia, bolstering its technology and capability. In turn, Rockwell is using Ship Subsystems Australia as a means of obtaining new maritime revenue for its ventures into the Asia-Pacific region.

According to the latest figures put out by the US Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, the Middle East still takes the largest chunk of military exports, but the proportion has dropped significantly since the end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988. This figure will now increase as a result of the current war if the United States goes ahead with providing Saudi Arabia with $22 billion worth of military equipment and then further sales to Israel.

There are also attempts to give Egypt a large number of US army tanks that would otherwise be scrapped following conventional arms reduction agreements in Europe. Doubtless, the Soviets will also try to boost their flagging economy by selling off some of their old weapons as well. The new growth area for military sales, according to the US Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, are South East Asia and eastern Asia. In 1977, that area took 6 per cent of the world's arms sales but, by 1987, this figure had increased to 23 per cent, principally as a result of increased military equipment acquisitions by India and Pakistan.

Curiously, Australian companies were quickly into this new market. An Australian company, Redecon Australia Pty Ltd, in a joint consortium with the Dutch company Nedeco was awarded a contract in March 1989 to provide engineering consultative services for the development and design of the breakwater complex and for the master planning of the shoreside facilities of the Indian Navy's new major naval base complex 80 kilometres south of Goa.

Next, we learned that the Royal Australian Air Force was going to sell off 50 of its old Mirages. I commend those senators in the Liberal Party of Australia who spent much of last year harrying the Minister for Defence over the sale of these planes to Pakistan along with all the other bits and pieces. I do not propose to go into the details as they have been well documented, but I do note that the sale went ahead even as India and Pakistan were threatening to resume hostilities over Kashmir and, indeed, they might well again go to war over that area, which has been a disputed territory for more than 40 years.

At this point, I would like to consider the Minister's rationale for promoting the export of military equipment by Australia. His justifications seem to fall into three categories: firstly, that to pay for military imports you have to export; secondly, that it brings down the cost of domestic production; and, thirdly, that we have strict controls and we do not export much lethal equipment but rather primarily defensive equipment.

The first line is an interesting one because everyone else uses it, too. We hear a lot about offset agreements but they are all the rage in South East Asia which is an area in which we are in hot competition. South Korea, for example, has become a major arms exporter and is even now assembling sophisticated United States aircraft involving substantial offset agreements. Iraq did the same in the 1980s to build up a huge military industrial complex in the Tigris valley, much of it through utilising dual use technology, dummy end-user certificates and front companies like Matrix-Churchill, registered in Coventry, England.
When Mr Hayden was Minister for Foreign Affairs, he made an excellent speech at the United Nations special session on disarmament in June 1988. In it he said:
It is also clear that arms exports should not be turned to as a way of solving domestic economic problems. Arms transfers must not become a new cash crop.

I have repeatedly asked Ministers for Defence since then how they reconcile current policy with Mr Hayden's statement. They have consistently refused to answer or to deal with the question. Likewise, I have asked how they reconcile the statement by the head of the World Bank, Barber Conable, with our policy on doubling military exports. Barber Conable said in September 1989:
Developing countries on one side, and suppliers and creditors on the other, must adapt to a world where budgets are tight.

It is important to place military spending decisions on the same footing as other fiscal decisions, to examine possible trade-offs more systematically and to explore better ways to bring military spending into better balance with development of priorities.
In evaluating their military expenditure, governments should be realistic, but they also should remember the human consequences of these choices.

This Government is very realistic but until now it has never considered the human consequences of these choices. We simply get a lecture on the economics of military purchases, which brings us to the heart of the matter. As countries buy more sophisticated military hardware they are faced with a heavy bill. Submarines, aircraft carriers, sophisticated fighter planes, frigates and so on, cost billions of dollars. The FA18s cost this country around $5 billion although they were originally costed at around $2.43 billion in 1981.

The six new submarines are currently estimated to be costing us about $5.5 billion, depending whose figures are checked, but that sum will doubtless have substantially increased by the time they are all built. The Anzac class frigates come in a similar expensive category at $3.5 billion at current prices. The Minister for Defence has asked me in the past how we can pay for all this unless we try to offset such costs by exporting. I have spoken on a number of occasions about the need for this country to stop buying such unnecessary equipment, so that is one way of dealing with that question.

We do not need FA18s, submarines, Anzac class frigates or spy bases like the one constructed near Geraldton for an unknown cost, as the Minister refuses to name the price tag. What we do need, like patrol boats and coastal patrol aircraft, we can build here. Many of these arguments apply to the second line of defence employed by the Minister. While I agree with his assertion that Australia is not as bad as some other countries, it is very hard to draw the line. We have seen this over the use that Iraq made of dual use technology supplied by the United States. Where in all this is the line between lethal and non-lethal equipment? Most military equipment is actually non-lethal but the military machine needs it just as much as the hardware that kills. The Minister did not think that the spare parts for the Iraqi trainer aircraft constituted lethal equipment but, with a man like Saddam Hussein, it is quite likely that trainer aircraft would be used to drop gas on his own people or foreign forces if it was deemed a military necessity.

In answer to a question I asked the Minister on 22 August last year, Senator Robert Ray said that the Mirages sold to Pakistan were not of major military significance, in which case I suppose the old Pakistani planes sold to Bangladesh were of even less military significance. Planes like these may not be of much use against a high-tech air force like the United States air force, but they are pretty devastating if used to bomb defenceless civilians, and I would assert that the Minister's distinction is really quite meaningless, if not hypocritical. Of course we are not as bad as Brazil, Chile, France, the Soviet Union, China or South Africa when it comes to arms sales, but that is no justification for slipping in behind them to catch a few more crumbs from the table.

The people at the receiving end in any of the 30-odd wars being waged today are not going to be too worried about which countries supplied the weapons. As analysts have sometimes observed, there is no difference between a capitalist bomb and a communist bomb and a non-aligned bomb at the point of impact. The only people laughing will be the merchants of death who were in a very worried state a year or so ago following detente in Europe and the winding down of a number of other nasty wars around the globe, especially the Iran-Iraq war. Of course, another war has conveniently, from their point of view, emerged so they can make lots of money. Australia did have tighter guidelines before 1988, although the present Minister may deny this.

It is interesting that the Opposition shares my concern about morale in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade because one of the reasons for loss of morale is the way in which the Department of Defence has taken an upper hand, particularly over the issue of military exports. This relates particularly to the 21-day fast tracking of licences to be granted, and the fact that issues are looked at in isolation-the foreign affairs side of the equation seems to have been missed out. I know that that has been a constant point of tension between the two departments. Obviously, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade lost out and the Department of Defence won that battle, so it has the major control.

I doubt whether the Mirage sale would have gone through before 1988, or the proposed sale of aircraft spare parts to Iraq, as officials in the Department of Foreign Affairs know full well what the situation is like between India and Pakistan over Kashmir. They are also aware of Iraq's human rights record under Saddam Hussein and indeed his predecessors since the coup against the monarchy in 1958.

Essentially, then, what I am asking for is that we take up the Minister's proposal for greater control by suggesting that Australia, as a small exporter, follow up the lead taken by Czechoslovakia under the leadership of Vaclav Havel. Czechoslovakia was a leading arms exporter but after the change of government there President Havel announced that his country was getting out of the business.

I am concerned about loss of jobs, of course, and the economic situation in Australia and I urge research into proposals for economic conversion. It would be desirable for Australia to trade its way out of economic recession and to reduce the balance of payments deficit, but not by trading in weapons. Socially useful export areas for Australia to promote could include: energy efficiency technology, like LPG conversions which we could perfect and export; alternative energy technology-for example, small scale water pumps which are in urgent need in developing countries; public transport systems, which are urgently needed; and research and development into rain forest products other than timber-for example, medicines. Let us become the clever country that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talks about by redeploying research and development funding away from military equipment to such areas as I have suggested which are urgently needed by the global community, a claim which can hardly be made by traders in death machinery.

Now we have belatedly learned, I hope, the lessons of the 1973 energy crisis which was also the result of a war in the Middle East. I mention the above options because although we may be about 85 per cent self-sufficient in oil, Australia is the world's fifth highest consumer of fossil fuels and the per capita use of petrol in our cities is more than double that of European cities. Another initiative for Australia to pursue would be the setting up of an international register of global arms transfers. This proposal has already come up before the United Nations over the last couple of years, particularly at the special session on disarmament. In Australia, we need to make public our record, which at present the Minister refuses to do allegedly for reasons of commercial secrecy and because it would be too time-consuming.

It is interesting to note that in the United States the Department of Commerce is having trouble tracing the export licences granted to United States companies which sold technology to Iraq during the last decade. So are the Germans who provided much of the wherewithal for Iraq's nuclear and chemical weapons capability. It is an argument that no longer holds water. This information must always be made public. There are already agreements to limit the spread of particularly dangerous and sophisticated weapons, like the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and the United States-Soviet agreement to limit the spread of ballistic missiles. We need more such agreements.

Countries like Australia and Czechoslovakia can actually take a lead, as small countries did with the international slave trade at the end of the eighteenth century, in cutting the international arms transfers. The Minister for Defence, in answer to a question I asked last year in Estimates, said that we sold only $238m worth of military equipment, which is less than the base line of $250m referred to by Robert Cooksey in his 1986 report. I note, too, that the Minister believes that this figure will increase in the current year, as he has referred to a figure of $300m. Obviously we are investing a lot of money in military technology but there are some doubts about how successful we will be and now, in the wake of the Gulf war, there are new considerations.

As a result of the Gulf war, the world is becoming increasingly aware of the dangers of encouraging the global arms trade. People are sickened by the consequences of the trade in weapons of death, although the coverage of the Gulf war has so far been severely sanitised. This is presumably to avoid the mistakes made during the Vietnam war. I commend the Minister for accepting that we will have to do something about further controls and reducing the international arms trade. I am glad to note that he is currently considering constructive measures by Australia to respond to this concern, as he stated in answer to Senator Coates's question earlier today. I am sure there will be considerable lobbying on the question of the arms trade in the months ahead. I hope that the Minister will act now in the two areas that I have outlined in the urgency motion this afternoon by following the example of the Governor-General, Mr Hayden, in 1986, when he was the Minister for Foreign Affairs and he cancelled PADEX 1986 in the International Year of Peace and also formally abandoned the goal of doubling Australia's military exports.
Accordingly, I move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

Considering the statement of the Minister for Defence, in light of the Gulf War, that `a major lesson for the future relates to the need to control and reduce the international arms trade', the necessity for the Government to cancel Australia's International Defence Equipment Exhibition (AIDEX `91) scheduled to be held in Canberra in November this year, and to abolish its goal of doubling military exports from $250 million to $500 million a year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —For once we are debating an urgency motion that does have some urgency and relevance. Often that is not the case in this chamber. I was one of those who raised this as an issue over the last few weeks. One thing which is patently clear to anyone who looks at the current conflict in the Gulf is that Iraq is now a warfare state. It is probably the only country in the world where one could make the accusation, if you like, that it is a total warfare state.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not much point in thinking of past ideologies or past practices when we analyse how this came about. Quite clearly, it came about by that country devoting an inordinate amount of its resources to defence equipment of an offensive nature. Iraq is a country with 17 million people. It has a gross domestic product far smaller than Australia's, yet it has managed to purchase more than $50 billion worth of capital equipment over the last few years. Part of it was disguised to the rest of the world, I would suggest, by its paranoia about Iran and, therefore, ignored. When we look at that equipment, we see that a lot of it came from the Soviet Union-the MIG fighters, the surface to air missile (SAM) sites, the Scud missiles and the tanks-but not all of it came from just one client.

Many arms merchants beat their way to Baghdad and elsewhere in Iraq to flog off equipment. Some of that was condoned and supported by government action; to some of it governments turned a blind eye and, especially in areas such as chemical warfare and the development of nuclear facilities, some governments clearly did not know the extent of the Iraqi technology.

We have seen countries involved in conflict with Iraq being met by some of their own equipment. There are many examples of that. We can talk about the Exocet missile and we can talk about trying to get rid of planes out of bunkers built by the British. It would be a very foolish government of any country of the world that did not recognise that it helped create some of these problems. It does not mean that we automatically draw all the conclusions that Senator Vallentine has today. I do not concede all those; some I do, some I do not.

One must draw the conclusion that post-conflict, the world has to learn. I put to this chamber that there has been a learning pattern in the world. The world has taken action to try to limit chemical warfare and many countries have taken action to try to limit biological warfare, nuclear warfare and, more recently, missile technology.

On those four fronts, many countries have been active, a lot of agreements have been reached and a lot of progress has been made. We cannot argue that with conventional weapons. Many weapons have been sold willy-nilly to whoever was willing to put up his hand and put up the amount of money necessary to buy them.

Let us look at Australia's record on this matter. I have said that I think we are reasonably well placed, post-Gulf, to be able to push for limitation of trade in conventional arms. I do not say that it is elimination, and I will come to that point later. Let us consider Australia's track record in regard to selling arms. Over the last few years most people in this chamber have come up with one or two examples. That is all they can come up with. One never eventuated and another has been a matter of controversy in this chamber since I first took over the portfolio. They cannot point to any others. Over the last decade we have hardly sold anything to the Middle East region, and certainly nothing significant. Our exports tend to concentrate on areas such as New Zealand, which buys the Steyr rifles from us, the United States, Great Britain or elsewhere. We do not have a history of exporting arms into regions which would increase the existing instability or make war more likely. We do not have a history of exporting weapons that can be used in countries that have gross human rights abuses.

Some care has been taken to filter through all applications for arms sales in this country. People refer to 1988 as the watershed. It was not so much that the guidelines were tightened; the procedures were changed in terms of response time. Other people have made reference to the fact that the formal committee does not meet every week. Like a sensible committee, it has various categories that it can deal with over the phone and decide one way or another, although any rejection ultimately comes to me for a decision. I believe that Australia has not sought to get into that sort of niche market of exporting lethal weapons that would increase the likelihood of conflict in this world. There is still a place for arms procurement and for countries to defend themselves.

Senator Vallentine comes in here today and criticises this Government's decision on frigates and submarines, as well as the previous Government's decision-an excellent one, I might add-on Hornets and F18s. That is her world view, and that is the sort of view that she can argue as much as she likes. I have a different world view. I believe that by spending a mere 2.3 per cent of our gross domestic product on defence we are laying the preconditions for a potential defence of this country. I do not identify any potential enemies at this stage, but we need a certain level of capability, otherwise we cannot respond. I remind the Senate that many people argued for unilateral disarmament in the 1930s, some in my own Party argued very strongly for it. That proved catastrophic to this country. It meant that we were left with a very low military base, and once threatened-we did have realistic threats-we found it very difficult to respond.

I have no problem at all in justifying Australia's current military expenditures. In eight years we have gone from a position of spending 80 per cent of our capital equipment budget overseas to spending 80 per cent within this country. I think that is a great achievement. When it comes to the export of arms, there are several reasons why a government may be inclined to encourage it, provided-and I have to make this proviso-there are proper controls and these arms do not go into regions that would use them for human rights abuses or aggression upon a neighbour. There are economies of scale to be achieved. I am not bringing forward the argument of jobs here today, but I wonder how many taxpayers want to pay more for defence equipment simply because we try to produce everything ourselves.

Turning to the question of where we go in the future, I have made it very clear, and I have had discussions with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), that we stand ready to look at the current guidelines and the current procedures in view of events that have occurred around the world. If necessary, we will change them. If we are open to criticism for not doing what we can to produce peace throughout the world, we will not hesitate to change them. On the other hand, we will not just panic and say that we will not sell any arms overseas simply because people point to the worst example of that, and that is not analogous to this country.

The Government will not support the motion moved by Senator Vallentine today. It is based on one false premise to begin with; that is, it is not within our capacities to cancel the Australian International Defence Export Exhibition-AIDEX 91. That is a privately run arms exhibition, most of which, incidentally, would be directed towards future purchases by Australia of items which are probably, but not exclusively, already in the pink book. So it is not a Government-run exhibition. I notice that Senator Vallentine really did stress this point. She said that in 1986 Mr Hayden cancelled AIDEX or the Pacific Area Defence Equipment Exhibition (PADEX) 86. On 13 February 1986 in the House of Representatives, Mr Hayden stated:

The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) accused me of closing down the PADEX armaments exhibition which was to be held in Australia. Nothing could be further from the truth. The Government took no such action at all. Private organisations which wish to conduct such exhibitions are entitled to do so.
The claim made by Senator Vallentine today that PADEX 86 was cancelled by Mr Hayden--

TALK.START.PARA: —She is never good where the truth or accuracy is concerned.

—All I am saying is that on this occasion it is not true that Mr Hayden cancelled it. He did not; he is on the public record in the House of Representatives as responding to that. It may well be, however, that actions by the Government that year-I think 1986 was the year of disarmament-could have contributed towards that decision, but it was not a case of a Government order. The exhibition to be held in 1991 has very little Government involvement. I said at Question Time today-Senator Vallentine was probably writing out her speech to read it here today-that I would look at that area of the two areas we are involved in. I am not making a prejudgment on it; I will look at it objectively to see whether it is a justifiable thing for us to be involved in and whether it would be consistent with our current tight guidelines for us continue in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the motion really misses the point I have been trying to make: it does not matter whether one is selling $250m-worth or $500m-worth of defence equipment. The whole point is who one sells it to and what the equipment is. The dollars that are put in here are absolutely irrelevant as far as I am concerned. It may be more justifiable to export $500m of product to New Zealand and a couple of other close allies than to export $100m into the wrong region of the world. Therefore, I regard the way this motion is framed as a bit of nonsense. I think it would have been better in the more general area.

The question of exports of defence equipment will be closely looked at by this Government, by me and by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The rather pathetic assertion that has been made in here today-that poor old Foreign Affairs has been rolled over by Defence-is just arrant nonsense. If necessary, that will occur, but it has not occurred historically. That department has been fully involved in the decision-making on all these applications and in the eventual grant for an export licence. It has been fully involved and there is good cooperation between the two departments and the other departments involved in this, including the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It is not a case of big bully boy Defence rolling over the noble Foreign Affairs Department. I am sorry, but that is just a rewriting and a creative bit of writing not reflected in fact.

If one looks at the history of Australia in this particular area, as I said, we do not come with completely clean hands, but, by gee, how do we compare with other countries? Their attitude has been, `Export or perish. What do you want-another 20 Exocets? Here we are; take them. Don't worry if they come back and take out one of your frigates six weeks later'. We have never had that attitude. I am talking about this Government. As far as I can look back at the historical record, the coalition Government never had that sort of record; it was also fairly stringent in its control of defence exports. I notice the coalition is going to look at the issue and I presume that it will come up with a similar policy as that followed in its previous practice.

The Government will not support this motion. It is based on a false premise. AIDEX 91 is a private concern; it is not within the power of the Government to cancel it. The reference to the doubling of military exports completely misses the point. The point and the danger with exports is when they are of a particularly lethal type going to a region of instability that will in fact create conflict. There is still a valid case for Australia to export to countries simply seeking defence self-reliance, where many countries, including New Zealand, rely on that assistance. It may well be-and Senator Vallentine may have referred to this-that government-to-government agreement to produce a particular item is a much better way of going than a private company going to another overseas company or government. I am quite willing to look at that sort of thing.

I have not picked up all the points made by Senator Vallentine, but her final point was in respect of the United Nations and that there should be a list. That is not really a matter for me; it is more a matter for the Foreign Minister, and I will draw it to his attention. That may well be one of the ways the world should go.

In conclusion, I repeat that this is not the only lesson to be learnt from the Gulf but it is one of current debate. There will be many others and we will come back to those at another time. One must learn from what has happened. There is no use in putting one's head in the sand and saying, `Iraq was not financed by Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and others; Iraq was not given defence equipment of a very offensive nature; Iraq did not have very sophisticated technology transferred by western European countries'. All that occurred and we cannot ignore that. We must learn the lesson of it. It does not mean that every other proposition about defence put by Senator Vallentine, the Australian Democrats or anyone else in the past 10 years is also automatically true. There are other lessons to be learnt from this conflict. One is that appeasement never works; another is that one must be consistent. I am sure that people are asking that I be consistent in terms of exports; I equally ask the Senator Vallentines of this world next time Kuwait is invaded to get outside the Iraqi Embassy--

TALK.START.PARA: —I was there yesterday, as a matter of fact.

—Only after Howard Sattler put the blowtorch to the honourable senator! Only after people asked, `Why are you never seen outside those sorts of places?'. It took us three years of putting the blowtorch to Senator Vallentine here to get her outside the Soviet Embassy. Senator Vallentine also has to be consistent on these matters. We will suffer some slight humiliation in admitting that maybe some of our past export practice has been wrong, but everyone has to learn lessons from the Gulf-not just the governments but also the critics. As many times as the Government may have been wrong, the critics have been equally as often wrong. Everyone wants to learn the lessons of this Gulf conflict to make sure we can help prevent a likely repeat in the future. I cannot say I am positively confident that all the lessons will be learnt. I am a little more confident of the new world order-that it is more likely now than it was in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine has brought forward as a matter of urgency the question of the export of defence materiel or arms exports-however one likes to call it-by Australia. Before I actually saw the details of her urgency motion, I heard that Senator Vallentine was bringing forward such a motion today and assumed it would be in somewhat general terms, calling upon this Parliament to oppose the export of defence materiel. In fact, that is the line which she used when she spoke to her motion today. I think this debate would proceed along more sensible lines if that were the subject we were debating here today.

SPEECH.PARA: However, before I move into that area, I want to refer to the actual terms of Senator Vallentine's motion, which is of a much more limited character than that, because she is simply calling upon the Government to cancel Australia's AIDEX-that is, the International Defence Equipment Exhibition scheduled for later this year-and for the Government to abolish its goal of doubling military exports, as she calls them, from roughly $250m to $500m a year. However, lest anyone misunderstand the matter, and Senator Vallentine apparently hoped that she would entice some support for a more limited proposal to the Senate than the one which is really dear to her heart and the one to which she really spoke in her argument in support of her motion, I wish to say that the Opposition is opposed to the proposal, even in the more limited terms of this motion.

The Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, who has just spoken, has given satisfactory reasons as far as we are concerned in relation to both these matters. Clearly, it is not a matter for the Government anyway to cancel an exhibition, but it would in our view be foolish for the Government to try to lean on this body to stop this exhibition taking place. Obviously, if we are permitting trade to occur in this materiel, suitable exhibitions from time to time are part and parcel of that. Although some people-rightly or wrongly-may believe that it was unsuitable to have such an exhibition in the International Year of Peace, 1986, there seems to be no particular reason why the exhibition should be stopped this year. In any event, it is not for the Opposition to determine whether to stop it. The Government has said it will look at it, but in our view it is an appropriate event to occur in the light of Australian Government policy.

I cannot understand Senator Vallentine complaining only about the Government's goal of doubling exports. When all is said and done, if she is concerned about the doubling of exports-they are already worth $250m-I would have thought a figure such as that would have really horrified her. This is only a smokescreen. The reality of Senator Vallentine's proposition is that there should not be any exports of this type at all. There are some very sensible reasons, which I will come to in a minute, why the Government should, in fact, be encouraging the Australian defence industry. If we are going to do that, obviously it is important for that industry to be able to increase its production and sales-as it is for any other industry which is going to be viable. It is going to want some goal: that is all part and parcel of this or any other industry. It seems to me that quite an irrelevant consideration has been introduced into this debate.

Let me turn to the real substance of today's debate-that is, Senator Vallentine's strong opposition to a defence industry at all or to defence exports. I notice that Senator Vallentine has been able to bring forward this matter of urgency today only because she is being supported by the Australian Democrats. We will hear from Senator Powell shortly. Clearly, the Democrats are of the same view as Senator Vallentine in relation to this matter. The Opposition's view is entirely different from the one which has been expounded by Senator Vallentine and, I imagine, the one which will be expounded by the Democrat speakers in this debate.

The Opposition is as concerned as Senator Vallentine, the Democrats and the Government about the extent of the arms build-up around the world and the uninhibited trading in lethal weapons that has occurred in recent years, particularly the arsenal now held by Iraq. No doubt the world has learnt a lesson from the experience with Iraq. Clearly, the Opposition supports the Government in its efforts, and the efforts of our allies around the world, through the United Nations, to endeavour to achieve arms control-whether they be nuclear, chemical, biological or conventional.

It is ironical that Senator Vallentine and the Democrats have spent so much of their time in recent years expressing their strong opposition to, and deep feelings about, nuclear weapons and nuclear threats. In fact, it has turned out that modern conventional weapons may be almost as great-if not as great-a threat as the threat from nuclear weapons. The world will have to give at least the same attention to getting agreements on control of conventional weapons as it has to nuclear weapons. That sort of agreement is one which has already had some notable achievements, certainly in western Europe as a result of the ending of the Cold War. Last year some very notable steps were taken to seek to vastly reduce the level of conventional weapons in that part of the world. I am hopeful that the time is ripe for international agreements of that kind.

I would think that one of the great lessons to be learnt from the Cold War is the fact that purely unilateral disarmament by countries will not work. Had the Western world taken note of Senator Vallentine's view, or the Democrats' view, and unilaterally disarmed its nuclear weaponry, I do not believe for one moment that the Cold War would have ended as it did in 1990. It was simply the Western powers, and particularly the United States, meeting the threat of nuclear war-which was evident in the policies of the Soviet Union-with greater and better weaponry and a greater capacity to produce and maintain it that the Cold War was ultimately ended. Forgetting Iraq for a moment, since the end of the Cold War we have seen the opportunities for peace in the world because the threat of nuclear holocaust by Soviet aggression was met and seen off by the resolute stance of the Western allies.

We also believe that we need an adequate defence force. There will be a lot of debate between ourselves and the Government about the extent of that. But that is not today's issue. Today's issue is the more fundamental one as to whether we will maintain an adequate defence force in this community and, indeed, whether we will support our friends and allies around the world who want to maintain, for defensive purposes, adequate military forces. These two issues are bound up, of course, with the need to produce and to trade in defence materiel.

That is what this debate is all about. Do we believe in having adequate defence for our own security? Do we believe in assisting our allies who themselves are only interested in defence, not aggression? That is the basis on which we pursue a defence policy. That is why we believe in the need for Australia to be able to get a reasonable degree of self-sufficiency in the production of defence materiel. The Opposition has applauded the policy of the Government in expanding Australia's defence industry-or attempting to do so. In order to maintain that industry and to help it to grow, it needs to be able to have a greater market than the Australian Government can provide.

Recently I had the opportunity of seeing some major new Australian industrial developments-the frigate project and the submarine project. Both of those big projects have limited lives as far as industry is concerned. Industry has to look beyond its current contracts which they have-large and small as Senator Vallentine has pointed them out to be.

If we are going to get industry to do this job in Australia it has to have long term security. It is not just a matter of Australia exporting arms to pay for imports of such materiel. It is a matter of building up and having within Australia adequate defence industry and capacity to service Australia's defence requirements.

That is why we believe that fundamentally the Government is correct. We support it in that policy. We believe that the export of that defence materiel must be subject to strict controls. As Senator Vallentine has said, in some respects we are critical of the Government's administration of these guidelines. We are conducting our own review of the guidelines and the way that they are operating. Obviously there are failures in the Government's administration of the guidelines.

Senator Robert Ray always tries to obscure the decision to sell aircraft parts to Iran by saying that the sale did not go ahead, but this decision was made by the Government under the guidelines. So the administration of those guidelines must be flawed if something like that can happen.

It is not my purpose to debate the adequacy or otherwise of those guidelines. We, as an opposition, are saying that we would maintain a policy of building up an export industry in this materiel. We think it is vital for Australia's own defence that we do so. We believe that there should be trade exports to countries that are friendly and democratic allies who would purchase these exports for their own legitimate defence purposes and who would not in any way undermine Aus- tralia's strategic defence interests.

These are some of the fundamental issues presented by Senator Vallentine's motion. Much deeper considerations are involved in this than the superficial matters that Senator Vallentine has referred to. Her speech in support of her motion clearly indicates that her views are fundamentally different from those of the Opposition. We will oppose the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats wholeheartedly support the urgency motion moved by Senator Vallentine calling for cancellation of the Australian International Defence Exhibition-AIDEX 91-and abandonment by the Government of its goal of doubling arms exports from this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We had hoped that the Opposition would support this motion as well as the Democrats' proposal for a Senate inquiry into Australia's military exports policy. If the Opposition fails to support the proposal for a Senate inquiry, as well as this motion, as Senator Durack outlined it would do, then of course the Opposition's sincerity in its stated opposition to the present system of arms exports will be in serious doubt. After listening to Senator Durack, I think that those doubts are even more serious. Indeed, I certainly hope that each Government member will vote according to his or her own conscience on this motion, given that it raises moral issues comparable to any others which might come before this chamber at any time.

This motion addresses a crisis that we now have arising from a major initiative taken in 1988 by Kim Beazley, then the Defence Minister, when he liberalised the guidelines on arms exports. It is not the case that nothing was said by me, my Democrat colleagues or Senator Vallentine at that time. Nevertheless, the changes were greeted with almost universal praise and support from the business community, the union movement, the media and, at the time, the Opposition. As I said, it was left to a few to challenge the secrecy which would continue to shroud arms exports and to predict that the changes would leave this Government with blood on its hands, jeopardise Australia's security interests, tarnish our country's image as a disarmament advocate, and still fail to yield the forecast economic bonanza.

It gives me no pleasure to say that we were right on each count. The liberalisation of Australia's arms exports guidelines has been a quagmire from which this Defence Minister, Senator Robert Ray, is now desperately trying to extricate the Government. But the export guidelines remain, as far as we can tell, essentially unchanged. This mess will be cleared up only by the intervention of democracy. A Senate inquiry such as I have proposed is an essential starting point.

The Beazley guidelines, as announced in 1987, were aimed at speeding export approvals by reducing the decision time but, we were reassured by Mr Beazley in a media release of 14 June 1988, the grounds for denying export approvals had been more tightly defined. Five such grounds were listed. Of these, only one-adherence to arms embargoes and international sanctions-has been observed. The other four have all been violated. An examination of each will prove my point. Senator Robert Ray, in his contribution, said that only one or two examples of inappropriate sales can be dredged up. I hope that he will take note of this examination that I am making of the violation of all but one of those guidelines.

Mr Beazley claimed that there would be no exports to countries about which there were human rights concerns, such that some risk existed that equipment would be used against its citizens. Yet Senator Ray had, at the time of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, approved the export of spare parts for trainer aircraft to the Iraqi air force-the same air force which in 1988 dropped chemical weapons on Kurdish civilians, killing up to 5,000 of them. Government officials have lamely tried to argue that the trainer aircraft themselves are non- lethal. But David Lague of the Australian Financial Review points out:
. . . this technical distinction is almost irrelevant when Iraq's overall military posture proved to be so deadly.
Trainers play a vital role in preparing pilots to fly lethal high-performance combat aircraft and the PC-9 can also be used as a highly effective ground attack aircraft.

Senator Durack, in his contribution, laid great emphasis on the need to support allies. Well, at the time Iraq was an ally. It now appears that Iran could very well be an ally. Senator Durack also raised another issue: the long term security of our arms industry. How can anything be long term, let alone secure, in a world of sliding and slippy allegiances such as I have just pointed to?

The Government has reported that Australian military sales to the United States of America in 1989-90 totalled $110m. I point out that this too is contributing to the violation of the rights of children, women and men in Kuwait and Iraq who have been killed, maimed, orphaned, widowed and left homeless probably-although we are yet to discover fully-in their tens of thousands under a relentless aerial bombardment campaign led by our major ally.

There is then the question of Somalia, to which approval was given in 1989-90 for the export of goods worth $4.87m. I have reason to believe that that request was subsequently withdrawn and that the export did not proceed. However, according to my information, this appears not to be the result of the stringency of the guidelines, but rather a commercial decision made by the exporter. As is well known, Somalia has been gripped by a civil war which recently resulted in the overthrow of former President Mohammed Siad Barre. Amnesty International's 1990 annual report accuses government forces of killing hundreds of unarmed civilians in attacks, reprisals and extrajudicial executions. Indonesia, the Philippines and Bangladesh also stand accused of serious human rights abuses, and all were significant buyers of Australian arms in 1989-90.

Another case in point is Bougainville, where Australian military equipment and training have contributed to human rights abuses by both the Papua New Guinea defence force and the Bougainville revolutionary army, including torture, ill- treatment and extrajudicial execution. After the abortive military campaign was terminated, Australian-made patrol boats were used to enforce a total embargo on supplies to Bougainville, which led to the collapse of health services and hundreds of innocent deaths. This embargo was also a gross violation of human rights. It went far beyond the terms of the comprehensive sanctions imposed on Iraq, which exempt medical supplies and some foodstuffs on humanitarian grounds.

Let us look at another guideline. Mr Beazley also insisted that export approvals would not be granted if they were to harm Australia's strategic interests. Yet we have just exported 36 Mirage fighters to Pakistan, which has a well documented nuclear weapons program and a simmering dispute with India. The Mirages could deliver nuclear weapons or provide air support for a nuclear strike by Pakistan's frontline F16 aircraft.

An Australian firm, Sinclair Knight and Partners (SKP), is the senior partner in a consortium which is planning a $2 billion west coast base for the Indian Navy. SKP's success in winning the contract was due in part to personal lobbying by Prime Minister Hawke, yet the new base at Goa will be a springboard for India's attempts to gain naval supremacy in the Indian Ocean. The Government would no doubt argue that planning a base is tame stuff compared to supplying warships, for instance. My response is that warships are no use without a base; it is no more moral to supply the bow than the arrow. It should be pointed out that the export guidelines do not cover military services such as naval base planning or training even though they can be as militarily significant as the actual hardware.

Mr Beazley also claimed that exports would be disallowed where specific foreign policy interests outweighed the export benefits. Had this principle been adhered to, the Mirage deal, which is a running sore in our relationship with India, as the Minister has said, would never have gone ahead.

Apart from our relationship with individual countries, Australia has an overriding foreign policy interest which is being undermined by the arms export drive. The present Governor-General, Mr Bill Hayden, when Foreign Minister, along with his disarmament ambassador, issued many calls for a reduction in conventional weapons and the arms trade. Our credibility in lobbying for such measures is much lower now than it once was, yet the time is ripe now, as I am sure we all agree, for conventional arms control, as the world faces the fact that Iraq could not have become the threat it now is without the military assistance of numerous industrialised countries on both sides of the Iron Curtain, as it then was.

As long as we tout our wares without concern for principle and gleefully host obscene arms bazaars here in our national capital, such as AIDEX 91, we have no right to call on other countries to exhibit restraint in their military export policies. The scrapping of AIDEX would be an excellent step in the right direction.

The final ground on which export approvals would supposedly be denied under the Beazley guidelines was opposition to private traffic in arms. Yet the Federal Government allowed the international arms smuggler, Mohammed Kahan, to get away scot-free after an enormous arms cache containing submachine guns, automatic rifles, hand grenades, mortars and antitank mines was discovered in Sydney in May 1988 bound for Fiji. Last year, four Australians were arrested in Singapore for unlawful possession of automatic and semiautomatic pistols, rifles and shotguns. They had been given export approval by Australian Customs. Claims that an Australian company had mediated the sale of fighters from Chile to Iran in 1989 have since been denied, but not before Senator Robert Ray admitted that such activity does not contravene Australian law.

Clearly, the new arms export guidelines have been a ghastly failure, of which I have been able to give more than one or two examples. While the Australian Democrats do not deny that some military exports can be legitimate-where they clearly contribute to the genuine defence of a nation and have no role in human rights violations or offensive military action-the strict implementation of these principles would see the number of export approvals fall dramatically. It is time for a drastic overhaul of the system and for a realisation of the difficulties in terms of international alliances, and the inability of any nation to be certain over the long term what the leadership in another nation might do with such equipment.

Over the past two weeks the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, has made a concerted attempt to prove that the guidelines have become more stringent. The only evidence, however, that he has provided to support his statement is that he claims to have rejected a $450m sale to a country in a region of tension. There is growing evidence-and I found nothing in Senator Robert Ray's answer to a question today to shed any further light on this issue-that this alleged application may never actually have been made. According to my sources, nobody in the defence industry appears to know anything about it. There are no reports from any foreign country that such a huge deal was being sought. I have to wonder whether the Minister has been fabricating a mirage, so to speak, of his own to be sold not to Pakistan this time but to the Australian public.

Even if there is some truth in his claim, it may well have been that the proposed sale was simply impractical because it would have set back the delivery of the product in question to the Australian Defence Force whose needs have become highlighted in recent months. Either way, I have little doubt that the Minister is making a virtue of necessity under pressure from those of us in the community who are questioning Australia's role in arms sales or making a virtue of nothing at all. Unless he reveals all the relevant details-and the attempt was made today by Senator Durack to get such a revelation-the public and my Senate colleagues could be forgiven for assuming that he is misleading us and hiding behind the plea of commercial confidentiality, as he did this afternoon.

This particular incident is at the core of the problem we are debating. The secrecy surrounding the arms export guidelines is a root cause of the blunders that have been made. It is time for Parliament to intervene in the national interest. The Australian Democrats support this motion and call on the Opposition to back our proposal for a Senate inquiry as a matter of urgency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The focus on the issue of arms sales is entirely appropriate, given the current circumstances in the Gulf with the conflict that is now raging. That conflict lends a sense of immediacy to the deliberations in the Senate this afternoon.
