But I suggest that beyond that what we need in an evaluation of the issue is a sense of urgency which will be required in the postwar world as we move to create a genuine new order in international affairs. As part of the process of recovery and reconstruction, not only in the Gulf and Middle East but on a global scale, the world requires a comprehensive international agreement to restrict, wherever possible, the trafficking and sale of arms. The fact that that traffic is being conducted on a global scale means that an international convention is required, a matter on which I shall say more later.

SPEECH.PARA: The platform of the Australian Labor Party on the issue of arms sales is in two parts. First, in the section on defence the platform reads:

Labor will ensure exclusive government control over the manufacture and export of arms and munitions. Regulation should balance the economic and strategic interest, and Labor's support for the inherent right of all nations for self defence with our broad concerns for discouraging conflict and for support of human rights.
That section must be read in complementary terms with the section in the foreign affairs part of the platform which reads:

Labor will support action in the United Nations and directly with other States to reduce the arms trade and to bring about reductions in military budgets. Control and, where appropriate, prohibit the provision or on-sale of Australian arms overseas if they are likely to be used in activity which the Australian Government considers undesir- able, such as abuse of human rights.

I would argue, without fear of contradiction, that the Labor Government has acted consistently with the terms and spirit of the Party platform in those two respects. That platform was arrived at relatively recently at the Hobart 1988 conference of our Party. It was arrived at after very careful consultation within the Party. I am pleased to say it was arrived at unanimously as to the manner in which the proposition was drafted, debated, and adopted. The platform has been applied rigorously in government and in its application the policy works and is seen to work.

Australia has not entered the dimension of major arms suppliers, thankfully. Our total arms exports for last year approached some $160m only, compared with the billions of dollars-in some cases, the tens of billions of dollars-earned by the major arms suppliers.

Most of the Australian arms exports have gone to our traditional friends and allies-to the United Kingdom, the United States (US) and New Zealand, countries with whom Australia has had very close defence ties over generations; with whom we have, or have had, treaty relationships that have been integral to our security; with whom, traditionally, we have traded in military technology; with whom we have exchanged intelligence and, I might add, with whom we have fought wars against aggressors on a number of occasions. As Senator Robert Ray said earlier-I think Senator Durack took up the point-in dealing with the issue it is a question of purposes, a question of objectives and, in trading with these countries, it is also a question of shared values.

The motion before the Senate that Senator Vallentine has moved today falls down because of basic inadequacies. The motion calls for unilateral action and it proposes no effective means of reducing the international arms trade. If Australia were to act unilaterally without consultation with other friendly powers, or outside the umbrella of the United Nations (UN), some other country-in all probability, far less scrupulous about arms trafficking than Australia-would simply pick up the trade. In other words, the motion before the Senate, if carried this afternoon, would achieve precisely nought.

If we are to achieve reductions in international arms trafficking, then it must be achieved through an international framework. The organisation for accomplishing that goal-and it is a very desirable goal-is surely the United Nations, an organisation to which this Parliament is committed and to which all parties represented in this Parliament are committed.

It gives me no joy at all to draw the attention of the Senate this afternoon to what unilateralism has actually brought over generations. Mention has been made of the 1930s earlier in the debate. We could also make mention of the fact that cries for unilateralism in the 1980s accomplished precisely nothing. Multilateralism achieves results through the United Nations or other organisations which bring countries together at the negotiating table. From time to time, bilateral negotiations can achieve highly desirable ends, as we have seen in Geneva between the superpowers. Unilateralism achieves nought.

It is worth while, sobering and, in some respects, disturbing to look at the recent history of global arms trade. It has been dominated by the superpowers of the post-war period-the United States and the Soviet Union, although whether or not we continue to refer to the Soviet Union as a superpower in the full sense of that terminology is open to question, but in terms of military capacity the Soviet Union remains a superpower.

Neither of the superpowers has been blameless with regard to arms trafficking with really difficult parts of the world. It is true that Iraq benefited from quite massive purchases of Soviet weapons and technology and from military advice from the USSR. Iraq benefited further from Western military technology, particularly from France, Britain and Germany. It is only very recently, with revelations in the United States and in Germany, that we have seen the full ramifications of awful German technical advice to Iraq. Iraq benefited also from US technology transfer and from assessments from the US intelligence community during the war with Iran. There were great mistakes made.

Just the other day the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade took evidence from a Colonel in the Australian Army who had experience as a peacekeeper in the immediate aftermath of the conflict between Iraq and the Islamic Republic of Iran. As Kim Beazley and Senator Robert Ray have said previously, Iraq can be described as nothing other than a warfare state. Its governmental apparatus, its bureaucracy, its political process, as well as its economic base and structure, are geared to war-to making war on neighbours; to aggression. It has no other objective. One anecdote may suffice to bring that message home to the Senate.

The circumstances that really brought the message home to me related to the defences constructed by the Iraqi military on the border with Iran. Not since 1918 have we seen trench fortifications that go the length of a country-from the Turkish border to the Shatt al-Arab waterway-of extraordinary complexity and depth. They are truly staggering in their ramifications.

It is true that Saddam Hussein ought not to have been supported. He ought to have been shunned both for his cruelty and his aggression. There are lessons to be learned now, as we deal with the Gulf conflict, in terms of our relations with other powers in the region and beyond.

Let us look at arms sales for the last decade or so and at the list of trouble spots to which arms have been exported. According to a fine article by David Lague in the Australian Financial Review which has been cited before, some 22 wars may be said to have been stimulated and fuelled-to use Mr Lague's expression-by arms trafficking.

If we look at the list of countries that have been both recipients and exporters we see that it is a list of flashpoints. Not only Iraq and Iran, but also Vietnam, Afghanistan and Angola all figure prominently. So do Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and Israel, Pakistan and India. North Korea, for example, exported some $3 billion worth of arms during the decade of the 1980s, while South Korea was a major recipient of US arms.

It is true that the end of the Cold War presents great opportunities to curb arms trafficking for the future, but there are immediate dangers with the end of the Cold War through surplus weapons in both East and West. The United States and the Soviet Union require fewer arms themselves, and so their military industrial complexes will look elsewhere. It is worth quoting President Eisenhower again in his farewell address to the American people on 17 January 1961, in which he used and popularised the term `military industrial complex' virtually for the first time. He said:

In the councils of government, we must guard against the acquisition of unwarranted influence, whether sought or unsought, by the military- industrial complex. The potential disastrous rise of misplaced power exists and will persist.

Eisenhower's observations are as relevant today as when they were made three decades ago for both the military superpowers. Turning to the Australian experience, can we ask rhetorically: is it acceptable to import arms but not export them? Is this a matter of morality transfer? Or are we morally correct in acquiring arms that we need for our self-defence, yet wrong in exporting arms to other countries-particularly friendly powers-which require arms and technology, especially non lethal equipment, for their own legitimate purposes? I am referring, of course, to self- defence.

The Standing Inter-Departmental Committee on Defence Exports was established by the Labor Government in 1988. It works effectively to oversee policy on arms exports. It works on the basis of our international obligations. For example, there have been no exports to countries that have been embargoed by the UN. There are no exports to countries with unsatisfactory human rights records. There are no exports to countries which have acted in defiance of United Nations resolutions. Of course, the disposal of surplus equipment by the Australian Defence Force now also comes under the guidelines.

As Senator Durack observed earlier, the guidelines are seen to work. We do need a new international agreement when this war comes to an end in the same way as the Hague Convention and the Geneva Convention set down principles and procedures on which humanity could order its international affairs. We do need a convention which will restrict and hopefully move us ultimately to ban the traffic in arms firstly to the trouble spots of the world and, ultimately by way of reduction, to eliminate the trade overall. We do need a new convention that applies with force firstly to the reduction of tension and ultimately to the elimination of trafficking in arms and military technology. The war over Kuwait gives us the opportunity to focus on that today. The motion before the Senate is woefully inadequate and ought to be rejected by all in the chamber. It cannot form the basis of a reasoned policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be opposing this motion. We will be opposing it quite simply because it is inaccurate and inappropriate. We in the Liberal and National parties have a long record of support for responsible arms control measures, and this motion completely misses the point about arms control and arms limitation. It misses it by such a mile that it is quite clear that not only has Senator Vallentine had a hand in writing it but also the Australian Democrats and the Democrats' staffers have had a hand in it. It is so inadequate and so incompetent, as the previous speaker, Senator Loosley, said. The motion says:

SPEECH.PARA: Considering the statement of the Minister for Defence, in light of the Gulf War, that `a major lesson for the future relates to the need to control and reduce the international arms trade', the necessity for the Government to cancel Australia's International Defence Equipment Exhibition (AIDEX '91) scheduled to be held in Canberra in November this year, and to abolish its goal of doubling military exports from $250 million to $500 million a year.

First, it is not possible for the Government to cancel AIDEX because it is a private operation. The second point deals with the increase from $250m a year to $500m a year in Australia's exports. The implication of those two claims is that, first of all, there is something wrong with AIDEX. AIDEX is an advertising and promotion exercise for the Australian defence industries collectively. It has a role in informing other countries and potential buyers as to what Australia might be producing that is useful to them. We would hope that sales would ensue from it, but there is no guarantee that any sales would be made there at all. As Senator Durack says, if we have a defence industry and we have a policy of selling overseas, there is nothing wrong in having an exhibition within this country which puts on display what the Australian industries can produce.

The second point refers to the doubling of sales from $250m to $500m. The figure is quite irrelevant. The implication is that, by moving from $250m to $500m, somehow or other we are producing sales of $250m per year. That is not true. The sales last year, the fiscal year 1989-90, totalled $157m. We come to a little point of mischief. I have a copy of the Hansard record of the proceedings of Senate Estimates Committee B. I found that question was one of a series of questions asked by the good Senator Vallentine who, we had to comment earlier in the debate, has very little respect for accuracy or truth in her statements. In direct answer to one of her questions as to the value of exports, she was told that sales last year were $157m.

If Senator Vallentine looks at one of her favourite publications, the SIPRI year book on world armaments and disarmaments for 1990 put out by the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute-that great bible of the lefties, the pacifists, the unilateral disarmers and people such as that-she will see that it lists 15 countries in order of their armaments sales around the world. Poor old Australia does not even make the 15. It is collected with the `others'. It is right off the list. Table after table in the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute year book never mentions Australia. We are lumped behind Egypt and 15 other countries in selling armaments. We are hardly in the big league. The figure of $157m, given the cost of armaments, really is peanuts. This country spends about $8 billion per year on defence. That is only 2.3 per cent of our gross domestic product (GDP), which is far too low a figure. It is generally agreed that the base figure should be about 3 per cent of GDP. Let us just take the figure of $8 billion. As a fraction, the sales of $150m-odd is minuscule. However the point is that the actual figure of sales is quite irrelevant.

It is desirable for Australia to be making its own weapons and its own armaments because it gives us a degree of self-reliance. Furthermore, we have a major interest in promoting regional security. Australia does not live in peace by the strength of its own defence capabilities; it lives in peace because of peace and security within the region. One of the things that this Government has not got onto is the importance of promoting regional security in the part of the world in which Australia lives.

If we are to have regional peace and security, we have to work with the defence forces of our neighbours. While the Association of South East Asian Nations is not a military alliance in any sense at all, it is one of the biggest groupings in our region. If we are to work with those nations for peace and security in the region, we need interoperability. Our forces have to work with theirs. If we are to work in concert with the forces of neighbouring nations, we need common operating procedures and in turn it is desirable to have a degree of commonality in the equipment we have. It should be quite possible for Australia to produce some of the defence equipment for the countries in our region and in turn we could buy some from them.

I have another problem with Senator Vallentine's motion. I doubt its sincerity. All I have heard from Senator Vallentine in the time she has been in this chamber has been the doctrine of unilateral disarmament. In this motion Senator Vallentine is talking not about unilateral disarmament but about the advertising of the sale of armaments-quite a different thing. By implication it could probably be adduced that Senator Vallentine has nothing against the sale of armaments. Everyone in this chamber knows that that simply is not the case. Senator Vallentine is totally opposed to any arms trade whatsoever.

The objection I have to the motion is that it misses the point. The crucial point here is what arms are sold, the nature of them and to whom they are sold. It is not possible to reduce an issue as complex as this to the simple slogans that the peace activists and the apologists for Iraq love to bring into this chamber as a substitute for debate. If it is desirable for Australia to have its own defence industry producing what weapons we can afford to produce within this country, it is quite legitimate for us to be selling those provided we exercise careful judgment in the nature of the weapons we sell and a careful judgment also of the governments to which we sell.

One of the problems we face is that most of the weapons we buy have been produced for the European theatre of operations in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation arena. Often they are not appropriate in the high temperature, high humidity tropical settings that we want to use them in. Again, it gets back to the point that I referred to before of regional security. If we are to support our neighbours and set up a regional defence capability, there is a good argument to have our own endemic production of weapons and weapons systems here that is appropriate for our needs.

As I said, the critical point is the nature of the weapons that we sell. Speakers against this motion have made the point that we have been quite responsible in this country about to whom we sell weapons. It is an extraordinarily difficult decision because there are enormous complexities. The previous speaker talked about the ready availability of arms. One of the sad facts of life, however much we do not like it, is that money buys anything in the armaments field. If a country has enough money, it can buy anything-probably up to and including nuclear weapons. The name of the game from an international relationships point of view is to try to control this very complex situation and that involves judgments being made about the nature of the weapons and the nature of the governments. It also requires a degree of forecasting the future.

Everyone of us here has good hindsight in relation to what happened five or 10 years ago. It is very difficult for us as individuals or collectively as governments to make forecasts as to what might happen in the future. I come back to the point that it is to whom we sell and what we sell to them that are the critical things and they are not the points mentioned in this motion. When we look ahead and try to forecast what might happen to governments it is genuinely very difficult. In our own regional experience we have only got to go back 20 years to the 1960s when we were in a state of undeclared war with President Sukarno, who was then the President of Indonesia. He was replaced by President Suharto. We have enjoyed a very benign environment ever since.

More recently, one has only to look at the great change that has taken place in Europe with the collapse of the Cold War and the way the Warsaw Pact countries now no longer promote a threat to the Western liberal democratic nations. As a consequence of that we saw a few months ago the signing of the Conventional Forces Europe agreement which was absolutely revolutionary. The stage of reductions that the Warsaw Pact countries voluntarily entered into, the reductions that they are making in their armed forces and armaments was absolutely unforeseen three years ago and could not have been predicted.

There has been a degree of restraint operating all the time in what this country has done with the sale of arms. This Government has introduced legislation to set up the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, COCOM, a committee for the investigation of sales. I do not think that is working very well. I am aware of instances where legitimate sales and proper sales were held up for such a period that it was quite uneconomic for the Australian industrial group involved to proceed with them. The bureaucratic procedures were so extended that they were simply not commercially viable.

On the other side of the coin we have had the instance of the sale of Mirage fighters to Pakistan and, if Saddam Hussein had delayed the invasion of Kuwait by a week or so, we would have had the sale of the PC9 parts approved by this Government in the hands of the Iraqis. Clearly, the system in place at the present time is not working and has fundamental flaws but that does not mean to say that it cannot be made to work and in government we will make it work.

Questions have been raised in the debate about where Australian armaments are going. I think it was the Australian Democrats spokesman who made a song and dance about the huge sales to Indonesia in the last 12 months. The sales to Indonesia were $976,000 which is hardly a great amount when we are talking about buying missiles for $1m and upwards at a time. There was a comment about sales to the Philippines but the sales to the Philippines were $3.2m of which $2.2m went to United States armed forces in the Philippines. Only $1m went to the Philippines. The great body of the $157m in Australian armament sales last year went to the United States of America, where over $110m was sold, and nearly $6m went to the United Kingdom-both countries with which we are allied through treaty agreements.

The solution to the problem is to develop our own rules and to develop international agreements. The Liberal Party was the signatory to and worked up the nuclear non-proliferation treaty which is one of the great treaties that exist in arms control at the present time. It stopped the explosion of nuclear weapons around the world. But there are other treaties that can come along. We have seen the Conventional Forces Europe treaty which came up in the recent past and 18 months before it we had the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty under which a whole class of ballistic missiles was removed from Europe.

This is the way that we have to go. We have to carefully assess what arms can be sold to what country and we have to assess the nature of the governments. We do that by introducing treaties and having requirements on the sales and above it all we have the United Nations effectively operating to maintain peace and stability in the world. The great irony is that the purpose of this motion is allegedly to promote peace and stability but the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine are out debasing every authority the United Nations has by pulling down its efforts to introduce some peace and stability by putting a force into the Gulf region to liberate Kuwait.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the urgency motion moved by Senator Vallentine. It was only recently during the special sitting of this Parliament when we debated our involvement in the Gulf war that I spoke immediately after Senator Vallentine. I made some remarks about inconsistencies I found in her views about why we should not be involved in the Gulf.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just come back from South Africa and Senator Vallentine will be pleased to know that some of the people in the world who take similar views to her about opposing the allied involvement in the Gulf in South Africa are the neo-nazis, the AWB. They support Saddam Hussein because he is opposing British and American imperialism in the Gulf. I bring that to Senator Vallentine's attention because I know she has been a strong opponent of apartheid but the people who advocate apartheid in South Africa have exactly the same sorts of views as she does about the allied involvement in the Gulf.

I do not take seriously Senator Vallentine's motion concerning supposed arms sales from Australia, the need for Australia to end the export business and particularly the possibility of cancelling Australia's International Defence Equipment Exhibition later this year because in most of these areas it does not stand up to proper analysis. First of all, let us talk about Australia's weapons exports. It is a very modest program. We have very strict guidelines. Naturally, from time to time all guidelines can be found to have weaknesses; they can always be reviewed. I only wish that most other western countries had the same guidelines as Australia has on the export of weapons. I only wish the same guidelines applied to the Soviet Union, vis-a-vis the supply of weapons to Iraq, or to the French for their supply of weapons to the Middle East or to a number of other western European countries. As Senator Ray, the Minister for Defence, said, in the world today we are in the small league by comparison and have been very careful not to supply weapons to countries in areas of instability.

Naturally, Senator Vallentine and others have pointed out that we supposedly have been proposing to sell some weapons to Iraq. The evidence, of course, points out that they were very minor materials. They were not direct weapons and as soon as the United Nations (UN) embargo came on Iraq they were cancelled in accordance with that embargo. The guidelines make it very clear that we do not sell weapons to countries in contravention of UN resolutions, that are subject to UN embargoes. The guidelines say that we cannot sell weapons to Israel because it is in contravention of UN resolutions about the Middle East. I do not find Senator Vallentine giving the Government credit for that sort of guideline-that we refuse to sell weapons to Israel when quite clearly there would be a very profitable market for weapons in Israel or elsewhere in the Middle East. We do not sell weapons where countries are in contravention of the UN.

We have consistently followed UN resolutions. We have consistently been a proper player in the world community in following UN dictates and, of course, we have followed the UN dictates about our involvement in support of the allied effort of getting Kuwait liberated. When one looks at the list of our exports-the way that both Senator Vallentine and the Democrats have gone on in the past, one imagines that we have hundreds of millions, if not billions, of dollars of export sales-one is actually surprised at how modest it is compared with what other countries are supplying in their export of weapons.

I do not see Senator Vallentine criticising such countries as China, for example, which will basically sell a weapon to anyone, anywhere, at any time, no matter what the consequences. Most of our export sales go to two main markets: to New Zealand, which is our closest friendly country and with whom our relationship for 100 years or more cannot be doubted; and also to the United States. These are the two countries that are with us in the ANZUS alliance. In neither case can those weapons that have been sold be criticised. All the rest, in terms of the world's arms sales, are minuscule by comparison but, even so, many of them are being rejected because they do not meet the guidelines.

What really annoys me about Senator Vallentine and the Democrats with this sort of motion and the views they express is that they get up here consistently arguing that we should have what they call a totally independent foreign policy, a totally independent defence policy, and have no alliances or arrangements with any other country. Well, we cannot have a totally independent foreign policy and a totally independent defence policy without having a self-reliant and self-sufficient armaments and defence industry in this country.

Bill Hayden once said that it is no use arguing for an aggressive independent foreign policy with a pacifist defence policy. They just do not go together. If we want to have some influence in the world with an independent view, then we have got to have some independence in our defence forces and not rely on everybody else to provide those weapons. So this Labor Government since 1983 has made a major transformation of defence procurement policy in this country. When we came to office, as I understand the figures, only about 20 per cent of the procurement of defence weapons was from within Australia, with 80 per cent imported from overseas. However, with the major weapons programs that we have now developed-that is, building in Australia the submarines, the frigates, the Jindalee and so on-we now procure about 80 per cent of our weapons from within Australian industry. We are using the taxpayers' money to develop those industries in Australia to make sure that we do not exacerbate our balance of trade deficit and so on.

I cannot imagine why the Democrats and Senator Vallentine argue that that is not a good thing. If they were really fair dinkum about arguing for an independent foreign policy and always saying that we should not be in alliance with America, then they surely must have to argue for an independent self-reliant defence force. If one reads the material put out by Dr Martin, representing the association promoting the concept of armed neutrality for Australia, one sees that he makes no bones about the fact that we have to have an independent defence force which is properly armed and capable of defending Australia's sovereignty within our region. He does not go around saying, `Get rid of the defence industries'. He makes the point that we cannot have it both ways; that we cannot say, `Get out of all the alliances with America and the West' and then say, `We are not going to have any defence capacity in this country'. He knows that that is not sustainable with the Australian people. I only wish that the Democrats and Senator Vallentine would concede that point, as certainly Dr Martin makes the point--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just outlined our policy, Senator.

—Yes, but Dr Martin does not go the way the Democrats go in arguing for the gutting of Australia's defence. The Democrats do not concede that point because they keep arguing for the reduction of defence expenditure in this country.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's responses to reports of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, on the Review of the National Capital Plan, dated May 1990, and the Review of the National Capital Plan, second report, the certified draft report, dated August 1990, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the response of the Government to the reports of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. It is ironic in a sense that I still have in my drawer from the end of the last session the national capital plan, December 1990, as certified by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly). It was on the Notice Paper at the time but was not reached and I did not get an opportunity to speak on it.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the Government's response to the two reports which the Manager of Government Business (Senator Robert Ray) has now tabled in the Senate. It comes about as a result of the granting of self-government to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), which came into existence in 1989. Under that legislation it was required that plans be devised to determine which parts of the Territory were to be part of national capital plans and which, under the influence of the Commonwealth, were to be the responsibility of the ACT Government.

Initially a draft plan was put out for public comment and consultation and the Joint Committee embarked upon a review of that. We did not table that report until May 1990 as the tabling was interrupted by the election last year, during which time the second draft was put out, that report being the subject of the report tabled in August 1990, to which the Government has now also responded. It was necessary to extend the time within which the plan came into existence because it was clear to everybody involved that there was more work than initially had been seen to be the case. That is the plan which was certified and released by the Minister in December 1990 that I referred to.

I shall not go in detail through all the recommendations made in both May and August last year. I wish to refer to just a couple of those responses. For the most part the recommendations of the Joint Committee have been accepted. A number of them have been accepted in principle; I am pleased to say that very few have been rejected. There is an acceptance in part of the third recommendation of the May report, which deals with the question of the timetable for the availability of the plan, and that is understandable. Some of those that are accepted in principle I would like to think were genuinely accepted in principle with a view to working actively towards their acceptance. I hope that that is what it means. I have no reason to suggest that it does not; I merely say that those accepted in principle will be monitored by me to see whether as time passes they work out to be just that.

Recommendation 12 is one of the recommendations which have been rejected by the Government. It recommends that the area in Civic, Vernon Circle and City Hill; Acton, south of Parkes Way; Anzac Way; the precincts of the Australian War Memorial; and those areas of national land between Parkes Way and Constitution Avenue be designated areas but that the remainder of Civic, Acton and Reid proposed for designation should be subject only to special requirements. That has been rejected. I hope that in time there will be some modification of this because I believe that that seriously interferes with the role of the ACT Government in planning in the Civic area.

It was my view that the area south of Parkes Way clearly bordering onto the lake and its confines was part of the national capital plan, but that the other side of Constitution Avenue where the school of technical and further education is situated, while an area and roadway of considerable significance, also contained the Convention Centre, and building and space clearly in my view ought to be determined at least principally by the ACT Government. For that reason we felt that special requirements were adequate. I am disappointed at that rejection and similarly that the Committee's recommendation in relation to University Avenue and Ainslie Avenue has been rejected. As I said, I am hopeful that what will happen in those areas will be worked out between the two governments in a way that does not disadvantage the citizens of the ACT.

Another recommendation related to the procedures to be adopted. The Committee said that the National Capital Planning Authority (NCPA) and the Territory Planning Authority should integrate the national capital plan and the Territory plan, and jointly develop a set of simplified procedures, including a one-stop office, for the administration of the plan and the approval of planning applications. It is said that this is accepted in principle and that the NCPA has prepared draft procedures and is discussing these with the Territory Planning Authority.

I cannot stress firmly enough how necessary it is for those trying to do business in Canberra to know exactly what the plan is, the way it operates and what they have to do. It is highly disruptive to have two separate plans, two separate authorities, and to have to go from one to the other. There have already been complaints from people about the difficulties in getting things approved and knowing exactly which authority will make a determination. As I say, the recommendation of the Committee has been accepted in principle. There needs to be an enormous amount of will to ensure that it operates so as not to economically disadvantage the ACT. There is a great need for this to be carried out.

One of our other recommendations, which again has been accepted in principle, concerns the resolution of disputes between the National Capital Planning Authority, which really represents the Federal Government and the Interim Territory Planning Authority. I am sure we all hope that there will not be disputes between the two, but it seems to me-and it seemed to the Committee-that there were inadequate mechanisms in place to resolve this. The Commonwealth's response seems to indicate that there is no necessity for an appeal mechanism and that there is no need to appeal against an NCPA decision.

What we were talking about was the relationship between the two governments and how disputes or disagreements between them might be resolved. I do not believe that the response of the Commonwealth is adequate to deal with that. I would urge the Minister to have another look at it and enter upon discussions, hopefully to work out a mechanism before any such dispute arises.

There are a lot of things in the first report-the Committee report of May 1990-which it would be nice to talk about, but they are apparent from the report and the acceptance which the Commonwealth has given to the recommendations of the Committee.

Turning to the report tabled in August 1990, there were five recommendations. I spoke at some length about them when I tabled the report as Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee. I welcome the acceptance of the recommendation relating to the Lanyon and Murrumbidgee corridors and the rural landscape that is encompassed within them. I regard them as very important. Eventually, Canberra has to stop being built and run into the mountains in a way that it cannot go any further, especially in the south. I regret in some ways that the housing construction has gone as far south as it has. But I welcome the acceptance of the recommendation relating to the area and its future. The second recommendation of the Committee states:
The Department of Defence urgently consider ways of making as much land as possible occupied by the Belconnen and Bonshaw Naval Communications Stations available for housing development.

One of the things that makes this city an expensive place to live in is the fact that it is spread out. All of us are aware of that and would not want it to change significantly. But it means that the cost of the infrastructure is quite high. The question of infill is talked about frequently and people invariably urge infill. When we actually question them about which bits should be filled in, it is very difficult to get them to make a commitment. It always seems to be a bit that is further away from their place than the one we might be looking at.

I do not think there is much doubt that the naval areas I have referred to are areas which will be built on in time, and they ought to be. In fact, I suggest it should occur sooner rather than later, to keep the costs of the spreading city within reasonable bounds. There are some problems in relation to parts of Harman but it is not necessary to go into those tonight. The Government says that this recommendation is accepted in principle. The response states:
The draft Plan permits urban use of the Belconnen site and foreshadows further planning study of the Bonshaw site.
It goes on to say:
Defence requires both sites until a new communications station is built outside the ACT.

I could not help wondering how long it took it to work out that form of wording. This is well known and obvious, but the response somewhat neglects to use the word `urgently', which was the word used by the Joint Committee when it recommended that the Department of Defence urgently consider ways of making as much land as possible available. DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, pursuant to the orders of the Senate of 23 August 1990 and 22 January 1991, I lay on the table the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Rescue the Future-reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect, together with the transcript of evidence, which was presented to the President on 23 January 1991. In accordance with the terms of the orders, the President has authorised the printing and circulation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology released this report by presenting it to the President on 23 January 1991. This is a significant report in that it examines the possibilities for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in Australia, and makes hard recommendations for achieving those greenhouse gas reductions. The Committee concluded that the greenhouse effect is real after examining the scientific evidence and, from there, working towards finding practical and affordable solutions.

The Committee received evidence that indicated that greenhouse gas emissions could be substantially reduced by increasing the efficiency with which we use energy and encouraging the development of new technologies, including renewable energy technology, such as solar power.

The achievement of greenhouse gas reductions will require a national approach. A central recommendation of the Committee is that a Special Premiers Conference be convened for the specific purpose of addressing greenhouse gas emissions. That conference should be held before the end of this year.

A key recommendation of the Committee is that a long term approach to the problem be adopted. The report focuses on energy conversion and use, and recommends that a 10-year energy plan be developed for ratification at the Special Premiers Conference. Central elements of that energy plan must include strategies in the following areas: a new charter for energy authorities emphasising least cost planning and demand management instead of traditional supply dominated approaches; more interstate sharing of power generation resources; an integrated national transport strategy, including fuel consumption standards for cars, incentives for purchasing fuel efficient vehicles and greatly improved public transport; energy use targets for houses in the commercial sector, including insulation standards and energy efficient design; national appliance labelling in all States with appliance energy standards to follow; and increased support for renewable and advanced energy technology development.

The amount of interest in the inquiry emphasised its importance. The Committee's terms of reference call for an examination of the contribution that industry, science and technology could make to reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect. The Committee sought and received evidence in all those areas.

At the industry level there was some concern about the cost of measures specifically aimed at reducing the impact of greenhouse gases. On the whole, though, the approach of industry was positive in that there was an acknowledgment of the problems and planning processes are under way to address them. In addition to industry making plans in this way, the Committee identified many opportunities that exist for industry in development and manufacture of new technology. In some areas Australia is at the cutting edge of new technologies which have the potential substantially to reduce emissions and for which there will be larger future world markets.

A good example is photovoltaics, the solar cells which recently powered the Spirit of Biel-Bienne, which features on the cover of the report, to victory in the Darwin to Adelaide solar challenge race. They were designed at the University of New South Wales. Disappointingly, however, industry has been slow to recognise the opportunities presented by these emerging technologies. The Australian designed and developed laser groove solar cell technology on the Spirit of Biel-Bienne is a prime example. It was offered to Australian industry under favourable conditions but subsequently was sold under licence to overseas companies. BP Solar Australia Pty Ltd plans shortly to manufacture the cells in Spain with the possibility of their manufacture at a later stage in Australia.

The contribution that science and technology can make to reducing greenhouse gas emissions was investigated thoroughly by the Committee. We were heartened by the amount of research that is being undertaken and the opportunities that have been identified. Unfortunately, those opportunities have not been backed by funding to make them a reality. The contribution of funding by both governments and industry has been too low and often misdirected.

The report sets out clearly the need for a substantial increase in funding to projects which should become projects for national priority development. In addition to increasing funding for energy research, which in most cases equates to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, the Government should make a long term commitment to maintaining the 150 per cent research and development deduction rather than decreasing it to 125 per cent as it proposed. The Committee considers this action vital for the stimulation of research and development within industry.

The Committee's view is that reducing emissions through energy efficiency is the best approach to take until widespread international agreements about emission reductions are reached. While Australian greenhouse gas emissions per person are high by world standards, our overall total emissions are relatively insignificant when compared to the global total. The Australian Government has now set emission targets and, to be able to meet those targets, action has to be taken now. International targets when set could in all probability be more stringent than those already adopted by Australia. To be in a position to meet tougher targets in the future and not suffer severe economic cost, Australia must begin to take effective action now.

Fortunately, energy efficiency measures which, as I mentioned earlier, are the most immediate and effective means for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, have economic benefits as well as environmental advantages. In many cases investment in energy efficiency pays for itself within a relatively short period. Other advantages are to be gained from energy efficiency. For example, a more efficient transport fleet will help to decrease Australia's future dependence on imported oil and reduce our balance of payments.

The Committee's report sets out many other areas in which energy efficiency can be achieved. None of the measures in itself is new. What is required is the bringing together of a whole range of such measures in a cohesive strategy, as suggested in the report, that would result in action. In the area of greenhouse, there has been an enormous amount of talk, particularly in the past couple of years, backed up by an endless procession of conferences, seminars, studies and reports. What has been lacking is specific action to do something about the problem.

The setting of a planning target of a 20 per cent reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by 2005 is a good first step towards doing something meaningful about emissions. This report emphasises that it is now time to put in place measures to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases to meet targets that have now been set. Effective action will require long term planning in many areas, for example, power generation technology and development of alternative energy sources. In addition, a commitment to research and development and funding must also be made. Immediate planning and a long term commitment will result in a future benefit for the nation in terms of both reduced greenhouse gas emissions and energy cost savings.

The Committee discusses in the report the issue of energy and the greenhouse effect in much detail. The report makes specific comments about electricity generation in Australia. The Committee found that significant efficiency improvements could be made in this area. In particular, the Committee concluded that electricity utilities require a new charter. Rather than simply seeing their role as suppliers of energy, they should consider their role as suppliers of energy services. This approach combined with least cost planning could in itself lead to significant energy improvements in the way in which electricity utilities operate. Because of the significance of electricity supply as a contributor to greenhouse gas emissions, a national approach must be adopted.

State boundaries should not be a consideration. For example, because of the low efficiencies attained in Victoria from burning brown coal, the Committee would not advocate the construction of additional power stations based on brown coal in the Latrobe Valley but recommended more efficient generating technologies based on the most efficient stations using black coal. These stations currently have a conversion efficiency of approximately 35 per cent compared to the most efficient brown coal plants of 29 per cent. Better still will be the use of gas combined cycle turbines which release approximately 50 per cent less carbon dioxide than the most efficient black coal power stations.

In addition, the Committee identified opportunities for co-generation which offer even greater efficiencies. These opportunities must be pursued before any further commitment is made to technologies whose relative inefficiency would preclude their use in future years when even tougher targets apply.

As well as looking at electricity generation, the Committee examined energy end use to determine whether efficiency improvements could be made. The report contains specific recommendations for commercial, industrial, residential and transport sectors which are too detailed to outline here but which would form the basis for a more detailed action plan for greenhouse gas emissions reductions based on better use of energy.

In summary, there is a big challenge facing this nation to reduce greenhouse emissions. If approached correctly, the nation can benefit from measures to meet targets. I urge all honourable senators to study the report and its implications and opportunities. I look forward to the Government's response to the report and, along with my colleagues on the Committee, will actively pursue the recommendations and strategies contained in the report with relevant Ministers and officials of the Commonwealth, significantly those at the State and local government levels.

I thank my colleagues for their support and activity in the long and complex inquiry. I have presented a number of reports over a few years now and I can say that in my experience I have not had a committee that has had a more collective effort in producing a report. I have been very pleased with the way in which we have worked so well together. The evidence of experts who provided submissions and oral evidence is also acknowledged, as is the contribution from industry and government sources. Finally, I think that the secretariat of the Committee has done excellent work in an excellent team effort. I therefore commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks made by the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. SPEECH.PARA: We started off the inquiry on the basis that we did not presume that the greenhouse effect was a fact. We started off by saying that whether or not there was a greenhouse, cleaning up the atmosphere had a lot going for it. By the time we got through the first phase of finding out what the culprits were we started to look at the issues involved and what to do about them. We found that half of the warming effect comes from energy use or generation and that was the major area that we were able to start on. Power generation, motor vehicles, industry and residential areas are all contributors and we looked at all of those areas.

We had a look at how to start. We looked at the generation of power by other means and we looked at the use of alternative energy, how to improve transport and how to practise economy of use. We found out early on that Australia lags behind many other countries in the energy efficiency field. I realised this on a parliamentary visit to Denmark just before Christmas. We found an electricity station which was fired with Australian black coal but which also had nine wind generators in the same area. The power generation question is the biggest problem we face and we did not spend any time at all in considering the nuclear alternative. We assumed that the nation at this juncture is not ready for contemplation of that sort of thing, so we did not spend any time on it. We then considered gas for electricity and found that burning gas to generate electricity is a fairly wasteful thing to do if the gas can be used as a direct means of energy in the first place-as a primary fuel.
