We had a look at a whole range of developing units. We saw various solar alternatives and the solar heaters that we have seen for heating water for years-the photovoltaic cells and so on-and we were also impressed with the solid oxide fuel cells and the availability that they will have in a wide range of uses in due course. We found that the current thinking there is that the cost per unit is not going to be much different whether it is a big unit or a small unit. In other words, we can decide how much power needs to be generated and build a unit accordingly. This means that small towns can build a unit to cover the whole town and industries of various sizes can build their own units to make it part of the plan. They would then be in charge of their own operations right through. It would enable serious co-generation and transfer of power between electricity authorities and separate generators. It would enable us to get the generation of power, to some extent at least, out of the hands of government which would be a great improvement.

We could see that these projects need to be organised as national priority projects and it means that we have to look at these organisations with the funny names, the ERDC, the Energy Research and Development Corporation, the NERDDP, the national energy research development and demonstration program, and the ARC, the Australian Research Council, and make sure that these are on the list. If not, we have to have special allocations just so that we can make sure these are funded adequately. The universities, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and, to some extent, industry are all working on it now but a stimulus is necessary. Of course, at the time that the stimulus is necessary we find that the projects that are being developed by CSIRO have had their funding cut.

The Chairman mentioned electricity audits. We believe that these are going to become important and that the householder, the commercial operator or the industry operator will want them. Whether or not it will be necessary to make them obligatory remains to be seen. But I believe they will be done just by making it attractive for people to do so.

The question of labelling and branding of appliances has also been mentioned. There is the provision of bonuses for the economic use of cars through lower registration fees for cars that meet certain limits. We are now looking, according to the car clubs, for a figure of eight litres per hundred kilometres by the year 2005. They also suggested that a figure of six litres per hundred kilometres is quite possible later on.

Our transport generally is bad and uneconomic. It is cluttered. In the cities we have too much traffic standing about and belching out gases while it is standing still. We have to look at better ways of moving people. Certainly, in this regard I am in no doubt that a project such as the Very Fast Train, where we can shift on one line 30,000 people a day, is the sort of project that we have to consider.

If we can get hundreds of thousands of cars off the road and hundreds of thousands of trucks off the road and fewer aeroplanes in the air and put their passengers and freight on to a railway line on the ground, that certainly must be the way to go. We have to change our attitudes on car sharing and we have to make sure that we have the most appropriate public transport. We have to list the special projects that need to be attended to so that we have them before us and we can then work on them. We have to consider what Australians already do well and the areas where they can do best.

We proved years ago with ordinary solar heating that we could be leaders in the world. We can do this in a whole range of these things. Then, once we have got those, the world is a huge market. It is enormous; it is absolutely huge and vast. Australia can do it, and we ought to be concentrating on doing this. It is crazy that we get these various developments up to a certain stage and then start to cut the funds on them when, at that stage, we ought to be pouring the funds in to make sure that nothing gets between us and the ultimate goal and so that we would be able to get these things merchandised and do our bit for cleaning up the world. Governments at all levels are going to find that it is necessary to provide encouragement for economy and conservation as well, because they have a vested interest in clean atmospheres and clean countries and they must do their part towards making it more interesting.

The question of power utilities and what they should be doing is important. In the past, we have seen that the main aim of power utilities is to generate as much power as they possibly could and then sell it. I believe that has long since been the wrong way round. For many years I have advocated that the generating authority and the retailing authority should not be in the same hands-that they should be entirely separate-because I believe that they have a fundamental conflict of interest. The utilities are the people who should be selling the various saving appliances that are necessary, as they did in my State of Tasmania many years ago in selling block heaters when they were trying to encourage people to use more of that type of heating. I believe that they should be encouraging people to use other than electric, and they should be providing those incentives with long term loans and pay-offs with the monthly accounts.

I am also certain that we need to have a much better look at the interstate load sharing, the co-generation involved and the cooperation between various industries. We need to study the building code more regularly and see how we can gently ease people into being more conscious of how they get better value for their money, and how the savings that are available can be made by changes to their various designs and buildings.

The inquiry was a fascinating one to work on. I certainly recommend the report as interesting reading. I would like to thank the Chairman for the way that he conducted the inquiry and also the committee staff for the way that they carried it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of the previous two speakers. It gives me particular pleasure to speak on this report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Rescue the Future-reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect. There are a number of reasons for my pleasure in this. One is that, as the Chairman and Senator Archer have already indicated, there was enormous cross-party support for concern over the question of greenhouse, the sorts of strategies, and the urgencies of the strategies that need to be adopted to address that very important problem. While often there is sniping in this chamber from certain quarters on environmental and conservation matters, on this particular Committee there was indeed a great deal of consensus, support and cooperation, which was extremely valuable.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe this is one of the better reports that any Senate committee has ever tabled, because we were able to go further than one is able to with many reports in which there are substantial and fundamental differences of opinion. Those differences of opinion did not emerge in this case. As Senator Archer has said, the Chairman was a particularly good chairman. He was particularly efficient at keeping the Committee on track, as were the staff members who worked with the Committee, particularly Rob Diamond and Peter Hallahan. The whole team, the Committee and the staff, worked extremely well. As the others have already said, this Committee's report would really repay very close reading because of the distance that it has been able to go in its recommendations.

I would like to say something about the genesis of this reference because there are a number of ways in which the Industry, Science and Technology Committee may have taken up a reference on greenhouse. This was recognised when I first proposed greenhouse as a reference to the Committee. First of all, some said that it was really not a matter for industry, science and technology at all; that it was a matter that should be sent off to the environment committee. That in itself indicates a certain attitude: that greenhouse is an environmental issue whereas industry, science and technology is something else.

Fortunately, the Committee was able to see that the causes of greenhouse, the causes of the changes in the global atmosphere, relate very much to what we do with our industry and our science-how we actually apply that; the sorts of technologies that we use; and the sorts of economic systems in which we live. If we were really going to address the problem of greenhouse in terms of how we can head it off, then it was most appropriate to be tackled by the Industry, Science and Technology Standing Committee and not by the committee on environment. So that was accepted.

Then it was interesting to see how several government departments sought to deflect the original intention of the Committee to look at how we head greenhouse off as far as that is possible. Suggestions were made such as: we should really look at collecting all the information that is available on greenhouse and simply make that available-or, conversely, how do we adapt to greenhouse? It was interesting to see the departments from which those suggestions came: Senator Button's Department, for instance, and even the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories came forward with that sort of deflective proposal. It was with some difficulty that, in the early stages of this reference, the Committee was able to stick to the reference that it wanted and take up this far more important reference; that is, greenhouse is potentially a very serious problem, and how do we do things which will avoid getting us into a greenhouse situation as far as that is possible? Indeed, that eventually was the reference that we took and, as the Chairman has said, based on that reference we went forward; took a lot of evidence; the Committee worked very hard; and the Senate has before it a really excellent report.

I think it is worth saying something about the differences of opinion which lie in certain aspects of the greenhouse question because, both in the popular press and indeed in recent times in this chamber, we have seen people casting doubt on greenhouse because of the doubt which still exists over the detailed consequences of greenhouse warming. It is important to recognise where there is absolute knowledge and understanding and where the doubt still lies. There is no doubt that the composition of the atmosphere has changed very dramatically since the beginning of the industrial era, and there is no doubt that that change is continuing at quite a considerable rate-indeed far faster than at any time in the geological past.

There is general acceptance that the changes in the global atmosphere are related to human intervention, to the burning of fossil fuel, to the cutting of rainforests, to the release of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCS), to the use of nitrogenous fertilisers, and to the release of methane as a consequence of increased agricultural activities and the keeping of herbivorous animals in larger numbers. There is no doubt about that. We have good figures which come from the ice cores in the Antarctic and from Greenland. We now have a record both of global temperature and of global atmospheric composition which goes back almost 200,000 years. When that record is looked at we find there is a very, very close parallel between global temperature and the concentration of carbon dioxide over that very long period. As the concentration of carbon dioxide has gone up, so the global temperature has gone up. As the concentration of carbon dioxide has gone down, the global temperature has gone down. We find, moreover, throughout most of that time that the composition of methane in the global atmosphere has remained remarkably constant and yet in the last 100 years or so the concentration of methane has been increasing. It is currently increasing at roughly twice the rate that carbon dioxide is increasing.

It is known that a number of these gases will trap the long wave infra-red radiation as it goes out from the earth into space. So there is a general scientific consensus-I will not say universal-that, as a consequence of this increase in concentration of this range of gases, there will be an increase in global temperature. From that, a number of consequences will follow. The predictions would indicate that the increases in concentration of gases so far would have resulted in about a half to one degree rise in temperature. The best evidence indicates there has been approximately half a degree rise in temperature. The problem with that observation is that there is an enormous noise in the signal of global temperature.

I do not think any scientist would claim that at present the increase which has been observed has broken through the background noise, so there is considerable and genuine doubt as to whether the increase that has occurred so far is related to that increase in gas. All one can say is that on the theoretical models which are used it is consistent with what would be found if we were experiencing the greenhouse. Similarly, as one goes on with the other effects, as one looks at the consequences of increase in temperature, the predictions for changes in global climate, the changes in local weather patterns, the changes in sea level, the changes in the ecology of various areas, and the changes in agriculture which will occur as a consequence of those changes, there is considerable doubt about the size of those effects and the rate of onset of those effects.

It is very important to point out that that is where the doubt lies. No doubt surrounds the increase in the concentration of gases in the atmosphere. No doubt surrounds the historical, geological evidence relating the levels of gas to temperature. The best scientific opinion, although not universal, is that there will be a greenhouse effect and that within the next 10 to 15 years the increase in global temperature will unequivocally break through the background noise and we will know definitely that we are in a greenhouse phenomenon. That, I believe, is the basis on which we should be acting; that is, the basis on which we should be considering the sorts of strategies that we need to use when we approach this question of greenhouse. It is the best evidence available. The evidence is that that evidence will be corroborated within 10 to 15 years and will become unequivocal.

The intergovernmental panel on climate control which met last year considered this question in a number of subcommittees. The scientific sub-committee of that intergovernmental panel on climate control said that on the evidence available it was urgently necessary to reduce greenhouse gas emissions globally by as much as 60 to 80 per cent. A 60 to 80 per cent reduction is a very large reduction indeed. If one looks at the per capita emission of greenhouse emissions, one finds, as Senator Childs has already pointed out, that Australia is a very profligate user of fossil fuels, a very profligate user of CFCS and halons, and is a very significant global emitter of greenhouse gases on a per capita basis.

So it becomes necessary to consider that Australia will need to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 92 per cent. I repeat that figure, 92 per cent. If we do not, then what we are essentially saying to the rest of the world is that we are usurping to ourselves an unfairly high proportion of the capacity of the global atmosphere indefinitely to absorb greenhouse gases. We are saying to the rest of the world, `Sorry, you either have to suffer a greenhouse effect with all its consequences or you have to forever forgo your fair share of the use of fossil fuels and the use of all the other technologies which result in the emission of greenhouse gases'. Morally, the situation in 10 to 15 years is very likely to be that we will be faced unequivocally with a situation in which we must reduce our greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 92 per cent.

Looking at our future-honourable senators will notice that the report we are considering is titled Rescue the Future -reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect-how do we look at the next 10 to 15 years in the light of what we may have to do only that distance out? I think it follows that in cases where we can adopt lifestyle changes, technological changes, new technologies, and conservation measures which do not cost a great deal of money, which have short payback times, and even if the savings of greenhouse gas emissions which can be made are not particularly substantial, then those changes should be made.

For instance, we might change the sorts of light globes that we use in our houses. There is a worked example in the back of this report on how much saving that could achieve and where the monetary savings would fall. On the other hand, there are major changes in the technological structure which are now contemplated which cost a large amount of money, which have very long payback times and which may or may not achieve significant savings. These are the ones we need to be extremely careful about in the way we approach them. For instance, consider the example given by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Childs. We may consider going from a coal fired power station at 35 per cent maximum efficiency to a gas fired combined cycle station with a 50 per cent maximum efficiency. We would indeed save a significant amount of greenhouse gas emissions.

A number of States are considering building new power stations. If a decision is made in the next two to three years to build such a power station, a large one of a thousand megawatts will cost roughly $1 billion. It will take about 10 years to build and will come on stream sometime when the evidence that unequivocally we need to very substantially reduce greenhouse gas emissions by a figure of 92 per cent becomes incontrovertible.

What do we do when we have a power station on which we have spent $1 billion, which has a lifetime of 30 to 40 years and does not achieve the efficiency improvements in terms of greenhouse gas emissions that need to be achieved? Do we decide simply to write-off $1 billion or do we go ahead and exploit that power station and continue to pollute for a long time into the future? Bringing those sorts of decisions back into the present means that in the cases where we face major expenditure with long term pay back times we must attempt to avoid making decisions on those sorts of investments as long as we possibly can. That is where many of the efficiency improvements which are mentioned in this report come into place. There are many ways in which industry, individuals and society as a whole can conserve electricity so that the existing installed electricity-generated capacity is sufficient to meet those needs over the next 10 to 15 year time span and it becomes unnecessary to build more power stations. It is urgent that we lay pressure on the Western Australian Government-there is a case at the moment-not to build the power station that it is contemplating, but to increase far more significantly the energy conservation measures which can be put in place and which would significantly reduce the demand for electricity and so extend the life of the existing installed capacity.

Queensland is another State in which a further power station is being contemplated. Again, it should be pressured not to make that decision and to avoid the building of any more power stations until well into the early years of the next century. There are good reasons for doing this, quite apart from the energy saving. The power utilities in Australia currently owe $27 billion. They have been very profligate not only with the building of power stations and the encouragement of the inefficient use of electricity, but also with the spending of public money. A large part of that debt is foreign owed because when power stations are built the heavy generating equipment comes offshore, as does a lot of the other equipment used in power generation, transformation and transmission. If a decision can be made not to build more power stations over the next 10 to 15 years there are very considerable economic savings as well as greenhouse gas savings to Australia. The rate of increase of debt of the utilities far and away exceeds the rate of growth of the economy, and there would be very good reasons for that decision to be taken.

The key to many of these conservation measures lies in the way electricity is charged for. I ask honourable senators to look at page 169 of the report. There is an example of the way in which a decision by a householder to buy an incandescent globe or a compact fluorescent globe results in an overall reduction in the cost both to the community and the consumer. Most of the saving actually accrues to the utility because the capital cost of installing the generating equipment for 65 watts of electricity is roughly $65, whereas the equivalent compact fluorescent globe taking 13 watts requires only $13 of capital investment by the utility.

Most of the savings of a decision which is made by the individual consumer actually accrue not to the consumer but to the utility. This suggests that one urgent necessity in achieving greater efficiencies in the use of electricity is to ensure that there is a shift of that benefit from the utility to the ultimate consumer of electricity.

If we extend this example to the consideration of purchasing a solar hot water service or an electric hot water service, we find that if a consumer decides to buy a solar hot water service, all the up-front capital cost is paid for by the consumer-roughly $1,700 or $1,800-whereas if the decision is to buy an electric hot water service, the consumer might save, initially, some $1,100 in that purchase. In doing so, the utility which must supply the electricity is faced with anything between $3,000 and $7,000 worth of capital investment required to put in the generating equipment to provide the electricity for the electric hot water service.

Again, the decision by the individual consumer, which is based perhaps on a concern over greenhouse and using renewable energy, would leave the individual consumer with an initial up-front capital cost of an additional $1,100, which would only be slowly recouped over eight or nine years, but in the process the utility would make a very substantial saving in not having to install a large amount of generating capacity. The key to getting people to use solar hot water as distinct from electric hot water is simply to shift some of that economic gain from the utility to the consumer.

It is interesting to notice that in my own State of South Australia, where the electricity tariffs are severely weighted against the consumer, there is only about 1 1/2 per cent penetration of solar hot water services, whereas in Perth, where the tariff structures are more reasonably arranged, there is about a 30 per cent penetration of solar hot water services. So, quite clearly, very significant shifts can be achieved through providing the right incentives.

The other area that I think bears some mention-this has already been mentioned by both honourable senators-is the way in which this country has developed some extremely clever technology. I personally become very distressed when I hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say that we must become a clever country. We are an extremely clever country. In terms of scientific papers which are published in reputable, refereed, scientific journals, Australia is the most productive country in the world. We are a clever country indeed.

In the area of alternative energy sources, we have some extremely clever and absolutely first class developments which are lacking proper support from this Government and, therefore, are likely to go off-shore and be developed by others and then we will have to import them back again. Senator Archer and Senator Childs have referred to several of these, but I think they bear some repetition.

The development of the solid oxide fuel cell would not merely increase efficiency from 35 to 50 per cent-which I mentioned earlier, going from coal to combined cycle gas-but may well increase the efficiency of the generation of electricity up to 60 to 70 per cent. Moreover, as Senator Archer pointed out, these units, which can be built in any size from a kilowatt up to hundreds of megawatts, would allow the units to be installed in factories down on the corner, if you like, of each suburban block, and the waste heat, which is about 30 per cent as distinct from 60 to 70 per cent with a conventional power station, can be used locally.

One can then increase the efficiency with which one uses the gas in the solid oxide fuel cell up to 90 per cent or more. That is a technology in which Australia leads the world. We have made a number of objects out of zirconium oxide, which no other country has succeeded in manufacturing. We have been able to make a very hard ceramic, which is the essential core of the fuel cell and which would substantially increase efficiency in the ways I have indicated. It is a technology the world will be crying out for in 10 to 15 years time; it is a technology for which the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is seeking a modest amount of only $10m or $15m to develop over the next five to six years, yet we find that the Federal Government is failing to support that technology. I repeat: we do not need to become a clever country; we need some wiser government which will see where we must get to in 10 to 15 years time and start making the appropriate investments.

The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Childs, also indicated the development of the very efficient solar photovoltaic cells by Professor Martin Green at the University of New South Wales. As most honourable senators will know, these were on the car which won hands down the solar car race from Darwin to Adelaide, yet the cells in that case, although designed in Australia, were actually manufactured under licence by AEG-Telefunken in Germany and placed on a Swiss car. The technology, including the whole production line on which the cells were made, has been sold to BP Australia but, as the Chairman indicated, BP Solar Australia will make those cells first in Spain, not in this country. This is a technology which is percentage points ahead of the best technology anywhere else in the world. It is a proven technology, not just a laboratory freak-it has been put into a production mode-which again we are likely to lose offshore unless we look at it very seriously in terms of the appropriate support; that is, support to the stage of actually installing it.

Extending from that we find at Sydney University the development of a total solar car, one which would have on board solar cells charging batteries but in which the other solar cells would be on the roof of the carport, charging batteries which would then charge the batteries in the car. One can see the possibility of a transport system in which 70 per cent of all journeys are driven by solar energy. That is a development that we have right here on our doorstep. That is a development that this Government should support; the vision the Government needs to pick up out of this report on the greenhouse effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the report Rescue the Future-reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect. It is really good for a change to be able to commend something wholeheartedly, as I can with this report, in particular its strong statements in support of action rather than further rhetoric, or placatory press releases which pretend to be paying attention to the problem while only putting off decisions on actions which will become more expensive and more difficult the longer we wait. The time for action is obviously immediate.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been some recent papers by experts like Brian O'Brien using their scientific credentials to attempt to lull Australians into believing that we can wait another century before we take this urgent action on greenhouse gas emissions and let future generations worry about the problem. It is hardly a responsible attitude and it is very worrying indeed that some scientists are using their credentials to discredit people who have been making a genuine effort around the globe to enlighten not only governments but also people in the community about the need for urgent action. Some industry figures also seem to be taking this approach, arguing international competitiveness as a reason for inaction rather than looking at trying to improve the energy efficiency of Australian industry and seizing the initiative in areas such as energy efficient and renewable energy technologies, which, as I indicated in my speech on another subject today, would be excellent export opportunities for Australian companies instead of trading in weapons of death.

This is something positive which the world urgently needs and there is a huge market, and the cutting edge is available now for companies that are prepared to take the initiative, obviously with the backing of government. We need to have the research and development funds redeployed from weapons technology and weapons industry to energy efficient industries.

The report comments on energy generation. I support strongly the comments in section 1.7 and chapter four. All opportunities for co-generation and energy savings through efficiency which can be realised at a lower cost than installing new capacity should be exploited before any new power station developments are permitted. It is recommended that the Commonwealth Government take the advice of the Committee and not allow further borrowing by the States to finance such stations until those opportunities have been exploited. In the case of my own State, Western Australia, the State Government is committed to either a new coal-fired power station or a new gas-fired power station and has not really explored the opportunities that already exist for greater energy efficiency. The question is not really being asked at government or industry level about whether we need a new power station at all. That is the important question that should be asked, and the recommendations of this report should be heeded in that respect.

I reiterate that the issue should not be clouded by focusing on the differences between precise predictions of greenhouse effects. As the Committee rightly points out, there is no doubt that the greenhouse effect is real and the weight of evidence is that emission targets are likely to be scaled up rather than down if we are to tackle the problem seriously. The report also points out that there are technologies, such as solid oxide fuel cells, and proven energy management systems that can be adopted to improve greatly the efficiency of energy production and use in Australia. I urge that the Government adopt the Committee's excellent strategies and recommendations and act on them as soon as possible.

I agree with Senator Coulter's remarks about the clever country. The clever country regarding greenhouse will be the one that ends up exporting technology and information on how to be more energy efficient and hence lead the world in cutting greenhouse gas emissions. That huge window of opportunity is wide open right now. Basically I would like to stress that we have heard all the talk; now we need to stop dithering and, in the strongest possible way, encourage action. We need to do something immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join my remarks to those of my colleagues. Firstly, I congratulate the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on this report and thank my colleagues, in particular our Chairman, Senator Bruce Childs. I think Senator Childs has polished tolerance to an art form. While he did say that we were a graceful and conciliatory committee, which is true, in the best of committees there are from time to time strains on the Chair and Senator Childs was exemplary with his tolerance.

SPEECH.PARA: It is fair to say that it was a Committee that largely operated-if not all the time, 99 per cent of it-with goodwill and with a real enthusiasm for what it was doing. We were asked to address a series of questions which were very interesting and relevant. I think all members of the Committee, for whatever reason-our experience, our working background and our histories before we came into the Senate-had an interest in this subject that meant it was of real interest to all of us. I think the Committee benefited from that kind of enthusiasm and inquiry amongst the members of the Committee. I also place on record our appreciation of the Secretary of the Committee, Rob Diamond; the research staff, Peter Hallahan and Sue Morton; and the executive assistant, Glenice Castles. I am also appreciative of the many photographs in this report and I think we should draw attention to the photographer, Peter West, who has done a splendid job of photographing Committee members.

More importantly, I want to make two points tonight. I understand that this debate will be adjourned and there will be time for more contributions on what is a very thorough and comprehensive report, one of those volumes which honourable senators could well put on their shelves and use as a source for basic data.

At the urging of not only our Chairman but also all members of the Committee, the report has been written so that it can be understood by people who are not scientifically literate in these complex areas. The measures of energy and other specific language, particularly of mathematics and so on, can be off-putting to people if they are trying to make sense of this complex question. There are lots of tables and explanatory descriptions in the volume, which means that it can be on the shelves of just about anybody in this community, particularly anyone with an interest in this matter.

While I agree with honourable senators who say that the greenhouse effect is real, I think that to some extent the debate on that is still open. I would prefer to think that it is real and to take that view when we deliberate on these issues. However, we should also be prepared to say that more evidence may still come in on this issue. If we are to be honest and open in our inquiry into the greenhouse effect, we must not rush into judgment about what the greenhouse impact will be and all the things that are claimed to contribute to greenhouse. I hasten to make it clear that that does not mean that I am disbelieving of greenhouse; I am just a long time sceptic.

While appreciating the significance of the prospects of greenhouse and the increasing evidence of it, I make it clear that we have to hasten cautiously before we guarantee all the greenhouse claims are real. I think the report stands with or without the greenhouse effect. Again, let me make it clear that I put my name to and am happy with the words in the report. Notwithstanding the greenhouse effect, this report would hold in terms of its urging energy efficiency and better use of energy. Paragraph 1.5 at page 4 of the report states:

Fortunately there are benefits available immediately through energy efficiency and conservation measures, and the use of renewable energy sources, which would significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions and yield an economic return.

If one takes out the words `reduce greenhouse emissions' the sentence still reads with sense and credibility in terms of use of energy efficient and conservation measures to yield an economic return. I would say to people who are still disbelieving or sceptical about greenhouse that this report deserves their serious examination even if they constrain themselves to only the energy efficiency dimensions. For that reason I could strongly endorse almost all of the remarks of Senator Coulter who, along with others in the debate tonight, referred again and again to more efficient uses of energy. I believe Senator Childs referred to that also. While not wanting to discount the greenhouse effect, I believe the report is valid even if it were not the case.

The Committee believes that it would be possible, through the application of energy conservation and efficiency measures which would yield an economic return, to avoid the building of any more electricity power stations during the critical period of the next 10 years.

That is a direct quote from pages 5 and 6 of the report. I add my support for such considerations already addressed by my colleagues. Under 1.9 at page 6, the point of cost savings and energy efficiency is raised again. Curiously we found that some witnesses who came before us almost found themselves arguing against energy efficiency because of the slow return of benefit to themselves. In the end they seemed to be arguing almost for no change because it was easier and introduced notions of Australia's international competitiveness and so on.

But the evidence given to the Committee clearly suggests that there are huge economic benefits by being energy efficient, not only for government-State or Federal-and the whole community but also for individuals both at the household level and in business and industry. In concluding my remarks on that section, I indicate that the report stands in terms of its very useful information on energy efficiency and the economic benefits that would come from industry and government making sure that they optimised their understanding of the most constructive use of energy in our society. There is talk of energy audits and so on of buildings. Clearly a lot of work can be done. For those who have that kind of interest I think this report is well worth reading.
I now turn to the section highlighting the energy efficiency possible in the transport area. This matter concerned the Committee because, as the report states under 5.1 at page 74:
Transport is the second largest sectoral contributor to Australian carbon dioxide emissions, contributing 26% of the national total. Of this, road transport is responsible for nearly 80%.
Paragraph 5.2 reads:

Cars, station wagons, utilities and panel vans together are the single largest contributor to carbon dioxide emissions in the country and are responsible for 60% of transport sector emissions and 14.8% of national emissions.

Paragraph 5.3 tells us that three-quarters of all car use is for urban transport. There are more constructive pieces of pithy evidence about trucks, road transport and so on. The report spends some time talking about the importance of an integrated national transport strategy. I raise this because in my State of South Australia in very recent times we have seen the closure of three rail passenger services. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Perhaps this is the appropriate stage for me to make a statement on this matter. On 8 and 11 February 1991, Westpac Banking Corporation made two submissions to me suggesting that I should not allow Senator McLean to reveal in proceedings in the Senate two documents, which are said to be advice by Westpac's legal advisers to Westpac, on the grounds of the sub judice principle. Senator McLean, at my invitation, made a submission to me on 12 February 1991 to the effect that he should be permitted to disclose the documents in the Senate because of the public interest in their contents and the freedom of the Senate to debate matters of public interest.

INTERJECT.PARA: This is a difficult and delicate issue on which it is clearly possible for different views to be strongly held. On balance, I do not think that it is appropriate for Senator McLean to reveal in the Senate the contents of the two documents he seeks to disclose, at least while the legal proceedings specifically involving these two documents are still current.

The sub judice rule, which is not a matter of law, but rather the practice of the Senate, is capable of application with varying degrees of strictness. It is always possible for the Presiding Officer, and ultimately the Senate itself, to take the view that any real and present danger to legal proceedings currently in progress is outweighed by the public interest in the matter in question and the prima facie right of the Senate to debate it. The most familiar, and probably the clearest, case for the application of the sub judice principle is one where the material in question goes to the guilt or innocence of a person currently on trial before a jury- and the clearest case for its non-applicability is in the context of a so-called stop writ issued for defamation in a case which is unlikely to be ultimately pursued in court. There are many cases, however, in between where some fine judgment has to be exercised.

In the present case I believe that judgment should be exercised in favour of non-disclosure for the following two reasons. The very subject matter of the case immediately before the courts, and in respect of which the sub judice claim is made, is the question as to whether the documents involved should be suppressed. To disclose the documents now would ipso facto abort that case. No clearer example of real and present danger to current legal proceedings could be imagined. Indeed, it is not merely a matter of the present proceedings being prejudiced, but rather a particular litigant's rights being denied absolutely.

While the subject matter of the documents may raise public interest issues, as Senator McLean strongly argues, there is equally a very clear public interest in judicial proceedings being able, and being seen to be able, to be brought to conclusion without being aborted by the Senate. From this point of view, it is not pertinent that a different situation may be thought to apply in practice once the present proceedings are complete.

There are two other matters to which I have given consideration. Firstly, it is arguable also that the claim of legal professional privilege which has been made in court in relation to these documents itself raises a public interest question, namely, that the Senate should not lend itself to a breach of this privilege being perpetrated. This, in my judgment, is a matter to be given some consideration, but should not be regarded as decisive.

Secondly, it is also arguable that other proceedings current or pending could be prejudiced or at least `coloured' by the public disclosure of the material in question, even though such material would presumably not be admissible, on legal professional privilege grounds, in those proceedings. On balance, however, this is not a matter, I believe, that needs to be addressed at this stage. It can be considered if and when the matter arises again following the conclusion of the present court proceedings relating to the suppression of the documents.
For the reasons I have spelt out I rule, accordingly, on sub judice grounds that the contents of the two documents in question should not be revealed to the Senate.

The disclosure of the documents would appear to be technically contrary to the sub judice principle in that such disclosure could be prejudicial to these proceedings, in the sense that the proceedings would be rendered largely ineffectual. The sub judice principle is always subject to the discretion of the Chair to allow proceedings in the Senate even where those proceedings could be prejudicial to legal proceedings. One of the matters which is taken into account in exercising that discretion is the public interest in the matters in issue and the freedom of the Senate to debate matters of public interest. In applying the sub judice principle, the Chair errs on the side of allowing proceedings in the Senate to be as free as possible.

It is apparent that any decision I make on this matter will rest on an assessment of whether the public interest in the matter and the Senate's freedom to debate it should outweigh the possible prejudice to the legal proceedings.

You are aware that for more than two years I have alleged to the Senate that malpractice and corruption are present in Australian banking. The documents now before you and others to which they refer are, to use their own words, `devastating'. They admit to the malpractice and fraud to which I have attested. But Sir, they go further, they aid and abet the obstruction of just outcomes for those who might seek redress.

Mr President, legal privilege is a fundamental cornerstone of our society; that is to say, the right of an individual to reveal all to her or his legal advisers in total confidentiality so as to clarify where he or she may stand at law. Such a right deserves the protection inherent in legal privilege. However, once having received legal advice that he or she has broken the law, (in this case fraud), any legal advice which follows and which is advice as to how effectively to obstruct justice thereafter does not attract such privilege.

In short, I argue that the documents are self-damning of PPL, Westpac and Allen, Allen &Hemsley. Further, I contend that they are documents of profound public interest which neither attract nor deserve any legal privilege whatsoever.

Of course, I place the same high value on my privilege as a parliamentarian as I ascribe to worthy legal documents. My privilege, which I now feel duty bound to use again in the public interest, is not one to be used lightly. I have not done so in the past and most certainly do not do so now.

Testimony to the potency of these documents lies not only in the words they contain but in the fact that Westpac has sought first, to constrain through injunction, their publication in three countries; second, that Mr Fowler in his opening statement to the House of Representatives Inquiry into Banking sought to have the Inquiry disregard and return them arguing that they enjoyed a privilege which they clearly do not have; third, that Westpac placed large advertisements in national newspapers in a futile attempt to call in all copies of these documents; finally, that they seek your ruling to constrain me from tabling them in protection of the public interest they have so thoroughly abused. Note, Sir, that at no stage has the authenticity of these documents been denied or challenged.

Mr President it is asserted that the question is whether the needs of public interest outweigh the principle of sub-judice. I am advised that the rules of the court relating to sub-judice only apply to protect the impartiality of a jury in civil and criminal proceedings, and only apply when a jury has been impounded. Therefore they are without relevance in this Westpac appeal.

I am informed that there is a presumption of the law that a judge sitting alone, or an appeal court, will have regard only for the matters before the court and will not be swayed or influenced by any extraneous matters. On this advice Sir, I can only conclude that the question of the abuse of the principle of sub-judice is irrelevant. The contents of the letters themselves make clear that the public interest must prevail. But please let me make several points concerning the gravity of the abuse of fiduciary duty as bankers which PPL and Westpac officers have exhibited.

Obviously banks are in a position of gravest responsibility. This is embodied in law in the fiduciary obligation; i.e. the obligation of bankers to consider the interests of their clients equal to their own. These documents clearly state that in the management (indeed in their own admission, non-management) of foreign currency loans, PPL abandoned its fiduciary obligation. These documents attest to the fact that Westpac (and indeed I have argued all four major banks) created a flawed product, promoted it vigorously deliberately marketing it in such a way that all risks lay with the client and all profit lay with the banks.
