SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This week I had intended, as the Senate was advised during the last week of last year's sittings, to bring before it a motion which would establish an inquiry into the administration of the Family Law Act. The Australian Democrats had indicated that they would be supporting this motion and, to that end, Senator Spindler and I had worked for some weeks to come to an agreement on what we believed were the correct terms of reference for that inquiry. At this stage I thank those persons who did so much on the inquiry while I was away at the end of last year: Senator Hill, Senator Boswell, Senator Spindler and also Senator Harradine, who spoke on the issue when I was away.

SPEECH.PARA: But yesterday, at what I can only describe as a somewhat belated stage in the whole of the negotiation process and in the entire history of the issue of trying to get an inquiry into the Family Law Act, the Federal Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) decided, albeit a little reluctantly, to agree to a joint inquiry, which was what we were looking for a year ago. I received the news with some ambivalence. I am very pleased that the Government has agreed to come along on this issue but, as I have said, we in the Senate have actually worked on the terms of reference and I thought the matter could have been finalised this week.

I am very concerned at this change of heart by the Government because it does mean further delays and further negotiations going backwards and forwards for the terms of reference. I am conscious that I have given a commitment directly to hundreds of people, and indirectly to possibly thousands, that this Parliament would establish an inquiry to review the Family Law Act. I had hoped that it could have proceeded last May when I first raised the issue and gave my first notice of motion. I then hoped that it could have been finalised in August at the start of the Budget session. At the end of the last session the Senate had a debate on the subject and it was then intended that the matter would have been finalised between the Democrats and the Opposition in this place. As I said, I thought we would be bringing the full version to the Senate in the next day or so.

I am disappointed, yet grateful, if you like, that the Government has taken so long to agree with this. It could have got under way a year ago when it was first proposed, and we would have had the inquiry well into being and finalised at this stage. I can only advise the Senate that now, having come this far, I do not intend-nor does the Opposition intend-to be put off for much longer. I urge the Attorney-General, in the negotiations with us, to reach a good agreement on the terms of reference as quickly as possible.

This issue, Mr Deputy President, is extremely important and too many people in the community are hurting from the consequences of some of the problems with the Family Law Act. For this Parliament to fiddle around the edges will do us no justice whatsoever, and we owe the people out there a quick and speedy resolution of the terms of reference. If we are to have an inquiry then let us get on with it, and the sooner we start the better. We cannot wait any longer to fix up some of the problems with accessibility, counselling, arbitration and independent mediation and to look at issues such as equitable resolution of custodial and access disputes and the effectiveness of current procedures in arriving at fair and equitable resolution of maintenance and property disputes. These are all issues that were in the original terms of reference a year ago. We have to get on with fixing up the enforcement provisions; with looking at the performance of the Child Support Agency scheme; with looking at whether children are being as well taken into account in a lot of the judgments that are being made within the Act; and with looking also at whether the adversarial procedures should or could be removed from the Family Law Act.

I urge the Attorney-General to resolve quickly to get the terms of reference right so that all those people out there in the community who have been asking for so long for this to be dealt with will get the results that they want. Then we can get this inquiry going and ensure that we have a better Family Law Act at the end of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time has now come, I believe, for Australia to normalise its relations with China. The Australian Government sanctions policy, which has been in place over the past 20 months, should now be ended. The time is ready for constructive dialogue between Australia and China at every level. The opportune time for this Australian initiative was on 1 January 1991, some six weeks ago, but that New Year's Day has now passed and already this week the Chinese new year is passing. I urge the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, who I am glad to see in the chamber this evening, to act now and to act openly and accountably for the sound reasons which I believe are evident and which I will go on to outline.

SPEECH.PARA: It was Australia which imposed sanctions on China and now it must be Australia's decision to remove them. The sanctions were imposed in response to the Beijing massacre on 4 June 1989. The basic facts about the events in and around Tiananmen Square are now consolidated and widely but not universally understood. The sanctions we imposed were soundly based. Certainly they had bipartisan support in this Parliament and support from all elements of the Australian people. These Australian decisions I had myself urged in my own speech here in the Senate on 6 June 1989 when, in part, I said:

Until this past weekend, we in Australia were prepared not to interfere, but to leave Chinese internal decisions to China. But the most recent government decisions and their effects reach far beyond China and they touch us all and we must respond.

For the first time since the late 1970s, the exciting and positive decade or so since the arrest of the Gang of Four, we have seen, at one stroke, the optimism and openness and affection for China and China's development put under the dark shadow of this deadly tragedy in Tiananmen.

Our pain in Australia at this event must be only a small reflection of the pain of the Chinese people. Theirs is a pain mixed with fear; a pain which saps confidence for the present and hope for the future. We weep along side those in China who weep. Our resolve together is for justice and truth and the truth will set us free.

A few days later on Friday 9 June I attended, in the front row, the memorial service for those who lost their lives in Beijing held in the Great Hall of this Parliament. The great sorrow we then felt and expressed is still felt and will not be forgotten.

In the few weeks that followed, sanctions were imposed not only by Australia but also by the United States of America, Japan, the United Kingdom, the European Community, and the Association of South East Asian Nations-indeed, by most countries in the world. There was not only an end made to ministerial contacts in all areas of government but a freezing of aid programs, an end to defence cooperation, no new credit facilities and an end to World Bank and Asian Development Bank assistance. At the same time, overseas business ventures in China were enormously reduced, many overseas education projects terminated and tourism was decimated.

For the Australian Government's part, the original sanctions policy was significantly reiterated both after six months and after 12 months had elapsed but in recent months it has been relaxed. For example, the Chinese Minister for Metallurgical Industry, Mr Qi Yuanjing, was allowed to visit the important Channar iron ore mine in Western Australia last May, and the Vice Foreign Minister, Mr Liu Huaqiu, came to Canberra last August to open the new Chinese Embassy.

Similarly, Dr Blewett, the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, visited Beijing in September for trade talks and Mr Kerin, Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in November to discuss Australian wool and wheat exports. Dr Hewson, Leader of the Opposition, Mr Tim Fischer, Leader of the National Party, Senator Hill, Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and myself as chairman of the Opposition's task force on international relations made a much publicised and successful visit to Shanghai and Beijing for wide-ranging talks last September.

The Opposition visit included meetings with the General Secretary, Mr Jiang Zemin, and the Premier, Mr Li Peng. Subsequently during October a National Party parliamentary delegation led by Mr Lloyd visited China and during November a Liberal Party parliamentary delegation led by Mr Downer visited China. These delegations were foreshadowed during the Hewson delegation visit.

Finally, I visited China again in December and January. As recently as last week there were some other notable visitors to Australia-Mr Rong Yiren, China's leading businessman and, in a separate delegation, Bishop K H Ting, China's leading churchman. Both also hold very senior positions in China's parliamentary bodies-the National Peoples Congress and the Peoples Consultative Congress. I was very glad to have had my own discussions with both of these visitors this past week. During recent months the Australian Government has avoided directly referring to its own sanctions policy, thus leaving the whole area out of the spotlight and ready for change. This development has especially followed the unnecessary remarks of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, in July last year which exposed the untenable and hypocritical position of super vigilance which he then appeared to have adopted. However, the Minister's outburst was not the only occasion for our criticism during this 20-month period of the Australian Government's sanctions policy. Our other criticisms have been more significant.

The first concerns the 20,000 citizens of the Peoples Republic of China, nearly all of whom are students, who were residents in Australia in June 1989, and for whom the Government has overruled our immigration laws and regulations to allow them, en masse, to remain in Australia pending some clearer determination of their immigration status in the four years to June 1993. My own view, which is the Australian Opposition's publicised position, is that this block 20,000 person extension is quite wrong and that each individual application for a change of immigration status should be considered on a case by case basis.

I also believe that the undertakings to return to China, which each of the 20,000 made when they came to Australia should, wherever possible, be honoured. It is my view that the students would suffer no penalty on returning to China. On the contrary they would, by returning, serve very well themselves and their own people and at the same time honour the bilateral education agreements between our countries-indeed, restore their credibility. Also, by returning, they would bring their own experience and skill to serve China's economic, social and political development.

For them to remain in Australia is, in the view of many Australians, a self-indulgence to gain Western material affluence and lifestyle. Only a small minority of the students from China have special humanitarian reasons to jump the queue ahead of the one million applicants Australia considers each year from all over the world and from whom only 120,000 are granted permanent entry and residence in this country.

The second major criticism which the Opposition has made about the Australian Government concerns the period from August 1990 onwards. We have disagreed with the Government's inflexible aloofness from China and the failure to engage in constructive dialogue with China even about the priority issue of human rights in China. It is our contention that the time had come last September to give our own views directly and frankly to China, including our own concerns, and to listen carefully to China's representatives not only on our concerns but also those concerns which China wanted to put on the agenda. Constructive dialogue would explore the reasons for the distance between us and the remedies needed to be made. There has been both substance and emotion in Australia's 1989-90 distancing from China. All the hurt of a `jilted lover' has contributed to Australia's attitude.

However, Australia should not forget the many positive elements of the golden decade of the Australia-China relationship, 1979-1988. Also, we need to look ahead to the whole decade of the 1990s and beyond that to the middle of next century. In a comprehensive speech about China which I gave here in the Senate on 10 and 14 December 1987, I said:

In Australia we should think about not only the current year or the next five years, but the next 50 years, and see what historical precedents there are over recent centuries for the emergence of a country with so vast a human resource to escape the 150 years of suffering that I have outlined. The emergence of China, in partnership with Australia and the other Pacific rim countries such as Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Canada and the United States, will ensure that the Pacific will become the economic centre of gravity for this world in the twenty-first century. I believe that the future lies more and more with an increased Chinese influence in our region, and that region is this important area of the Pacific.

I still strongly believe that we should expect and plan for a greatly increased mutual economic prosperity in the relationship between Australia and China. All the opportunities are there. It is very much to Australia's own benefit to take up these opportunities. Certainly, in my recent visits to China in September last year and in January this year I further explored China's economic planning and I am the more convinced that the following benchmarks ought to be more objectively recognised.

Firstly, China on 30 December last year adopted proposals for drawing up the eighth Five-Year Plan, 1991-1985, and the Ten-Year Program, 1991-2000, both of which are positive and realistic. We can expect these outlines to be implemented by the National People's Congress when it meets next month. Australia should be appraised of these economic plans right from the outset and be in a position to maximise trade, investment and technology contracts to the mutual benefit of ourselves and the Chinese people.

Secondly, China still endorses the October 1987 speech of the then General Secretary, Mr Zhao Ziyang, which set out a new analysis of China's detailed economic and political objectives. The analysis and objectives set out in this speech are still explicitly endorsed by the Party and by the Government and I believe they are still achievable.

By 2050, the Chinese economy will be in gross terms, but not in per capita terms, the largest national economy in the world. On several occasions last month senior Chinese officials told me that Deng Xiaoping has, without any contradiction, declared that `not one word of Zhao Ziyang's 1987 speech will be altered.' It remains China's economic, political and social orthodoxy.

May I remind the Senate that this speech, given to the Party Congress, was broadcast on television and radio all over China. It was seen by the ordinary people everywhere as refreshing and inspiring because, in comparison with earlier statements of this kind, the 1987 analysis was so realistic, flexible, comprehensive and practical. It captivated the nation. It put all earlier economic and political programs into its shadow. It outlined the way for China to consolidate the growth during what I have termed the `golden decade' and to go on to achieve the full modernisation of China within the lifetime of today's students.

Thirdly, China has been chastened by the trauma arising from the Beijing massacre of June 1989. There is a genuine resolve to ensure that these events will never be repeated in China. There is a resolve for stability accompanied by the widening education and political reform necessary to achieve modernisation. There is a resolve to remain permanently open to the outside world. A threshold of awareness has now arrived in China that not only was the Cultural Revolution a disaster never to be repeated but also the Tiananmen tragedy was a disaster never to be repeated.

I now turn to the issue of human rights in China. I believe that sceptical observers-and I include myself-should look beyond the cardboard jargon which over-defensively and unconvincingly asserts the official line that the Tiananmen issue is a matter `internal to China' and about which foreign nations and individuals should not interfere. Rather, it is clear that the great majority of Chinese officials, those with intelligence and ears to hear, have felt from the beginning the horror and rebuke of the Tiananmen events. Moreover, they are genuinely aware of the world's reaction.

The majority of the officials have heard the same message but even more dramatically from the ordinary Chinese people themselves, including their own sons and daughters and the people in the villages and the people in the city streets. It is my observation, for example, that the 13 million people of Shanghai, from top to bottom, hold in contempt the Beijing Government and military apparatus that allowed the Tiananmen disaster to occur. Shanghai, the most prosperous and progressive city in China, has nothing more to learn from Australia's sanctions policy. Their own resolution about the matter is already stronger than ours and it will be more effective. After all, it is their own country they are concerned to get right.

Another significant example is Chengdu, the capital of the 100 million strong province of Sichuan. Here the provincial officials in May 1989 identified themselves with the anticorruption accountability and freedom goals of the demonstrating students. These were among the students all over China who were moved by the death of Hu Yaobang on 15 April 1989 to stand up and vigorously support the principles that Hu had so significantly espoused.

In Chengdu, the anarchy and disarray that occurred arose on 5 and 6 June. The news then from Beijing, which was also mixed with some alarming and false reports, whipped up a very angry demonstration. Some people, who perhaps thought they were helping the students at this time, burnt down the people's cinema and the people's market, two prominent buildings on opposite sides of a major intersection in central Chengdu. However, this enormous vandalism was seen as such by the people, students and government alike, who were horrified by these losses. As a result, the demonstration completely ceased. That was the end of it. Fewer than 30 persons were charged, tried and convicted for destruction of property. No-one was shot; no-one has been imprisoned for holding a political view. In Chengdu, there are no unresolved matters arising from June 1989.

The third example is Chongqing, the major city of the south-west. Here the authorities cooperated with the students and actually cleared the traffic whenever a demonstration was held. Some particular government representatives spoke so convincingly in support of the students' original concerns that no difficulties ever arose. There were no injuries and no arrests in Chongqing. Further examples can be cited: in the south, Kunming; in the centre, Hangzhou, Nanjing and Wuhan; and in the north, Harbin, Shenyang and Dalian. All of these are cities that I have recently visited. The students marched but there were no disturbances, no fighting and no arrests; in fact, the people, the students and the Government had the same reaction of horror at the Beijing events of 4 June, and this reaction effectively meant an end to all these activities.

It has become very clear that the offensiveness of the 4 June crackdown was 90 per cent restricted to Beijing. The horror of it all was the massacre that happened in Beijing. There were no massacres anywhere else in China; there are no unresolved matters arising from these events anywhere else in China. Only in Beijing are there some unconcluded and controversial developments. However, these remaining matters are now in the process of finally being resolved.

In my recent visits I have travelled to all the cities mentioned and I have asked questions of many people. I have also reviewed again videos of the June events in Beijing and Chengdu. I have read most of the articles and books that are available about these events, both by the Chinese writers and by overseas diplomats and journalists. Over the past 20 months I have listened carefully to the assessments of informed Australian observers.

The Beijing massacre occurred on the night of 3 June and the morning of 4 June when the Chinese Army shot many people on the major approach roads to the centre of Beijing. The best estimate is that about 1,000 people were killed by the soldiers shooting. The soldiers' guns were aimed comprehensively at any person in sight on the approach roads to Tiananmen. In addition, about 100 soldiers were killed, most of these by mob violence in the few days preceding 4 June; in fact, it was largely in reaction to these earlier soldiers' deaths that the advancing Army columns were ordered to clear the way to Tiananmen. It also partly explains why these advancing Army columns in the pre-dawn hours of 4 June were so desperately violent. About 1,200 Army vehicles and public buses had already been destroyed by the crowds before the guns were fired; mostly they were burnt by mob violence in the few days preceding 4 June. These were the vehicles which contributed to the road blocks set up on the approach roads to Tiananmen.

Paradoxically, very few students, if any, who were in Tiananmen Square itself were actually killed because the students withdrew to the south of the square in the final hours before the Army columns arrived. It is even possibly true that no-one was actually killed in Tiananmen Square itself. In any event, there is no evidence that tanks rolled back and forth over the bodies of the hunger-striking students in the square. No evidence has ever been presented to substantiate this allegation which was given wide publicity in Australia on 9 June.

What did happen from 4 June onwards is this: the vast amount of material left by the students in the square, including their tent city, was bulldozed and burnt. In addition to the 1,000 people who died in Beijing, there were many more who suffered injuries. Some of these and many others were arrested in the weeks following 4 June, and those arrested were then investigated pending charges being laid for subsequent trial in the courts. It appears that at least 900 persons were arrested for investigation. In the 12 months that followed, some 880 of these were released, many of them in January and May 1990. Some in fact were released at an earlier stage without any charges being made against them. Others suspected of various actual crimes, including the destruction of property, were released for lack of sufficient evidence to convict or for having served a sufficient period of detention to fit the punishment set down by law for these actions.

Last month, on 5 January, the results of the first trials were announced in newspapers and news broadcasts all over China. Eight persons had been in court charged with specific unlawful actions: two were acquitted and released; the other six were sentenced to two years or four years detention. I was told by officials in Beijing that these trials followed normal legal process and that no-one was charged for merely holding a particular political opinion, but only for an action prohibited by law and for which there was sufficient evidence to convict. Those charged had legal representation and the trials were conducted with some public witnesses attending, including family members of the accused. Of course, these trials do `fall far short of international standards', as Amnesty International stated last week. The trials are not fully open to the public, nor are they able to be observed by journalists or diplomats. These omissions, unfortunately, are the common practice in many countries.

I was further told that no-one is detained in Beijing merely for holding political opinions. I was told, quite credibly, that to do otherwise would only repeat the grave mistakes of the Cultural Revolution period. Moreover, the then victims of these grave mistakes are in many cases the officials now responsible for administering these procedures. However, this distinction is not entirely black and white. A grey area remains. It appears that some of the charges currently directed against the relatively few remaining detainees amount to accusations of political action unacceptable to the Government. Whilst political action is a step beyond political thought, it is not at all clear that the action involved was in itself criminal. This issue of course has for centuries been the controversy about accusations of treason.

I asked repeatedly to be told how many students and how many other persons are still being detained. I was never given an exact number. The answer I was eventually given was that it was a relatively small number. I am convinced that the number is limited to Beijing and that the exact number is not publicly available. No reason for this unnecessary secrecy was ever suggested to me. Several officials did tell me that all persons detained were charged with criminal actions and all are to be tried by due legal process. It is usual for all charged persons to be legally represented, the family members are allowed to attend the trial, and the concluded outcome is made public.

My final observation is this: I had until this evening had the expectation that all the remaining court proceedings would be concluded by June 1991-that is, by two years after the original events-but I did not have any guarantee of this. However, it is now my understanding this evening that some radio reports from China today appear to have announced that all the outstanding trials are now completed, with the sentences in these last trials being six years up to 13 years. I certainly hope that the trials are in fact concluded.

When one looks at the evidence from June 1989 and at the deaths, the casualties and the arrests, it is very clear that there was a massacre in Beijing. Moreover, there has never been a massacre like it in Beijing's entire history. Of the many massacres suffered by the Chinese people during the many centuries of dynastic history, none was in Beijing-whether by the invading Mongols, Manchus, Japanese, at the hands of the warlords, in uprisings, in the civil war of the 1940s, or even in the relief of the foreign embassies from the Boxer Rebellion in 1900. Beijing itself has never before seen killing like that of 1989. Naturally it has traumatised Beijing and the trauma is still being felt. It is not now felt anywhere else in China but it is felt in Beijing.

Whereas there is an ease to talk about the June 1989 events in the other cities of China, there is not this ease in Beijing. The trauma is not far below the consciousness of the people everywhere in Beijing. Ironically, it is also seen in the ineffective defensiveness and immature bravado of a minority of senior leaders. It is at the heart of the present lack of coherence in China's leadership. I hope it will not be many months before the robust unity and fully convincing sense of direction returns to China's national leadership in much the same way that it has already returned in Shanghai and in the other regional centres of China.

The major observation I wish to add here is this: the people and leaders of Beijing do not now need foreigners to keep on telling them what they very well know already. They are no longer being any further moved by our sanctions policy; they have already been moved a hundred times more by their own people and by their own sense of horror and loss. Does anyone in this Australian Parliament really think that it is only because we have been prodding them from overseas that the Chinese people have felt the suffering of the Beijing events of June 1989? How patronising and self-righteous that would be. Also, how ignorant that would be of the Chinese people's sense for what is right and just. I seek leave to have the next three paragraphs of my speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Most of the Leaders whom I met in Beijing last month, and some last September, could not be described as defensive or immature or heartless in their evaluation of these matters. The majority of the officials I have met remain close to the people and responsive to the people. The foundations of their thinking show an intelligent and responsive grasp of this enormous trauma even if there is a very inadequate public resolution of and public explanation of these events. The Chinese do not need foreign observers to point this out to them when their own people are crying out for a convincing explanation of why the People's Army shot the people. The Chinese don't need our consciences now, they already have consciences of their own.

There is an enduring patience in the Chinese people that an actual explanation and just resolution will eventually emerge. This patience baffles many in the West and appears cowardly or supine to some. But, for example, the Lin Biao affair of 1971 with all its hypocrisy and secrecy was eventually resolved. Even Mao's mistakes were eventually resolved after his death. The mistakes of the Red Guards have been exposed and resolved: the `ten lost years' of the Cultural Revolution were eventually brought to an end by the 1976 arrest of the Gang of Four. And, remark- ably then, as if pent up for all those ten years, the people all over China rose up and celebrated all night exploding all the available firecrackers and drinking all the available wine. The dark shadow of fear over China had been lifted. The point I wish to make is this: in not one of these examples did the resolution actually depend on any foreign intervention. Not one of these victories for popular justice came about because of sanctions imposed by overseas countries. Perhaps this is the factually correct aspect of the overdrawn claim that such matters as these are ``internal to China''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In conclusion, I wish to summarise the case I am arguing by referring to eight significant reasons why the Australian Government should now end its sanctions policy and normalise Australia's relations with China. Firstly, the objectives of the sanctions policy have already been achieved. Mostly this achievement has been the response to internal pressures from the people of China themselves. There is no turning back now for China's open-door policy and the priority of effective economic and political development of China. In any event, let us avoid the foolishness of thinking that the Chinese need our consciences when they already have sensitive consciences of their own.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, those remaining matters in China which raise objections for Australians-and there are significant remaining objections, such as the failure, to date, to allow journalists and diplomats to attend the trials-will be much more effectively pursued by our direct dialogue with China on the basis of resuming normal relations. Thirdly, the resumption of normal relations does not mean that we have forgotten the horror of the Beijing massacre any more than our building normal relations after 1976 meant that we had forgotten the fear, the abuses and the wasted opportunities of the Cultural Revolution.

Fourthly, we should not fail to remember the positive strengths and advantages of the Australia-China relationship in the golden decade preceding 1989. We should now work to see another decade, the 1990s, build on that established track record and expand anew. In the words of Dr Hewson last September, our vision ought to be the resolution of each country's concerns and the threefold expansion by the year 2000 of our economic relations to the mutual benefit of both countries. Fifthly, now is the opportune time to begin again the expansion of our economic relations. China is about to launch its eighth Five-Year Plan and Australia should be engaged from the outset to maximise trade, investment and technology contracts to the mutual benefit of both countries.

Sixthly, Australia should, as in much of the 1980s, actually set the pace internationally for China's relations. Already Japan, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank have opened some financial doors. Already the foreign Ministers of Europe, of some Asian countries-even Indonesia-have opened some diplomatic doors. Australia should be the first country to drop sanctions and achieve normal relations. We should lead the rest of the world by our own actions.

Seventhly, the past few months have demonstrated the significant role China holds in the United Nations (UN), especially as a permanent member of the Security Council. The Gulf, Cambodia, the shape of the post-Cold War world are all significant international issues where China has begun to make a constructive contribution. China's participation in recent UN decision making has begun to take into account the views of Australia and other nations. We would want China to receive Australia's views positively, and this will be more effectively achieved by returning Australia-China relations to normal.

Finally, Australia has professed to have a special relationship with China. Perhaps because of that we reacted with all the more honesty and conviction in June 1989. If we do have a special relationship, a similar honesty and conviction are called for now to return to direct constructive dialogue and to prove that our remaining difficulties can be addressed and solved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the lateness of the hour, I will be brief as best I can.
—What does that mean? Five minutes, 10 minutes, 20 minutes?

—I do not know. I want to talk briefly about the finding of the Resource Assessment Commission with respect to the Kakadu conservation zone. Without making the obvious observation-that is, that it has achieved absolutely nothing in terms of its definitive findings and in matters of fact-I find the conclusions of the Commission thoroughly astounding in a number of respects.

SPEECH.PARA: It finds that the Jawoyn people are opposed to mining at Coronation Hill, and it finds an intrinsic link between the land areas in the conservation zone, the Coronation Hill area particularly, and the Jawoyn people. Frankly, that flies in the face of all the evidence of substance thus far discovered.

The Commission makes the observation that with respect to the Coronation Hill area three people are judged to be the senior elders. One is Mr Peter Jatbula; the second is Mr Sandy Barraway; and the third is Mr Nipper Brown. It is the claim of the Commission that these three senior elders are opposed to mining Coronation Hill. I say to the Commission frankly that I find that conclusion to be absolutely astonishing.

During the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts into the potential of Kakadu National Park, the Committee took very deliberate evidence from those three witnesses. It was taken in a very informal, relaxed way, providing every opportunity for those elders to articulate their views about mining Coronation Hill. Nipper Brown quite properly identified himself as the senior elder. I asked him in clear terms:
Are you happy for BHP to explore on Coronation Hill?
Nipper Brown responded:
We are all happy if they go ahead and explore for gold or anything like that.
I went on to say:
So mining on Coronation Hill would not hurt Aboriginal sites?
He said:
It can go ahead.
I responded:
Is that one, Coronation Hill, okay?
Nipper Brown said:
Yes.
I asked earlier whether there was a sacred site on Coronation Hill. Nipper Brown said:
Nothing. It is free.
I asked:
Did some people make a mistake and think that Coronation Hill was a sacred site?
Nipper Brown said:
It is free.

The answer is clear and undisguised. It is a commitment under oath in articulate English that mining could and should proceed with his support on Coronation Hill. Further evidence was taken from Barraway, the other elder referred to by the Commission. He gave quite unqualified evidence, firstly, that he had never applied for a sacred site on Coronation Hill and, secondly, that he supported mining in the area.
The Commission, under Justice Stewart, seeks to set aside that evidence by asserting the following when referring to statements:
Others were made in situations of some pressure, such as the appearance of the men before a Senate Standing Committee.

With respect, that is thoroughly untrue and it reeks of impertinence. Being on the Committee and being present, I am well aware of the environment and the circumstances in which that evidence was given. It is thoroughly presumptuous for the Commission to dismiss out of hand that evidence on the basis of its assumption and presumption that the evidence was given under some sort of pressure. Frankly, in a very impertinent way the Commissioner goes on to say:

There may have been times when the responses of the senior Jawoyn men to questions about Coronation Hill and their views about mining were a reflection of their internal struggle to find an appropriate balance between religious and material imperatives. When subjected to pressure from outside sources, it is not surprising that they sometimes expressed what appeared to be contradictory views.

In other words, the Commissioner said that they were agonising between the morality of their religion, the fundamental spiritual beliefs and the offer of money, and that is why there were contradictions. In other words, some of the time they were telling the truth and the rest of the time they were being expedient. I do not know what evidence the Commission took to justify that assertion, but as one who took evidence from those people I found their integrity impeccable, their responses articulate and their understandings precise. Their knowledge of the questions was crystal clear and the environment one of thorough confidence and relaxation.

We made a point of ensuring that no press and no members of the public were allowed in. It was a very informal meeting around a circular table. Yet that evidence-clear, unqualified, specific and to the point-is dismissed by the Commission as evidence given, first, under pressure because they were before a Senate committee and, secondly, because they were agonising over telling the truth about their spiritual relationship with the land and the financial imperatives. If that is the basis of the conclusions drawn by the Commission in respect of that matter, I have grave concerns about the rest of the findings.

The second matter is the intrinsic spiritual relationship between the Jawoyn people, Coronation Hill and, to wit, the conservation zone. In an application for land rights by the Jawoyn people, a hearing before Justice Kearney, areas 4 and 5, which abut Kakadu National Park and which are in the proximity of South Alligator River, were dismissed by Justice Kearney. He had this to say:
The two senior claimants who spoke with knowledge of Areas 4 and 5-
these applications for land rights were the closest to Coronation Hill-
Peter Jatbula and Sandy Barraway-
these are two of the three elders referred to by the commissioners as having the authority-

did not convey an impression of interest in those areas or of any strong attachment to them. While several sites in the vicinity of Areas 4 and 5 were named and their associated Dreamings identified, no evidence to establish common spiritual affiliations by the claimants to those sites or the performance of spiritual responsibilities for those sites was given in either open or closed sessions of the enquiry. At transcript p.1156 Dr Merlan-
note: Dr Merlan-

considered that the Jawoyn were exercising primary spiritual responsibility for Bekluk (No. 17, Q2) on Area 4 and Gunlom (No. 86, K2) on Area 5; however, the basis of that opinion was not stated and I do not give it any weight.
That was evidence given by Dr Merlan, who was the consultant engaged by the Commission to provide expert evidence. Justice Kearney went on to say in respect of those two areas:

However, the traditional evidence put forward in relation to Areas 4 and 5 is insufficient to enable any finding to be made that the members of that group (or any group, for that matter) are the traditional Aboriginal owners of those areas, within the meaning of the Act. While there are sites on both areas and Dreamings to which the Jawoyn have links, for example, through the travelling Dreamings Gupu (Kangaroo) . . . the existence of common spiritual affiliations to sites on Areas 4 and 5 or to sites which can be linked with those areas, is not established; nor is there evidence of a strong traditional attachment to Areas 4 and 5. Accordingly, the claim to Areas 4 and 5 fails.

He says that there is no spiritual link, no intrinsic link, and there is no clear relationship. This judgment was made by the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 before the Land Rights Commissioner who took evidence exclusively in order to make those assessments. Yet the Commission, in a prosecution of another term of reference, dismisses the findings by saying that the terms of reference of Justice Kearney were not relevant to the relationship between the Aboriginal community and the land.

Frankly, that is absolute bunkum. If they cannot claim a land right, what is the measure, the test, of their relationship with the land which allows them an opportunity to negotiate with BHP Gold, as it then was, for royalties? What is their claim which allows them to have a say in whether mining ought to proceed? What is their claim, upon which the Commissioner makes a judgment, in respect of whether or not mining ought to proceed? Clearly, it is something other than that which can be found at law. The Committee took evidence from a Ms Wynjorroc and Ms Flora. Both of them gave clear, unqualified evidence. I quote:
Senator Crichton-Browne: Would you be happy for there to be mining on Coronation Hill?
Ms Wynjorroc: Yes.
Ms Flora: Yes.
Ms Wynjorroc: It is okay on that land.

Ms Wynjorroc went on to make some other claims that there was no Bula site, no sacred site, on Coronation Hill. It is not without significance to note in respect to the land claim application that substantial evidence was taken by Mr Justice Kearney from those two women. He relied upon their evidence as expert evidence and was proud enough to publish photographs of both the women throughout the report. Both those women said that there were no sacred sites or areas of significance. In fact, Eva Valley, which is to the south of Coronation Hill, was referred to in the report. Justice Kearney says:
The claimants stated what was not Jawoyn country as emphatically as they stated what was their country. For example, when Willy Bye-
who is also an elder of some standing-
was describing the extent and the borders of Jawoyn territory he remarked of Eva Valley:
We got nothing to do with them fellows. That is Mayali.

That is an area of another Aboriginal community. Eva Valley is further to the south than Coronation Hill. Yet we are now being persuaded by the Commission that this is an area of significance. The Land Commissioner said:
Sandy Barraway-
referred to as one of the authorities-

provided a fairly complete outline of Jawoyn country, referring to sites, European and Aboriginal place names and the countries of bordering Aboriginal groups. By his account, Mayali country is to the north of the Jawoyn, in the vicinity of the South Alligator River . . .
Nobody knows better than Senator Gareth Evans where Coronation Hill is-South Alligator River; not in the Jawoyn country, according to the findings of Justice Kearney.

One of the findings of the Resource Assessment Commission, which was seeking to resolve the conflict, in its inclination to believe that the Jawoyn people were opposed to mining, and having regard to the compelling evidence given under oath before a Senate committee, was:

In this respect, the Inquiry has found that the discussion paper prepared by Mr Robert Levitus and appended to the submission of the Aboriginal Areas Protection Authority (Submission 77) is of great assistance in understanding Jawoyn people's evolving attitudes to the mining question.

There was nothing evolving about the attitude of the Jawoyn people in their evidence to us. But what is of significance is that the Aboriginal Areas Protection Authority was deeply and subjectively involved in seeking to persuade the Jawoyn people that mining in the Kakadu region, the Coronation Hill region, was wrong and bad. It makes no secret of the fact that it went to a number of meetings of the Jawoyn people and harangued them and sought to persuade them not to agree to negotiate with BHP, not to agree to any mining, and yet they are now held up as authorities.

There is reference to Mr Cooper. Mr Cooper gave evidence to our Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. He was so emotionally involved, it was difficult to distinguish between fiction and fact in his evidence. In respect to those two matters I find it remarkable that the Commission finds in the way it does. If I were a less charitable man, I would draw the conclusion that it was trying to find facts to fit its findings. On page 110, when referring to the economic advantage to the Aboriginal community, it says:
Royalty and other revenues that might flow from the Coronation Hill project to Jawoyn and other Aboriginal people have the potential to deliver positive benefits-
then it qualifies the matter-
but realisation of these benefits depends on the establishment of sound management structures and access to good financial advice.

I find that remarkable. In the case of Koongarra, if mining is ever to proceed under this Government-and we know that it will not; it will take the next or another-they are entitled to receive $256m in royalties. Already, if my calculations are correct, the Aboriginal community that lays claim to the area which contains the Ranger uranium mine has received $50m in royalties. Nobody is claiming that they need some special managers. There is no qualification about the benefits that they are receiving.

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you finished yet?

—There are two other quick matters I will touch upon. I do not speak unkindly about the anthropologists who acted as consultants on this occasion, but this seems a quaint way of doing business. The Resource Assessment Commission engaged, as best I am able to understand, Dr Merlan and it refers to her evidence in an authoritative way as explaining the contradictions in respect of the sickness country. I must say that what is now described as the `sickness country' by the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority seems to be a new phenomenon which has appeared in the last three decades. To my knowledge, up to that point it had not been known of.
—Buffalo country.

—Clapped out buffalo country, as it was articulately and precisely referred to by Senator Evans. Dr Merlan is in the unique position of identifying sacred sites in the conservation zone. The Aborigines registered them with her assistance because she found the sites for them and she then gave evidence to the Sacred Sites Authority for their registration. Then when an application for land rights was made, she gave expert evidence that they were sacred sites. I would have thought that in normal circumstances that would be a conflict of evidence. But we have a potential situation where Dr Merlan finds a sacred site and then gives evidence on a land claim that it is a sacred site. That is hardly the best way of doing business, yet it seems to me that the Commission fell into the same trap of using that as expert advice.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, there is an assertion in this report that there is little benefit in terms of work for the Aboriginal community. If my memory serves me correctly, when we in the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts did our report there were a minimum of 13 Jawoyn people engaged on site and 65 others who were seeking employment. My distinct impression was that there was overwhelming support. If a plebiscite had been conducted-that is not the way that the Aboriginal community does business-I feel that there would have been a strong expression by the Jawoyn people in support of mining at Coronation Hill.

In light of the hour and the education of Senator Evans, who presumably wants to go home and watch the late night news, I will not keep the Senate a great deal longer other than to say that on page 24 of volume 2 the Commission says:
Keen and Merlan-
that is the Dr Merlan to whom I previously referred-
reviewed the circumstances in which these apparently contradictory statements were made.

The Commission was referring to the fact that the elders had told the Senate Standing Committee in a clear and articulate way, as I said, that they supported mining, but that they told the Authority-aided, abetted, intimidated and threatened in all sorts of ways, I suspect, by the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority-they did not. The Commission had Keen and Merlan review the circumstances. The report continues:

They suggest that some of the statements may have been responses to situations of substantial pressure or fear and that others may be responses to questions that are poorly understood or poorly phrased for people who speak English as a second language . . .

I am not going to retrace the simple four-word, one syllable questions that I asked, but Nipper Brown had no difficulty understanding me when he was asked the very simple question: is Coronation Hill free? He said yes. I asked whether it was free? He said that there was nothing there and mining was okay. I said during the hearing that it should not be thought that there was an atmosphere of officialdom in this hearing. I asked whether everybody was quite relaxed, whether everybody felt comfortable answering the questions, whether they would like an adjournment, whether they all understood the question. The witnesses all nodded vigorously and said that they were quite relaxed. Yet we were told by Merlan that it was because of perhaps substantial pressure in some cases or because the responses were to questions poorly understood. That is simply not the case.

I shall pursue the balance of my concerns about this report at a later stage, but suffice it to say that the Resource Assessment Commission has been a waste of time. I now have grave doubts about the integrity of the findings and the validity of the manner in which the Commission went in pursuit of its findings. I have no doubt that on the matters of which I have knowledge the Commission's report is fundamentally wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nights like this on the adjournment in the Senate that make me deeply appreciative of the opportunities my present job gives me to serve my country overseas. A number of contributions have been made tonight. The least said about Senator McLean's, the better. Senator Crowley contributed to our knowledge of women's sport, and I join with her in congratulating Kerry Saxby on her spectacular world record breaking performance. I am sure Senator Brownhill's contribution on the review of the Family Law Act will be read with assiduous attention by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), as it was intended to be. I expect he will act accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution on the Resource Assessment Commission report on Coronation Hill is, I guess, just the forerunner of many more contributions on this subject. I do not want to make any contribution myself tonight except perhaps to lay to rest once and for all the canard that I ever actually referred to the Coronation Hill area or the South Alligator River valley as `clapped out buffalo country'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What part was it then? Just the whole conservation zone?
—That description did escape my lips in relation to some country to the west of the South Alligator River-the south-west corner of the stage 2 area.
—But in the World Heritage listing area.

—It is within stage 2, as I recall it, of the Kakadu area. The description may or may not have been accurate; it was certainly graphic. I just make the point that, for all its subsequent repetition, it has no relevance whatsoever to the ongoing debate about Coronation Hill, because that area is manifestly of scenic and other significance, and I do not think too many buffalo have been anywhere near it, quite apart from anything else.
—I like the way you work, Gareth.

—The most substantial contribution tonight, with the utmost respect to Senator Crichton-Browne-particularly after his flash remark just then-was that of Senator Teague on the subject of China. It was an interesting contribution to what is an ongoing debate in this country. I will read both it and the more extensive paper which I know Senator Teague has prepared on this topic with close attention.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make clear to him that the issue of our relationship with China is not one about which the Government has been cavalier or indifferent. I think it is unfortunate that he marred his presentation tonight by his characterisation of the Government's behaviour in relation to China after Tiananmen, or the Beijing massacre, as that of a jilted lover. The truth of the matter is that Australia's reaction, while emotional, was no more so than that of most other countries around the world which did react with horror to the violence that occurred on that occasion and which regarded it then, as now, as totally indefensible. I think it does trivialise that reaction to describe it in those terms.

Equally, I do not think it is fair to describe the measures which we took-in common with so many other countries-to convey our displeasure of the situation as being patronising, self-righteous or, indeed, unproductive for Australia to join in as part of a world wide-or, at least, Western country wide-response to what was a most unhappy situation. It was always part of the Australian response to maintain lines of communication and access to China. The breach in our relations has never been absolute, and deliberately so because we acknowledge the force of many of the points that Senator Teague made in his contribution tonight.

The downgrading of aspects of the relationship was not intended to be permanent. That was made clear in 1989 and, again, at the time of subsequent reviews that have been the subject of later public announcements. Nor is it intended now that the restrictions that are presently in place will go on forever. More than that, we are, in fact, giving close consideration right now to their continued application.

Apart from questions of defence sales, visits by security officials and so on, which will no doubt go on being very sensitive for a good deal longer yet, the particular restrictions in the relationship to which we are presently giving close attention are the suspended procedures for consideration for technical cooperation and agricultural research projects; the suspended consideration of the availability of new concessional finance for development assistance projects; and, of course, the question of parliamentary and formal party visits in respect of which the Government policy has continued to apply fairly stringent limitations, albeit ones that have been more honoured in the breach than in the observance by the Opposition side of politics in recent months.

In considering all these matters, it is very difficult to apply absolute considerations. To deal in any absolute way with the situations we confront is always a matter of drawing an appropriate balance between competing demands, competing objectives. It is always a matter of judgment as to how these responses should be applied, taking into account the nature of our relationship, the nature of the great issues of principle that are involved and, among other things, the nature of the reaction of other like-minded countries, and I can assure Senator Teague that all these things are being very closely considered at the moment.

One of the matters that is always relevant in considering these kinds of issues is the question of timing. It is the case, as Senator Teague himself acknowledged in his speech, that that is a particularly sensitive matter at the moment with a number of remaining trials either taking place or just concluded in Beijing. That is something that the Government, again, will need to bring into account in its deliberations on these matters.

I say no more than that. This is an appropriate matter for serious policy debate in this place. The Government has never sought to trivialise that and it has never been insensitive to the need to think very carefully about the way in which we handle these aspects of our relationship. Having said all of that, I suggest, Mr President, that it is now more than time for the Senate to adjourn.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12.15 a.m. (Wednesday)
